div.p: ESSAYS Of the STRANGE SUBTILTY GREAT EFFICACY DETERMINATE NATURE OF EFFLUVIUMS.
To which are annext NEW EXPERIMENTS To make FIRE and FLAME Ponderable: Together with A Dicovery of the Perviounes of GLASS.
BY The Honorable ROBERT BOYLE, Fellow of the Royal Society.
div.q: —Conilium et, univerum opus Intaurationis (Philoophiae) potius promovere in multis, quàm perficere in paucis.
div.p: LONDON: Printed by W. G. for M. Pitt, near the little North Door of St Paul's Church. 1673.

div.head: An Advertiement to the READER.
div.p:
'TIS hop'd, the Reader will not think it trange, not to meet with in the following Papers a more cloe and uniform contexture of the paages that make them up, if he be eaonably inform'd of the rie and occaion of penning them, which was this. The Author having many years ago written an Eay about an Experiment he made of Nitre, by whoe Phaenomena he endeavour'd to exemplifie ome parts of the Corpucular Philoophy, epecially the Production of Qualities; he afterwards threw together divers occurring thoughts and experiments, which he uppos'd might be imployed by way of Notes, to prove or illutrate thoe Doctrines, and epecially thoe that concern'd the Qualities of Bodies; and among thee
oberving thoe that are call'd Occult, to be Subjects uncultivated enough, (at leat in the way that eem'd to him proper,) he propos'd to handle them more largely than mot of the ret; and in order to that Deign he judg'd it almot neceary, to premie ome Coniderations and experimental Collections about the Nature and power of Effluviums, about the Pores of Bodies and Figures of Corpucles, and about the efficacy of uch Local-motions as are wont either to be judged very faint, or to be pas'd by unheeded. For he had often look'd upon thee three Doctrines, of Effluvia, of Pores and Figures, and of Unheeded Motions, as the three principal Keys to the Philoophy of Occult Qualities. But having hereupon made uch Collections, as upon review appear'd too large to pas for Notes on o hort a Text, he was induc'd to draw themAnd ome that were publih'd An. 1669. under the Title of The Atmopheres of conitent Bodies. into the form (they now appear in) of Eays; but he would not put himelf to the trouble of doing it, with care to keep
them from retaiaing much of their firt want of exact Method and Connexion. Nor was the Author olicitous to finih them up, in regard that his other Studies and occaions made him perceive, that in what he had deign'd about Occult Qualities, he had cut himelf out more work than probably he hould during many years have opportunity to et upon in earnet, and complete. And in this Condition thee Papers lay for divers years, (as is well known to everal that aw them, or even trancrib'd ome of them,) and might have continued to do o, if the Author had not been induc'd to let them come abroad, partly by conidering, that though the Subjects, (however he handled them) were as well important as curious, yet he did not find himelf prevented by others in what he had to publih about them; and partly by the References he had made to them in ome other Papers, that he had promied his Friends, wherein everal things here deliver'd are vouched, and others uppos'd. And becaue the Notes concerning the Poroity of greater Bodies and the
Figurations of minute Particles, together with the Paper about unregarded Motions, having been long laid aide among other neglected papers, were ome of them miing, and others o mis-us'd, that they could not eaily be made ready to accompany thoe that now come abroad; the Author, that he might keep this Book from having its dimenions too diproportionate, was content to add to the thicknes of it, by ubjoyning one of thoe little Tracts, that lay by him, concerning Flame, becaue of the Affinity betwixt the preceding Doctrine about Effluviums in general, and Experiments that hew in particular the Subtilty and the Efficacy of thoe of Fire and Flame. And though, to that Tract it elf, there belong another, deign'd to examine, Whether the matter of what we call the Sun-beams, may be brought to be ponderable; yet uppoing this, hitherto cold and wet Summer, to be like to be as unfriendly to the Tryals to be made with Burning-glaes as of late years ome other Summers have prov'd, he was eaily prevail'd with, not to make thoe Experiments
that were ready, wait any longer for thoe, that probably will not in a hort time be o; epecially ince thoe that now come abroad have no dependency upon the others.
OF THE Strange SUBTILTY OF EFFLUVIUMS.
BY The Honorable ROBERT BOYLE.
LONDON: Printed by W. G. for M. Pitt at the ign of the White Hart, over-againt the little North Door of St Paul's Church. 1673.

div.head: OF The trange SUBTILTY OF EFFLVIMS.
CHAP. I.
div.p:
WHether we uppoe with the Antient and Modern Atomits, that all enible Bodies are made up of Corpucles, not only inenible, but indiviible; or whether we think with the Carteians, and (as many of that Party teach us) with Aritotle, that Matter, like Quantity, is indefinitely, if not infinitely diviible: It will be cononant enough
to either Doctrine, that the Effluvia of Bodies may conit of Particles extremely mall. For if we embrace the Opinion of Aritotle or Des-Cartes, there is no top to be put to the ub-diviion of Matter, into Fragments, till leer and leer. And though the Epicurean Hypotheis admit not of uch an interminate diviion of Matter, but will have it top at certain olid Corpucles, which for their not being further diviible are called Atoms ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ,) yet the Aertors of thee do jutly think themelves injured, when they are charged with taking the Motes or mall Dut, that fly up and down in the Sun-Beams, for their Atoms; ince, according to thee Philoophers, one of thoe little grains of Dut, that is viible only when it plays in the Sun-Beams, may be compoed of a multitude of Atoms, and exceed many thouands of them in Bulk. This the Learned Gaendus in his Notes on Diogenes Laertius makes probable by the intance of a mall Mite, which, though carce
ditinctly dicernable by the naked Eye, unles when 'tis in motion, does yet in a good Microcope appear to be a compleat Animal, furnihed with all neceary Parts; which I can eaily allow, having often in Cheee-Mites very ditinctly een the Hair growing upon their Legs. And to the former Intance I might add, what I have elewhere told you of a ort of Animals far leer than Cheee-Mites themelves, namely thoe that may be often-times een in Vinegar. But what has been already aid may uffice for my preent purpoe, which is only to hew, that the wonderful minutenes I hall hereafter acribe to Effluvia, is not inconitent with the mot received Theories of Naturalits. For otherwie in this Eay the Proofs I mean to employ, mut be taken, not à Priori, but à Poteriori. And the Experiments and Obervations I hall employ on this occaion will be chiefly thoe, that are referrible to one of the following Heads.

list.item: I. The trange Extenibility of ome Bodies whilst their Parts yet remain tangible.
II. The multitude of Viible Corpucles, that may be afforded by a mall portion of Matter.
III. The mallnes of the Pores at which the Effluvia of ome Bodies will get in.
IV. The mall decrement of Bulk or Weight, that a Body may uffer by parting with great tore of Effluvia.
V. The great quantity of Space that may be fill'd, as to ene, by a mall quantity of Matter when rarified or dipers'd.

div.p:
But though to thee ditinct Heads I hall deign ditinct Chapters, yet you mut not expect to find the Intances olicitouly marhall'd,This Eay was deigned to be but a part of the Author's Notes upon his Eay about Salt-peter. but et down in the order they occurr'd to me; uch a liberty being
allowable in a Paper, where I pretend not to write Treaties, but Notes

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: AMong many things that are gros enough to be the Objects of our Touch, and to be managed with our Hands, there are ome that may help us to conceive a wonderful minutenes in the mall Parts they conit of.

I do not remember what Cardan, and ince him another Writer have deliver'd about the Thinnes and Slendernes to which Gold may be brought. And therefore without poitively aenting to, or abolutely rejecting what may have been aid about it by others, I hall only borrow on this occaion,In a Paper about Improbable Truths. what I have mention'd on another upon my own Obervation; namely,
That Silver, whoe Ductility and Tractility are very much inferiour to thoe of Gold, was, by my procuring, drawn out to o lender a Wire, that, when we meaur'd it, which was omewhat troubleom to do, with a long and accurate meaure, we found, that eight Yards of it did not yet fully counterpoie one Grain: So that we might add a Grain more without making the Scale, wherein 'twas put, manifetly preponderate, notwithtanding the Tendernes of the Ballance. Whence we concluded, that a ingle Grain of this Wire amounted to 27 Foot, that is, 324 Inches. And ince Experience informs us, that half an Englih Inch can by Diagonal Lines be divided into 100 parts great enough to be eaily ditinguih'd, even for Mechanical ues, it follows, that a Grain of this wiredrawn Silver may be divided into 64800 parts, and yet each of thee will be a true metalline, though but lender and hort, Cylinder, which we may very well conceive to conit
yet of a multitude of minuter parts. For though I could procure no Gilt Wire near o lender as our newly mention'd Silver-wire; yet I tryed that ome which I had by me was mall enough to make one Grain of it fourteen foot long: At which rate an Ounce did amount to a full Mile, coniting of 1000 Geometrical Paces, (of 5 foot a-piece,) and 720 foot over and above. And if now it be permitted to uppoe the Wire to have been, as in probability it might have been, further drawn out to the ame lendernes with the above-mention'd Silver-wire, the Intance will till be far more coniderable; for in this cae, each of thoe little Cylinders, of which 64800 go to the making of one Grain, will have a uperficial Area, which, except at the Bais, will be cover'd with a Cae of Gold; which is not only eparable from it by a mental Operation, but perhaps alo by a Chymical one. For I remember, that from very lender gilt Wire, though I could get
none o lender as this of meer Silver, I did more than once, for Curioities ake, o get out the Silver, that the golden Films, whilt they were in a Liquor that plumpt them up, eem'd to be olid wires of Gold: But when the Liquor was withdrawn, they appear'd, (as indeed they were) to be oblong and extremely thin and double Membranes of that Metal, which, with an Intrument that had been delicate enough, might have been ripp'd open, and diplayed, and been made capable of further. Diviions and Subdiviions. To this I hall add, that each of the little ilver Cylinders I lately pake of, mut not only have its little Area, but its Solidity; and yet I aw no reaon to doubt, but that it might be very poible, if the Artificer had been o skilful and willing as I wih'd, to have drawn the ame quantity of Metal to a much greater length, ince even an Animal ubtance is capable of being brought to a lendernes much urpaing that of our Wire, uppoing the Truth
of an Obervation of very credible Perons critical enough in making Experiments, which, for a Confirmation and an Improvement of our preent Argument, I hall now ubjoyn. An Ingenious Gentlewoman of my Acquaintance, Wife to a Learned Phyician, taking much pleaure to keep Silk-worms, had once the Curioity to draw out one of the Oval Caes, (which the Silk-worm pins, not, as 'tis commonly thought, out of its Belly, but out of the Mouth, whence I have taken pleaure to draw it out with my Fingers,) into all the Silken-wire it was made up of, which, to the great wonder as well of her Husband, as her elf, who both inform'd me of it, appeared to be by meaure a great deal above 300 Yards, and yet weigh'd but two Grains and a half: o that each Cylindrically hap'd Grain of Silk may well be reckon'd to be at leat 120 Yards long.

Another way, I remember, I alo employed to help men by the extenibility of Gold the better to conceive
the Minutenes of the Parts of Solid Bodies.

We took ix beaten Leaves of Gold, which we meaured one by one with a Ruler purpoely made for nice Experiments, and found them to have a greater equality in Dimenions, and to be nearer true Squares, than could be well expected: The ide of the Square was in each of them exactly enough three Inches and 2/8, (or 1/4,) which number being reduc'd to a Decimal Fraction, viz. 3125/100, and multiplied by it elf, affords 10|5625/10000 for the Area, or uperficial Content of each quare Leaf: And this multiplied by 6, the number of the Leaves, amounts to 63|3750/10000 quare Inches, for the Area of the ix Leaves. Thee being carefully weigh'd in a pair of tender Scales, amounted all of them to one Grain and a quarter: And o one Grain of this foliated Gold was extended to omewhat above fifty Inches; which differ'd but about a fifth part from an Experiment of the like nature, that I remember I made
many years ago in a pair of exact Scales; and o mall a difference may very well be imputed to that of the pains and diligence of the Gold-Beaters, who do not always work with equal trength and skill, nor upon equally fine and ductile Gold.

Now if we recal to mind what I was lately aying of the actual diviibility of an Inch into an hundred enible parts, and uppoe an Inch o divided to be applied to each ide of a quare Inch of the Leaf-Gold newly mention'd, 'tis manifet that by ubtle parallel Lines, drawn between all the oppoite Points, a Grain of Gold mut be diviible into five hundred thouand little Squares, very minute indeed, but yet dicernible by a ufficiently harp-ighted Eye. And if we uppoe an Inch to be divided into two hundred parts, as I lately told you it was in a Ruler I employ, then, according to the newly recited way, the number of the Squares, into which a ingle Grain is capable of being divided, will amount to no les than two Millions.
There is yet another way that I took to hew, that the extenibility, and conequently the diviiblenes of Gold is probably far more wonderful, than by the lately mention'd Tryal it appears.

For this purpoe I went to a great Refiner, whom I ued to deal with for purify'd Gold and Silver, and inquir'd of him, how many Grains of Leaf-Gold he was wont to allow to an Ounce of Silver, when it was to be drawn into gilt Wire as lender as an Hair? To this he anwer'd me, that eight Grains was the proportion he allowed to an Ounce when the Wire was to be well gilt; but if it were to be more lightly gilt, ix Grains would erve the turn. And to the ame purpoe I was anwer'd by a skilful Wire-drawer. And I remember, that deiring the Refiner to hew me an Ingot of Silver, as he did at firt gild it; he hew'd me a good fair Cylindrical Bar, whereon the Leaf-Gold, that overlaid the urface, did not appear to be by
odds o thick as fine Venetian Paper; and yet comparing this with gilt Wire, which I alo deired to ee, the Wire appeared to be the better gilt of the two; poibly becaue the Gold in paing through the various Holes, was by the ides of them not only extended but polihed, which made it look more vividly than the unpolih'd Leaves that gilded the Ingot.

So that, if we uppoe an Ounce of the gilt Wire formerly mention'd to have been gilt with ix Grains of Leaf-Gold, it will appear by an eaie calculation, that at this rate one Ounce of Gold, employ'd on gilding Wire of that lendernes, would reach between ninety and an hundred Miles. But if now we further uppoe, as we lately did, that the lender Silver-wire, mention'd at the beginning of this Chapter, were gilt; though we hould allow it to have (becaue of its exceeding lendernes,) not, (as the former) 6 Grains, but 8 Grains of Leaf-Gold to an Ounce of Siver,
it mut be acknowledged, that an hollow Cylinder or heath of Gold weighing but eight Grains, may be o tretch'd, that 'twill reach to no les than 60 times as much (in weight) of Silver-wire as it covers: [I aid 60 times, for o often is 8 contain'd in 480, the number of Grains in an Ounce;] and conequently (a Grain of that Wire having been found to be 27 foot long,) the Ounce of Gold would reach to even hundred eventy even thouand ix hundred foot, that is, an hundred fifty five Miles and above a half. And if we yet further uppoe this uperficial or hollow Cylinder of Gold to be lit all along, and cut into as lender lits or thongs as may be, we mut not deny that Gold may be made to reach to a tupendious length. But we need not this lat uppoition to make what preceded it an amazing thing: which yet though it be indeed Stupendious and eem Incredible, ought not at all to be judg'd Impoible, being no more than what upon the
Suppoitions and Obervations above laid down, does evidently follow.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: AFter what has been aid of the minutenes of tangible Objects, 'twill be proper to ubjoyn ome intances of the mallnes of uch as yet continue viible. But in regard thee Corpucles are ingly too little to have any common meaure apply'd to any of them, we mut make an etimate of their minutenes by the number of thoe into which a mall portion or fragment of matter may be actually divided, the multitude of thee being afforded by o inconiderable a Quantity of matter, ufficiently declaring, that each of them, in particular, mut be marvelouly little.

Among the intances, where the mallnes of Bodies may be deduc'd from what is immediately the Object of Sight, it may not be unfit to take
notice of the evaporation of Water, which though it be granted to conit of gros particles in comparion of the pirituous and odoriferous ones of divers other Liquors, as of pure Spirit of Wine, Eential Oyls of Spices, &c. yet to hew that a mall Quantity of it may be dipers'd into a multitude of manifetly viible Corpucles, I thought upon, and more than once try'd, the rarefaction of it into Vapors by help of an Aeolipile, wherein, when I made the Experiment the lat time, I took the pains to regiter the Event as follows.

We put an Ounce of common Water into an Aeolipile, and having put it upon a Chaing-dih of coals, we oberv'd the time when the treams of Vapors began to be manifet. This tream was for a good while impetuous enough, as appear'd by the noie it made, which would be much increaed, if we applied to it at a convenient ditance a kindled brand, in which it would blow up
the fire very vehemently. The tream continued about a quarter of an hour (ixteen minutes or better,) but afterwards the Wind had paues and guts for two or three minutes before it quite ceaed. And by reaon of the hape of the Aeolipile, (which being fram'd chiefly for other purpoes, was not o convenient for this) a great portion of the Vapors condens'd in the upper part of it, and fell down in drops; o that uppoing that they alo had come out in the form of Wind, and the blat had not been intermitted toward the latter end, I gues'd it might have continued uninterruptedly 18 or 20 minutes. Note, That applying a meaure to the Smoak, that came out very viible in a form almot conical, where it eem'd to have an Inch or more in Diameter, 'twas ditant from the hole of the Aeolipile about twenty Inches; and five or ix Inches beyond that, though it were pread o much, as to have four or five Inches in Diameter, yet the not uniform
but till-cohering Clouds (which was the form wherein the Vapors appear'd) were manifet and conpicuous.

After the rarefaction of Water when 'tis turn'd into Vapors, we may conider that of Fewel when 'tis turn'd into Flame; to which purpoe I might here propoe everal Tryals as well of our own as others, about the prodigious Expanion of ome Inflammable Bodies upon their being actually turn'd into Flame. But in this place to mention all thee, would perhaps too much intrench upon another Paper; and therefore I hall here propoe to your conideration but one intance, and that very eaie to be tryed; of which I find this account among my Adveraria.

Having oftentimes burnt Spirit of Wine, and alo Oyl in Glas-lamps, that for certain ues were o made, that the urface of the Liquor was till circular, 'twas obvious to oberve, how little the Liquor would
ubide by the wat that was made of it, in about half a quarter of an hour. And yet if we conider, that the naked Eye after ome Exercie, may, as I have often tryed, dicern the motions of a Pendulum that wings fat enough to divide a ingle minute of an hour into 240 parts, and conequently half a quarter of an hour into 1800 parts; if we alo conider into how many parts of the time imployed by a Pendulum, the Vibrations, low enough to be dicernible by the Eye, may be mentally ubdivided; and if we further conider, that without intermiion, the Oyl is preyed upon by an actual Flame, and the particles of it do continually furnih a coniderable tream of hining matter, that with a trange celerity is always flying away; we may very well conceive, that thoe parts of Flame into which the Oyl is turned, are tupendiouly minute, ince, though the wating of the Oyl is in its progres too low to be perceived by the Eye, yet 'tis
undoubted that there is a continual decrement of the depth of the Oyl, the Phyical urfaces whereof are continually and ucceively attenuated and turn'd into flame; and the trange ubtilty of the Corpucles of flame would be much the tronglier argued, if we hould uppoe, that intead of common Oyl the flame were nourih'd by a fewel o much more compact and durable, as is that inflammable ubtance made of a Metalline Body, of whoe latingnes I have elewhere made particular mention,In ome Papers about Flame. after having taught the way of preparing it.

Having in a pair of tender Scales carefully weigh'd out half a Grain of good Gunpowder, we laid it on a piece of Tile, and whelm'd over it a veel of glas (elewhere decrib'd, and often mention'd) with a Bras-plate to cover the upper orifice of it. Then having fir'd the Gunpowder, we oberv'd that the moak of it did opacate, and as to ene o fill the
whole cavity of the Glas, though its Bais were eight inches, its perpendicular height above twenty inches, and its figure far more capacious than if it were conical, and this moak, not containing it elf within the veel, iued out at two or three little intervals, that were purpoely left between the orifice of the veel and the plate that lay upon it. This cover we then remov'd, that we might oberve how long the moak would continue to acend; which we found it would do for about half a quarter of an hour, and during near half that time, (viz. the three firt minutes) the continually acending moak eem'd to be, at its going out, of the ame Diameter with the orifice at which it iu'd; and it would acend ometimes a foot, ometimes half a yard, ometimes two foot or more into the Air, before it would dipere and vanih into it.

Now if we conider, that the cavity of this round Orifice was two inches in Diameter, how many myriads
of viible Corpucles may we eaily conceive throng'd out at o large an out-let in the time abovemention'd, ince they were continually thruting one another forwards? And into o many viible Particles of moak mut we admit, that the half Grain of Powder was hatter'd, beide thoe multitudes, which, having been turn'd into actual flame, may probably be uppos'd to have uffer'd a comminution, that made them become inviible. And though I hall not attempt o hopeles a work, as to compute the number of thee mall Particles, yet to make an etimate whereby it would appear to be exceeding great, I thought fit to conider, how great the Proportion was between the paces, that to the Eye appear'd all full of moak, and the dimenions of the Powder that was reolv'd into that moak. Cauing then the Glas to be fill'd with common Water, we found it to contain above two and twenty Pints of that liquor, and cauing one of thoe
meaures to be weigh'd, it was found to weigh o near a pound (of ixteen ounces,) that the computation of the whole Water amounted to at leat 160000 grains, and conequently 320000 half grains. To which if we add, that this Gunpowder would readily ink to the bottom of Water, as being (by reaon of the Saltpeter and Brimtone, that make up at leat ix parts of even of it) in pecie heavier than it, and in likelyhood twice as heavy, (for 'tis not eaie to determine it exactly,) we may probably gues the pace to which the moak reach'd to exceed 500000 times that, which contain'd the unfir'd Powder; and this, though the moak, being confin'd in the veel, was thereby kept from diffuing it elf o far as by its treaming out it eem'd likely that it would have done.

To thee Intances from Inanimate Bodies I hall ubjoyn one more taken from Animals. Whereas then men have with Reaon wonder'd, that o mall a Body as a Cheee-mite,
which by the naked Eye is oftentimes not to be taken notice of, unles it move, (if even then it be o,) hould by the Microcope appear to be an Animal furnih'd with all neceary parts; whereas this, I ay, has given jut occaion to conclude, that the Corpucles that make up the parts of o mall an Animal, mut themelves be extremely mall; I think the Argument may be much improved by the following Conideration. Thoe that have had the Curioity to open from time to time Eggs that are at upon by a hatching Hen cannot but have oberved, how mall a proportion in reference to the bulk of the whole Egg the Chick bears; when that, which the Excellent Harvey calls Punctum aliens, dicloes the motion of the Heart, and the colour of the Blood; and that even about the eventh or eighth day the whole Chick now viibly form'd, bears no great proportion to the whole Egg, which is to upply it with Aliment, not only for its nourihment,
but peedy growth for many days after.

To apply this now to the matter in hand, having everal times oberved and hewn to others, that Cheee-mites themelves are generated of Eggs, if we conceive, that in thee Eggs, as in ordinary one, the Animal at its firt formation bears but a mall proportion to the bulk of the whole Egg, the remaining part being to uffice for the food and growth of the Embryo probably for a pretty while; ince, if an Ingenious peron, that I deired to watch them, did not mis-inform me, they ued to be about ten or twelve days in hatching; this whole Egg it elf will be allowed to be but little in reference to the Mite it came from, how extremely and unimaginably minute may we uppoe thoe parts to be, that make up the Alimental Liquors, and even the Spirits, that paing through the Nerves or Analogous parts, erve to move the Limbs and Senories of but, as it were,
the Model of uch an Animal, as, when it rets, would not (perhaps) it elf to the naked Eye be o much as viible; and in which we may preume the nobler ort of tabler parts to be of an amazing lendernes, if we conider, that, though in other hairy Animals, the Optick or ome other of the larger Nerves do, I know not how many times, in thicknes and circuit urpas a hair of the ame Animal; yet in a Cheee-Mite, though none of the larget of thoe Creatures, we have divers times manifetly een, as is before intimated, ingle Hairs that grow upon the Legs.

Another way there is, that I imployed to give men caue to think, that the inviible Effluvia of Bodies that wander through the Air may be trangely minute; and this was, by hewing how mall a fragment of matter may be reolved into particles minute enough to aociate themelves in uch numbers with a Fluid o much more dene than Air, as
Water is, as to impart a determinate Colour to the whole liquor. What I did with Cocheneel in proecution of this deign, my Experiments about Colours may inform you; but I hall now relate the ucces of an attempt made another way, for which perhaps ome of your friends the Chymits will thank me; though I was not olicitous to carry on the Experiment very far with Gold, not becaue I judged that les diviible into a number of colour'd particles, but becaue I found, as I expected, that the palenes of the native colour of the Gold may make it in the end les conpicuous, though, if I had then had by me a Mentruum, as I ometimes had, that would diolve Gold blood-red, perhaps the experiment with Gold would have urpas'd that, which 'tis now time I hould begin to relate, as oon as I have hinted to you by the way, that, for varieties ake, I made a tryal with Copper calcin'd per e, that I might not be accued of having omitted to
employ a Metal whoe Body Chymits uppoe to be much opened by Calcination. And though the event were notable even in Comparion of that of the experiment made with Cocheneel, yet my conjectures inclin'd me much to preferr the way decrib'd in the following Account.

We carefully weigh'd out in a pair of tender Scales one grain of Copper not-calcin'd, but barely fil'd; and becaue, as we made choice of this Metal for its yielding in mot Menstruums a Blew, which is a deep and conpicuous colour; we alo choe to make a olution, not in Aqua fortis or Aqua regis, but the Spirit of Sal Armoniack (as that is an urinous Spirit,) having found by former tryals, that this Mentruum would give a far deeper olution than either of the others. This lovely Liquor, of which we us'd a good proportion, that all the Copper might be throughly diolved, we put into a tall cylindrical Glas of about four inches in Diameter, and by degrees pour'd to it of ditill'd
Water, which is more proper in this cae than common Water, which has oftentimes an inconvenient Saltihnes, 'till we had almot fill'd the Glas, and aw the colour grow omewhat pale, without being too dilute to be manifet; and then we warily pour'd this liquor into a conical Glas, that it might be the more eaie to fill the veel everal times to the ame height. This conical Glas we filled to a certain mark four times conecutively, weighing it, and the liquor too, as often in a pair of excellent Scales purpoely made for Statical experiments, and which, though trong enough to weigh ome pounds in each Scale, would, when not too much loaden, turn with about one grain. Thee everal weights of the Glas, together with the contained liquor, we added together, and then carefully weighing the empty Glas again, we deducted four times its weight from the above-mentioned umm, and thereby found the weight of the liquor alone, to be that, which
reduc'd to grains amounted to 28534; o that a grain of Copper, which is not full half o heavy in pecie as fine Gold, communicated a Tincture to 28534 times its weight.

But now if you pleae to take notice, that the cope of my Experiment was to hew, into what a number of parts one grain of Copper might be divided, you will allow me to conider, as I did, that this multitude of parts mut be etimated by the Proportion, not o much in weight as in bulk, of the tinging Metal to the tinged Liquor, and conequently, ince that divers Hydrotatical tryals have inform'd me, that the weight of Copper to the weight of Water of the ame bulk is proximè as 9 to 1, a grain-weight of Copper is in bignes but the ninth part of as much Water as weighs a grain; and o the formerly mention'd number of the grains of Water mut be multiplied by 9, to give us the Proportion between the tinging and tinged Bodies, that is, that a ingle grain of
Copper gave a blewnes to above 256806 parts of limpid Water, each of them as big as it. Which, though it may eem tupendious, and carce credible; yet I thought fit to proecute the Experiment omewhat farther, by pouring all the liquor out of the tall cylindrical Glas into another clean veel, whence filling the conical Glas twice, and emptying it as often into the ame cylindrical Glas, the third time I fill'd the conical Glas with colourles ditill'd Water, and pouring that alo into the cylindrical Glas, we found the mixt liquor to have yet a manifet, though but a pale, blewnes. And, latly, throwing away what was in the cylindrical Glas, we poured into it, out of the ame conical Glas, equal parts of ditill'd colourles Water, and of the tincted Liquor we had formerly et apart in the clean Veel, and found, that, though the colour were very faint and dilute, yet an attentive Eye could eaily dicern it to be blewih; and o it was judg'd
by an intelligent Stranger that was brought in to look upon it, and was deir'd to dicover of what colour he thought it to be. Whereby it appears, that one grain of Copper was able to impart a colour to above double the quantity of Water above mentioned.

This Experiment I have allow'd my elf to be the longer and more particular in relating, both becaue I know not, that any uch has been hitherto either made or attempted, and becaue it will probably gratifie your Chymits, that love to have the Tinctures of Metals believ'd very diffuive; and becaue, if Circumtances were not added, it would eem to you as well incredible, as perhaps it does eem tupendious, that a portion of matter hould be able to impart a conpicuous colour to above 256806 times its bulk of Water, and a manifet tincture to above 385200, (for o it did, when the proportion of the ting'd part to the whole mixture, made of it and the unting'd
part, was as 2 to 31,) and a faint, but yet dicernible and ditinguihable colour to above five hundred and thirteen thouand ix hundred and twenty times its bulk of Water.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: IT were eaie for me (Pyroph.) to give you everal Intances, to hew, that the Effluvia of Liquors may get in at the Pores of Bodies that are reputed of a cloe Texture, but I hall at preent forbear to mention uch Examples, not only becaue they belong to another placeA Dicoure of Pores of Bodies, and Figures of Corpucles., where I take notice of them, but becaue many uch would not eem o remarkable, nor be o coniderable to our preent purpoe, as a few taken from Bodies that are not Fluid.

And firt, it is deliver'd by Writers
of good credit, that everal Perons, (for the Experiment does not hold in all) by barely holding for ome time dryed Cantharides in their hands, have been put to much pain at the neck of the Bladder, and have had ome other parts minitring to the ecretion of Urine enibly injured. That this is true, I am induced to believe, by what I have elewhere related to you of the unwelcome experiment I had of the effect of Cantharides applied but outwardly to my neck, and that unknown to me, upon the Urinary Paages; and that thee Operations are due to material Effluxes, which, to get into the Mas of Blood, mut pas through the pores of the skin, you will not, I preume, put me to prove.

Scaliger Exercit. 186. relates, that in Gacony, his Countrey, there are Spiders of that virulency, that, if a man treads upon them to cruh them, their poyon will pas through the very oles of his Shooes. Which tory, notwithtanding the Reputation
of the Author, I hould perhaps have left unmention'd, becaue of a much tranger about Spiders, which he relates in the ame Section, but that I met with one that is analogous in the diligent Pio's late Hitory of Braile; where, having poken of another venemous Fih of that Country, and the Antidotes he had uccesfully ued to cure the hurts it inflicts, he proceeds to that Fih the Natives call Amoreatim, of one kind whereof, call'd by the Portugals Peize Sola, his words are thee; Quae mira anè efficacia non olum manum vel leviimo attactu, ed & pedem, licet optimè calceatum, Picatoris incautè piciculum conterentis, Paralyi & Stupore afficit, intar Torpedinis Europaeae, ed minus durabili. Lib. 5. cap. 14.

What I hall ere long have occaion to tell you of the power of the Torpedo, and ome other Animals, to affect the Hand and Arm of him that trikes them, eems applicable to the matter under conideration: For, though their affecting the triker at
a ditance, may very well be acrib'd to the tupefactive or other venemous Exhalations that expire (and perhaps are as it were darted) from the Animal irritated by the troke, and are breath'd in together with the air they infect; yet their benumming, or otherwie affecting the Arm that truck them, rather than any other part, eems to argue, that the poyonous teams get in at the pores of the skin of the Limb, and o tupifie, or otherwie injure, the nervous and muculous parts of it.

Other Examples belonging to this Section may be referr'd hither from divers other places in thee Papers about Occult Qualities, and therefore I hall only add here that mot remarkable Proof, That ome Emanations, even of olid Bodies, may be ubtil enough to get through the pores, even of the cloet Bodies; which is afforded us by the Effluvia of the Loadtone, which are by Magnetical Writers aid to penetrate without reitance all kind of Bodies. And
though I have not tryed this in all orts, yet having tryed it in Metals themelves, I am apt to think, the general Rule admits of very few Exceptions, epecially, if that can be fully made out, which is affirm'd about the perviounes of Glas to the Effluxions of the Loadtone. For, not only Glas is generally reputed to be as cloe a Body as any is, but (which weighs more with me) I have by Tryals purpoely made, had occaion to admire the cloenes of very thin pieces of Glas. But the reaon why I jut now expres'd my elf with an If, was, becaue I was not entirely atisfied with the Proof wont to be acquiec'd in, of the perviounes of Glas; namely, that in Dials and Sea-Compaes that are cover'd with plates of Glas, the Needle may be readily moved to and fro by a Loadtone held over it. For thee Plates being commonly but faten'd on with Wax, or at bet with Cement, a Sceptick may pretend, that the magnetical Effluvia
pas not through the Glas, but through that much more pervious matter, that is imployed to ecure the Commiures, only from the acces of the Air. To put then the matter pat doubt, I caued ome Needles to be Hermetically eal'd up in Glas-pipes, which being laid upon the urface of water (whereon by reaon of the bignes of the Cavities they would lightly float,) the included Needles did not only readily feel the virtue of an externally applied Loadtone, (though but a weak one) but complied with it o well, that I could eaily, by the help of the Needle, lead, without touching it, the whole Pipe, this was hut up in, to what part of the urface of the water I pleaed. And I alo found, that by applying a better Loadtone to the upper part of a ealed Pipe, and a Needle in it, I could make the Needle leap up from the lower part as near to the Loadtone as the interpoed Glas would give it leave.

But I thought it would be more coniderable, to manifet that the
Magnetical Effluvia, even of uch a dull Body, as the Globe of the Earth, would alo penetrate Glas. And though this eem difficult to be tryed, becaue no ordinary Loadtone, nor any Iron touch'd by it, was to be imployed to work on the included Iron; yet I thought fit to attempt it after this manner: I took a cylindrical piece of Iron of about the bignes of ones little finger, and between half a foot and foot long, (for I had formerly oberved, that the quantity of unexcited Iron furthers its Operation upon excited Needles,) and having Hermetically eal'd it up in a Glas-pipe but very little longer than it; I uppoed, that if I held it in a perpendicular poture; the Magnetical Effluvia of the Earth, penetrating the Glas, would make the lower extreme of the Iron anwerable to the North Pole; and therefore having applied this to the point of the Needle in a Dial, or Sea-Compas, that look'd toward the North, (for Authors mean not all the ame thing by
the Northern Pole of a Needle or Loadtone,) I preum'd it would, according to the Laws Magnetical (elewhere mention'd) drive it away, which accordingly it did. And having for farther tryal inverted the included Iron, (o that the end which was formerly the lowermot, was now the uppermot) and held it in a perpendicular poture jut under the ame point of the Needle, that extreme of the Iron-rod, which before had driven away this point, being by this inverion become (in a manner) a South-Pole, did (according to the ame Laws) attract it: By which udden change of Poles, meerly upon the change of ituation, it alo appear'd, that the Iron ow'd its Virtue only to the Magnetim of the Earth, not that of another Loadtone, which would not have been thus eaily alterable. And this Experiment I the more particularly relate, becaue this is not the only place, where I have occaion to make ue of it.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: ANother proof of the great Subtilty of Effluviums, may be taken from the mall Decrement of weight or bulk that a Body may uffer by parting with great tore of uch Emanations.

That Bodies, which infus'd in Liquors impregnate them with new Qualities uitable to thoe of the immers'd Bodies, do o by imparting to them omewhat of their own Subtance, will, I preume, be readily granted by thoe that conceive not, how one Body hould communicate to another a olitary and naked Quality, unaccompanied by any thing Corporeal to upport and convey it. But I would not have you think, Pyrophilus, that the only matter of fact I have to countenance this notion, is that Experiment, which has convinc'd divers Chymits and Phyicians, otherwie
not friends to the Corpucular Philoophy, that Medicines may operate without any conumption of themelves. For, though divers of thee, ome of them Learned men, have confidently written, that Glas of Antimony and Crocus Metallorum, being either of them infus'd in a great proportion of Wine, will make it vomitive; and if that liquor be poured off, and new be poured on, every new portion of uch liquor will be impregnated with the ame virtue, and this though the liquor be chang'd a thouand times, and yet the Antimonial Glas or Crocus will continue the ame as well in weight as virtue; and though thence ome of them, epecially Chymits, argue, that ome Metals without imparting any thing ubtantial, but only, as Helmont peaks of ome of his Arcana, by irradiation: Yet, I confes, I have ome doubts, whether the Experiment have been competently tryed, and hall not fully acquiece in what has been aid, till ome skilful Experimenter deliver it upon his
own Tryal, and acquaint us too, with what Intruments and what Circumpection he made it. For, beides that the Ingeniouet Phyicians I have quetion'd about it, acknowledg'd the Tat, and ometimes the Colour of the Wine to be alter'd by the infus'd Mineral, I could not acquiece in the affirmation of an ordinary Chymit or Apothecary, or even Phyician, if he hould barely averr, that he had weigh'd an Antimonial Medicine before 'twas put to infue, and after the infuion ended, and oberv'd no decrement of weight. For I have had too much experience (as I elewhere mention) of the difficulty of making exact Statical tryals; not to know, that uch Scales, as are wont to be imployed by Chymits and Apothecaries in weighing Drugs, are by no means fit to make tryals with the nicety which that I am peaking of requires: It being eaie, even with the better ort of uch unaccurate Scales, epecially if they be not upended from ome fixt thing,
but held with the hand, to mitake half a grain or a grain; and perhaps a greater quantity, and at leat more than by divers of the Experiments of this Eay appears neceary to be pent upon the impregnating of a coniderable proportion of Liquor with Corporeal Effluxions. Beides, that if, when the beaten Crocus or Glas be taken out of the Wine to be weigh'd again, the Experimenter be not cautious enough to make allowance for the Liquor that will adhere to the Medicament, 'tis plain that he may take notice of no decrement of weight, though there may be really Effluviums of the Mineral amounting to everal grains, imbib'd by the Liquor. And though he be aware of this, and dry the powder, yet 'tis not o eaie, even for a skilful man, to be ure that none of the more vicous particles of the Liquor tick to the Mineral, and being enible upon the Ballance, though not to the Eye or Hand, repair the reces of thoe emetick Corpucles that diffus'd
themelves into the Mentruum. And the ene of thee difficulties put me upon the attempting to make o noble an Experiment with excellent Scales, and the care that it deerves: But after a long tryal, an unlucky accident frutrated at lat my endeavours. But though, till competent Relators give us an account of this matter upon their own tryal, and repeat the Infuion very much oftener, than, for ought I find, any man has yet done, I mut not acquiece in all that is aid of the Impregnation of Wine or other Liquors by Antimonial Glas and Crocus Metallorum; yet that after divers repeated Infuions the Mineral ubtance hould not be enibly diminih'd in bulk or virtue, may well uffice to make this Intance, though not the only or chief that may be brought for our purpoe, yet a pertinent one to it. For that there is a powerful Emetick Quality imparted to the Liquor, is manifet by experience; and that the Mineral does not impart this virtue
as 'twere by irradiation, but by ubtantial effluxion, eems to me very probable; not only becaue I conceive not, how this can be done otherwie, but becaue, as 'tis noted above, the Wine does oftentimes change colour by being kept a competent time upon the Mineral, as if it drew thence a Tincture; and even when it is not dicolour'd, I think it unafe to conclude, that the Mentruum has not wrought upon it. For I have kept good Spirit of Vinegar for a coniderable time upon finely powder'd Glas of Antimony made per e, without finding the Spirit to be at all ting'd, though 'tis known, that Antimonial Glas is oluble in Spirit of Vinegar, as mine afterwards appear'd to be, by a longer digetion in the ame Liquor. But there may be a great number of minute particles diolved in the Mentruum before they be numerous enough to change the Colour of it. And with this agrees very well what is oberv'd, That though too great a quantity of the
prepar'd Antimony be put into the liquor, yet it will not be thereby made too trongly Emetick. For the Wine, being a Mentruum, will, like other Mentruums, be impregnated but to a certain meaure, without diolving the overplus of the matter that is put into it. And Mars, which is a harder and heavier body than Glas of Antimony, is it elf in part oluble in good Rhenih or other white Wine, (and that in no long time,) and ometimes even in Water.

I do not therefore reject the Emetick Infuion, as unfit to have a place in this Chapter, but till the experiment have been a little more accurately made, I think it inferiour, as to our purpoe, to ome of the Intances to be met with in the next Chapter, and perhaps alo to that mention'd by Helmont, and tryed by more than one of my Acquaintance, concerning the Virtue of killing Worms, that Mercury imparts to the water or wine wherein it has been long enough infus'd, or ele for
a while decocted. Though Quickilver given in ubtance is commended as an effectual Medicine againt Worms, not only by many profet As Quercetanus, Libavius, Zabata, Burggravius. Spagyrits, but by divers
As Vidius, Paraeus, Caealpinus, &c. Methodits of good Note. And though, ome other things, Chymical and Philoophical, keep me from being of their opinion, who think that in this cae the Mercury impregnates the liquor as it were by Irradiation, rather than in a Corporeal manner, yet the Eye does not perceive, that even limpid water takes any thing from clean and well purg'd Mercury, which we know that divers corroive liquors themelves will not work upon.

To this Intance I mut add one that is yet freer from exceptions, which is, that having for Curioity ake upended in a pair of exact Scales, that would turn with a very mall part of a grain, a piece of Amber-greece bigger than a Walnut,
and weighing betwixt an hundred and ix-core grains, I could not in three days and a half that I had opportunity to make the tryal, dicover, even upon that Ballance, any decrement of weight in the Amber-greece; though o rich a perfume, lying in the open Air, was like in that time to have parted with good tore of odoriferous Steams. And a while after upending a Lump of Aa foetida five days and a half, I found it not to have utain'd any dicernible los of weight, though, in pite of the unfavourable cold weather, it had about it a neighbouring Atmophere replenih'd with foetid exhalations. And when twelve or fourteen hours after, perhaps upon ome change of weather, I came to look upon it, though I found that in that time the Aequilibrium was omewhat alter'd, yet the whole Lump had not lot half a quarter of a grain; which induc'd me to think, that there may perhaps be Steams dicernible even by our Notrils, that are far more ubtil than the odorous
exhalations of Spices themelves. For, having in very good Scales upended in the Month of March an ounce of Nutmegs, it lot in about ix days five grains and a half. And an ounce of Cloves in the ame time lot even grains and five eigths.

You will perhaps wonder, why I do not preferr to the Intances I make mention of in this Chapter, that which may be afforded by the Loadtone, that is acknowledg'd continually to emit multitudes of Magnetical Steams without decrement of weight. But though I have not thought fit to pas this wholly under ilence; yet I forbear to lay o much tres on it, not only becaue my Ballances have not yet atisfied me about the Effluvia of Loadtones, (for I take them not all to be equally diffuive of their Particles;) but becaue I foreee it may be doubted, whether Loadtones, like odorous Bodies, do furnih afreh of their own, all the Corpucles that from time to time iue from them? Or, whether
they be not continually repaired, partly by the return of the Magnetical Particles to one Pole that allied out of the other; and partly by the continued paage of Magnetical matter (upplied by the Earth or other Mundane Bodies) it make the Pores or Channels of the Loadtone their contant Thorow-fares.

I doubt not but it will make it more probable, that a mall Quantity of matter being catter'd into inviible Effluvia may be exceedingly rarified and expanded, if it can be made appear, that this little portion of matter hall, for a coniderable time, emit multitudes of viible parts, and that in o cloe an order among themelves, as to eem in their Aggregate but one intire liquor, endow'd with a tream-like motion, and a ditinct uperficies, wherein no interruption is to be een, even by an Eye plac'd near it. To devie this Experiment, I was induc'd, by conidering, that hitherto all the (total) diolutions that have been made of
Pigments, have been in liquors naturally cold, and coniting probably of much les ubtile, and certainly of much les agitated parts, than that fluid aggregate of hining matter that we call Flame; whereas I argued, that if one could totally diolve a Body compos'd of parts o minute as thoe of a Metal into actual Flame, and husband its Flame o, as that it hould not immoderatly wate, I hould thereby diolve the Metal in a far more ubtil Mentruum than our common water, or Aqua fortis, or Aqua Regis, or any other known Mentruum I have yet imployed. And conequently the attenuation and expanion of the Metal in this truly Igneous Mentruum would much urpas not only what happens in ordinary Metalline olutions, but poibly alo what I have noted in the third Chapter of this Eay, about the trange diffuion of Copper diolv'd in Spirit of Urine and Water. In proecution of this deign, I o prepar'd one ingle grain of that
Metal, by a way that I elewhere teach, that it was diolv'd in about a poonful of an appropriated Menstruum. And then having caus'd a mall Glas-lamp to be purpoely blown to contain this liquor, and fitted it with a ocket and wieck, we lighted the Lamp, which, without conuming the wieck, burnt with a flame large enough and very hot, and eem'd to be all the while of a greenih blew, as if it were a but finer and hining olution of Copper. And yet this one grain of prepar'd Metal ting'd the flame that was from moment to moment produc'd, during no les than half an hour and ix minutes. And now if we conider, that in this flame there was an uninterrupted Succeion of multitudes of colour'd Particles newly extricated, and flying off in every of thoe many parts wherein a minute of time may either actually or mentally be divided; and, if we conider Flame as a light and very agitated body, paing with a tream upwards through the Air,
and if we alo conider the quantity of liquor that would (as I hall by and by tell you) run through a Pipe of a much leer diameter than that Flame, within the compas of the forementioned time: What a quantity of the treaming fluid we call Flame, if it could have been preerv'd and collected into one Body, may we uppoe would appear to have iued out of one grain of Copper in the pace of thirty-ix minutes; and what a multitude of metalline Corpucles may we uppoe to have been upplied for the tinging of that Flame during o long a time? ince a Cylindrical tream of water falling but through a very hort Pipe of glas, contantly upplied with liquors, did pas at uch a rate, that, though the aqueous Cylinder eem'd more lender by half, (or perhaps by two thirds or better) than the Flame, yet we etimated, by the help of a Minute-watch and a good pair of Scales, that, if I had had conveniencies to let it run long enough, the water efflux'd in thirty-ix
minutes (the time of the Flames duration) would have amounted to above nine gallons, or, (reckoning a pint of water to contain a pound of ixteen ounces) eventy-two pounds.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p: THE lat ort of Intances I hall propoe to hew the trange Subtilty of Effluvia, is of uch, as dicover the great quantity of pace that may by a mall quantity of matter, when rarified or dipers'd, be either fill'd as to ene, or, at leat, made (as they peak) the phear of its activity.

To manifet this Truth, and thereby as well confirm the foregoing Chapter, as make out what is deign'd in this, I hall endeavour to hew, and help your imagination to conceive, how great a pace may be impregnated with the Effluxions of a Body, oftentimes without any enible, and oftener without any coniderable decrement
in bulk or weight of the Body that affords them. And in order to this, though I hall not pretend to determine preciely how little the ubtances, I am to intance in, would wate upon the Ballance, becaue you will very eaily ee they are not that way to be examin'd; yet I preume, you will as eaily grant, that the decrement of weight would be but inconiderable, ince of uch light ubtances the los even of bulk is o; which lat claue I hall now attempt to make good, by etting down ome Obervations, partly borrow'd from the writings of approv'd Phyicians, and partly that my friends and I have made about the durable Evaporation of uch mall particles of the Effluxions of Animals, as are actually not to be dicern'd by the Eye to have any of thoe things ticking to them, which are o very long in flying ucceively away.

'Tis wont to be omewhat urprizing to men of Letters, when they firt go a hawking with good Spaniels,
to oberve, with how great agacity thoe dogs will take notice of, and ditinguih by the cent, the places where Partridges, Quails, &c. have lately been. But I have much more wonder'd at the quick cent of an excellent Setting-dog, who by his way of ranging the fields, and his other motions, epecially of his Head, would not only intimate to us the kinds of game, whoe cent he chanc'd to light on, but would dicover to us where Partridges had been (though perhaps without taying in that place) everal hours before, and ait us to gues how long they had been gone before we came.

I have had trange anwers given me in Ireland, by thoe who make a gain if not an intire livelihood by killing of Wolves in that Countrey, (where they are paid o much for every head they bring in) about the agacity of that peculiar race of dogs they imploy in hunting them; but not truting much to thoe Relators, I hall add, that a very ober and
dicreet Gentleman of my acquaintance, who has often occaion to imploy Blood-hounds, aures me, that if a man have but pas'd over a field, the cent will lye (as they peak) o as to be perceptible enough to a good dog of that ort for everal hours after. And an ingenious Hunter aures me, that he has oberv'd, that the cent of a flying and heated Deer will ometimes continue upon the ground from one day to the next following.

And now we may conider thee three things; Firt, That the ubtance left upon the gras or ground by the tranient tread of a Partridge, Hare, or other animal, that does but pas along his way, does probably communicate to the gras or ground but ome of thoe Effluxions, that tranpire out of his feet, which being mall enough to ecape the dicernment of the Eye, may probably not amount to one grain in weight, or perhaps not to the tenth part of it. Next, That the parts of fluid Bodies,
as uch, are perpetually in motion, and o are the inviible particles that wim in them, as may appear by the diolution of Salt or Sugar in water, and the wandering of aqueous Vapours through the Air, even when the Eye perceives them not. And thirdly, That though the Atmophere of one of thee mall parcels of the exhaling matter we are peaking of, may oftentimes be exceeding vat in comparion of the emittent Body, as may be gues'd by the ditance, at which ome Setters, or Blood-hounds, will find the cent of a Partridge, or Deer; yet in places expos'd to the free air or wind, 'tis very likely that thee teams are aiduouly carried away from their Fountain, to maintain the fore-mention'd Atmophere for ix, eight, or more hours, that is, as long as the cent has been oberv'd to lye, there will be requiite a continual recruit of teams ucceeding one another And that o very mall a portion of matter as that which we were aying
the fomes of thee teams may be judg'd to be, being enibly to impregnate an Atmophere incomparably greater than it elf, and upply it with almot continual recruits, we cannot but think, that the teams it parts with, mut be of an extreme and carce conceivable minutenes.

And we may further conider, that the ubtances, which emit thee teams, being uch as newly belong'd to Animals, and were, for the mot part, tranpir'd through the pores of their feet, mut be in likelihood a far more evaporable and diipable kind of Bodies than Minerals or adut Vegetables, uch as Gunpowder is made of; o that if the grains of Gunpowder emit Effluviums capable of being by ome Animals perceiv'd at a ditance by their mell, one may probably uppoe, that the mall grains of this powder may hold out very many times longer to upply an Atmophere with odorable teams, than the Corpucles left on
the ground by tranient Animals.

Now though it be generally agree'd on, that very few Birds have any thing near o quick a ene of melling as Setting-dogs or Blood-hounds, yet that the odour of Gunpowder, epecially when aited by the teams of the Caput mortuum of Powder formerly fir'd in the ame Gun, may be Fowls be melt at a notable ditance, particularly when the wind blew from me towards them, I often perwaded my elf I oberv'd, epecially as to Crows, when I went a hooting; and was confirm'd in that opinion, both by the common Tradition, and by ober and ingenious perons much exercis'd in the killing of Wild-fowl, and of ome fourfooted Beats.

I had forgotten to take notice of one Obervation of the experienc'd Julius Palmarius: Whence we may learn, that Beats may leave upon the Vegetables, that have touch'd their bodies for any time, uch Corpucles, as, though unheeded by
other Animals, may, when eaten by them, produce in them uch dieaes as the infected Animals had. For this Author writes in his ueful Tract de morbis Contagiois, that he oberv'd Hores, Beeves, Sheep and other Animals, to run mad upon the eating of ome of the traw on which ome mad Swine had layn.

And now to reume and proecute our former dicoure, you may take notice, that the Effluvia, mention'd to have been melt by Animals, are, though inviible, yet big enough to be the objects of ene; o that 'tis not improbable, that, among the teams that no ene can immediately perceive, there hould be ome far more ubtil than thee, and conequently capable of furnihing an Atmophere much longer, without quite exhauting the effluviating matter that afforded them.
Lib. 6. Oberv. 22. Foretus, an ueful Author, recites an Example of Petilential contagion long preerv'd in a Cobweb.

Alexander Benedictus writes alo, that at Venice a Flock-bed did for many years harbour a petiferous malignity to that degree, that when afterwards it came to be beaten, it preently infected the by-tanders with the Plague.

And the LearnedLib. 4. de Eeb. cap. 3. Sennertus himelf relates, that in the year 1542. there did in the City of Uratilavia (vulgarly Brelaw,) where he afterwards practied Phyick, dye of the Plague, in les than ix Months, little les than ix thouand men, and that from that time the Petilential Contagion was kept folded up in a linnen cloth about fourteen years, and at the end of that time being diplay'd in another City, it began a Plague there, which infected alo the neighbouring Towns and other places.

Libr. 3. Con. 17. Trincavella makes mention of a yet latinger Contagion, (which occaion'd the death of ten thouand
perons) that lay lurking in certain Ropes, with which at Justinopolis thoe that dy'd of the Plague had been let down into their Graves.

But, though none of thee Relations hould to ome Criticks appear carce credible, it may be objected, that all thee things, wherein this Contagion reided, were kept cloe hut up, or at leat were not expos'd to the Air. Wherefore having only intimated, that the exception, which I think is not irrational, would, though never o true, but leen the wonder of thee trange Relations, without rendering them unfit for our preent purpoe, I hall add, that though 'tis the opinion of divers Learned Phyicians, that the matter harboring Contagion cannot lat above Twenty or a few more days, if the Body it adheres to be expos'd to the free air and the wind, and though I am not forward to deny, that their judgement may hold in ordinary caes; yet I mut not deny neither, that a Contagion may ometimes
happen to be much more tenacious and obtinate: Of which I hall give but that one, almot recent intance oberv'd by the LearnedLib. 4. de Pete. Dimmerbrook in his own Apothecary, who having but remov'd with his foot, from one ide to the other of a little Arbour (in his Garden) ome traw, that had layn under the Pallet, on which near eight Months before a Bed had layn, wherein a Servant of the Apothecaries, that recover'd, had been ick of the Plague; the infectious teams preently invaded the lower part of his leg, and produc'd a pungent pain and bliter, which turn'd to a petilential Carbuncle, that could carce be cur'd in a Fortnight after, though during that time the Patient were neither feaverih, nor, as to the ret of his Body, ill at eae. This memorable intance, together with ome others of the like kind, that our Author oberved in the ame City (of Nimmegen) obtain'd, not to ay,
extorted, even from him, this Confeion; which I add, becaue it contains ome coniderable, and not yet mentioned Circumtances of the recited cae: Hoc exemplo Medicorum Doctrina de Contagio in fomite latente atis confirmatur. Mirum tamen est, hoc Contagium tanto tempore in praedicto stramine potuie ubitere, utpote quod tota hyeme ventis & pluviis, (he adds in another place) nivibus & frigori, expoitum fuiet.

And now I will hut up this Chapter with an intance, that ome will think, perhaps, no les trange than any of the ret, which is, that though they that are skilful in the perfuming of Gloves, are wont to imbue them with but an inconiderable quantity of odoriferous matter, yet I have by me a pair of Spanih Gloves, which I had by the favour of your fair and virtuous Siter (F.) that were o skilfully perfum'd, that partly by her, partly by thoe, that preented them her as a Rarity, and partly by me, who have kept them
everal Years, they have been kept about eight or nine and twenty years, if not thirty, and they are o well cented, that they may, for ought I know, continue fragrant divers years longer. Which intance, if you pleae to reflect upon, and conider, that uch Gloves cannot have been carried from one place to another, or o much as uncover'd (as they mut often have been) in the free Air, without diffuing from themelves a fragrant Atmophere, we cannot but conclude thoe odorous Steams to be unimaginably ubtile, that could for o long a time iue out in uch warms, from a little perfum'd matter lodged in the pores of a Glove, and yet leave it richly tock'd with particles of the ame nature; though, (epecially by reaon of ome removes, in which I took not the Gloves along with me,) I forgot ever ince I had them, to keep them o much as hut up in a Box.
Of the GREAT EFFICACY OF EFFLUVIUMS: BY The Honorable ROBERT BOYLE.

div.head: OF THE GREAT EFFICACY OF EFFLVIMS.
CHAP. I.
div.p:
THey that are wont in the Etimates they make of Natural Things, to trut too much to the negative informations of their Senes, without ufficiently conulting their Reaon, have commonly but a very little and light opinion of the Power and Efficacy of Effluviums; and imagine that uch minute Corpucles (if they grant that there are uch,) as are not, for the mot part of them, capable to work upon the
tenderet and quicket of Senes, the Sight, cannot have any coniderable Operation upon other Bodies. But I take this to be an error, which, as it very little becomes Philoophers, o it has done no little prejudice to Philoophy it elf, and perhaps to Phyick too. And therefore though the nature of my deign at preent did not require it, yet the importance of the ubject would invite me to hew, That this is as ill-gounded as prejudicial a Suppoition.

And indeed if we Conider the ubject attentively, we may oberve, That though it be true, that, caeteris paribus, the greatnes of Bodies doth, in mot caes, contribute to that of their Operation upon others, yet Matter or Body being in its own precie nature an unactive or moveles Subject, one part of the Mas acts upon another but upon the account of its Local Motion, whoe Operations are facilitated and otherwie diverified by the Shape, Size, Situation and Texture both of the Agent and of the
Patient. And therefore if Corpueles, though very minute, be numerous enough, and have a competent degree of motion, even thee mall Particles, epecially if fitly hap'd, when they chance to meet with a Body, which the congruity of its texture dipoes to admit them at its Pores, and receive their either friendly or hotile impreions, may perform uch things in the patient, as viible and much groer Bodies, but les conveniently hap'd and mov'd, would be utterly unable (on the ame Body) to effect.

And that you may with the les difficulty allow me to ay, that the Effluviums of Bodies, as minute as they are, may perform Coniderable things, give me leave to oberve to you, that there are at leat ix ways, by which the Effluviums of a Body may notably operate upon another; namely, 1. By the great number of emitted Corpucles. 2. By their penetrating and pervading nature. 3. By their celerity, and other Modifications of their Motion. 4. By the congruity and incongruity
of their Bulk and Shape to the Pores of the Bodies they are to act upon. 5. By the motions of one part upon another, that they excite or occaion in the Body they work upon according to its Structure. And 6ly, By the Fitnes and Power they have to make themelves be asited, in their Working, by the more Catholick Agents of the Univere. And though it may perhaps be ufficiently proved, that there are everal caes wherein a Body that emits Particles, may act notably upon another Body by this or that ingle way of thoe I have been naming; yet uually the great matters are performed by the aociation of two, three or more of them, concurring to produce the ame Effect. Upon which core when I hall in the following Paper referr an Intance or a Phenomenon to any one of the forementioned Heads, I deire to be undertood as looking upon that but as the Head, to which it chiefly relates, without excluding the ret.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: TAking thoe things for granted, that have, I hope, been ufficiently proved in the former Tract about the ubtlety of Effluviums, I uppoe it will readily be allowed, That the Emanations of a Body may be extremely minute; whence it may be rightly inferr'd, that a mall portion of matter may emit great multitudes of them.

Now that the great number of Agents may in many caes compenate their littlenes, epecially where they Act or Reit per modum unius, (as they peak,) men would perhaps the more eaily grant, if they took notice to this purpoe of ome familiar Intances.

We ee that not only leer Landfloods that overflow the neighbouring Fields, but thoe terrible Inundations that ometimes drown whole Countreys, are made by Bodies ingly o o mall and inconiderable as Drops
of Rain when they continue to fall in thoe multitudes we call Showers.

So the aggregates of uch minute Bodies as grains of Sand being heaped together in ufficient Numbers, make Banks wherewith greatet Ships are ometimes plit, nay and erve in mot places for Bounds to the Sea it elf.

And though a ingle Corn of Gunpowder, or two or three together, are not of Force to do much michief, yet two or three Barrels of thoe Corns taking Fire all together are able to blow up Ships and Houes, and perform prodigious things.

But intead of multiplying uch Intances, afforded by Bodies of mall indeed but yet viible Bulk, I hall (as oon as I have intimated, that the above-mentioned drops of Rain themelves conit of convening Multitudes of Vapors mot commonly Inviible in their Acent,) endeavour to make out what was propoed, by two or three Intances drawn from the Operations of Inviible particles.

And firt, we ee, that though
Aqueous Vapours be look'd upon as the faintet and leat active Effluviums that we know of, yet when multitudes of them are in Rainy weather dipered thorow the Air, and are thereby qualified to work on the Bodies expoed to it, their Operations are very coniderable, not only in the diolution of Salts, as Sea-Salt, Salt of Tartar, &c. and in the putrefactive changes they produce in many Bodies, but in the intumecence they caue in Oak and other olid Woods; as appears by the difficulty we often find in and before Rainy weather, to hut and open Doors, Boxes, and other Wooden pieces of work, that were before fit enough for the Cavities they had been adjuted to.

I might here urge, that though the trings of Viols and other Muical Intruments are ometimes trong enough to utain coniderable weights, yet if they be left crewed to their full tenion, (as it frequently happens) they are oftentimes by the upervening of moit weather made to break, not
without impetuoity and noie. But it may ute better with my preent aim, if I mention on this occaion, (what I elewhere more fully take notice of:) Being deirous to try what a multitude even of Aqueous Steams may do, I caued a Rope that was long, but not thick, and was in part utained by a Pully, to have a Weight of Lead o fatned to the end of it, as not to touch the ground, and after the Weight had leiure allowed it to tretch the Cord as far as it could, I oberved that in the moit weather the waterih particles, that did inviibly abound in the Air, did o much work upon and horten the Rope, as to make it lift up the hanging Weight, which was, if I mis-remember not, about an hundred Pounds.

The inviible Steams, iuing out of the Walls of a newly plater'd or whited Room, are not enibly prejudicial to thoe that do but traniently viit it, or make but a very hort tay in it, though there be a Charcoal-fire in the Chimney; but we have many
intances of perons, that by lying for a night in uch Rooms, have been the next morning or ooner found dead in their Beds, being uffocated by the multitude of the noxious Vapours emitted during all that time.

And here I think it proper to oberve, That it may much ait us to take notice of the multitude of Effluvia, and make us expect great matters from them, to conider, that they are not emitted from the Body that affords them all at once, as Hail-hot out of a Gun, but iue from it as the Vaporous Winds do out of an Aeolipil well heated, or Waters out of a Springhead in continued Streams, wherein freh parts till ucceed one another; o that though as many Effluxions of a Body as can be ent out at one time were numerous enough to Act but upon its Superficial parts, yet the Emanation of the next minute may get in a little farther, and each mallet portion of time upplying freh Recruits, and perhaps urging on the Steams already entred, the Particles
may at length get into a multitude of the pores of the invaded Body, and penetrate it to the very innermot parts.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
I Come now to hew in the econd place, That the ubtile and penetrating nature of Effluviums, may in many caes cooperate with their multitude in producing notable effects; and that there are Effluviums of a very piercing nature, though we hall not now enquire upon what account they are o, we may evince by everal Examples. For not only the inviible Steams of good Aqua Fortis and Spirit of Nitre do uually in a hort time, and in the cold, o penetrate the corks wherewith the Glaes that contained them were top'd, as to reduce them into a yellow pap; but alo the emanations of Mercury have been ometimes found in
the form of coagulated, or even of running Mercury in the heads or very bones of thoe Gilders, or Venereal Patients, that have too long or too unadviedly been expoed to the fumes of it, though they never took Quickilver in its gros ubtance. Chymits too often find in their Laboratories, that the teams of Sulphur, Antimony, Arnick, and divers other Minerals, are able to make thoe tagger, or perhaps trike them down, that without a competent warines unlute the Veels wherein they had been ditilled or ublimed; of which I have known divers ad Examples. And of the Penetrancy even of animal Steams we may eaily be perwaded, if we conider, how oon in many Plagues the contagious, though inviible, Exhalations are able to reach the Heart, or infect other internal parts; though in divers of thee caes the Blood helps to convey the infection, yet till the Morbifick particles mut get into the body before they can infect the mas of Blood. And in thoe tupefactions that
are caued at a ditance by the Terpedo, the parts mainly affected eem to be the Nervous ones of the Hand and Arm, which are of the mot retired and bet fenced parts of thoe members. And there is a Spirit of Sal Armoniack, that I make to mell to, whoe inviible Steams, unexcited by heat, are of o piercing a nature, that not only they will powerfully affect the Eyes and Notrils, and Throats, and ometimes the Stomachs too (yet without proving Vomitive,) of the Patients they invade, but alo when a great cold has o clog'd the organs of melling, that neither weet nor tinking odours would at all affect them, thee piercing Steams have not only in a few minutes both made themelves a way, and which is more, o open'd the paages, that oon after the Patient has been able to mell other things alo. And by the ame penetrating Spirit, a peron of Quality was, ome time ince, retored to a power of melling, which he had lot for divers Years, (if he ever had it equally with other men.) I could
eaily ubjoyn Examples of this kind, but they belong to other places. And here I hall only add, that the teams of Water it elf aited by warmth, are capable of diolving the Texture of even hard and olid bodies, that are not upected to be Saline; as appears by the Philoophical calcination (as Chymits call it) wherein olid pieces of Harts-horn are brought to be eaily friable into pouder, by being hung over waters, whil't their teams rie in ditillation and without the help of Furnaces. The Exhalations, that uually wim every night in the air, and almot every night fall to the ground in the form of Dews (which makes them be judged Aqueous,) are in many places of the Torrid Zone of o penetrating a nature, that, as Eye-witnees have informed me, they would in a very hort time make Knives rut in their heaths, and Swords in their cabbards, nay and Watches in their caes, if they did not contantly carry them in their pockets. And I have known even in England
divers hard bodies, into which the Vapours wimming in the air have ininuated themelves, o far as to make them friable throughout. But of the penetration of Effluviums, I have given, in everal places, o many intances, that 'tis not neceary to add any here. And therefore to hew, that, as I intimated at the beginning of this Chapter, the Penetrancy and the multitude of Effluviums may much ait each other, I hall now ubjoyn; That we mut not for the mot part look upon Effluviums as warms of Corpucles, that only beat againt the outides of the Bodies they invade, but as Corpucles, which by reaon of their great and frequently recruited numbers, and by the Extreme mallnes of their Parts, ininuate themelves in multitudes into the minute pores of the bodies they invade, and often penetrate to the innermot of them; o that, though each ingle Corpucle, and its ditinct action, be inconiderable, in repect of the multitude of parts that compoe
the body to be wrought on; yet a vat multitude of thee little Agents working together upon a correpondent number of the mall parts of the body they pervade, they may well be able to have powerful effects upon the Body, that thoe parts contitute; as, in the cae mentioned in the former Chapter, the Rope would not probably have been enabled to raie o great a weight, though a vehement Wind had blown againt it, to make it loe its perpendicular traightnes, but a vat multitude of Watery Particles, getting by degrees into the pores of the Rope, might, like an innumerable company of little wedges, o widen the pores as to make the thrids or plinters of Hemp, the Rope was made up of, well, and that o forcibly, that the depending weight could not hinder the hortning of the Rope, and therefore mut of neceity be rais'd thereby. And I have more than once known olid and even heavy Mineral Bodies, burt in pieces by the moiture of the Air, though
we kept them within-doors carefully helter'd from the Rain.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p:
THat the Celerity of the motion of very minute Bodies, epecially conjoyned to their multitudes, may perform very notable things, may be argued from the wonderful effects of fired Gunpowder, Aurum fulminans, of Flames that inviibly touch the Bodies they work on, and alo Whirlwinds, and thoe treams of inviible Exhalations and other aerial Particles we call Winds. But becaue intances of this ort uit not o well with the main cope of this Tract, I hall not init on them, but ubjoyn ome others, which, though les notable in themelves, will be more congruous to my preent Deign. That the Corpucles whereof Odours conit, wim to and fro in the Air, as in a fluid Vehicle, will
by mot, I preume, be granted, and may be eaily prov'd. But I have elewhere hewn, That the motion of the Effluviums of ome ufficiently odorous Bodies, has too little Celerity to make a enible impreion on the organs of melling, unles thoe Steams be aited to beat more forcibly upon the Notrils by the Air, which hurries them along with it, when it enters the Notrils in the form of a tream, in the act of Inpiration. And I have by familiar obervation of Hunters, Fowlers, and partly of my own made manifet, that Setting-dogs, Hounds, Crows and ome other animals, will be much more affected with ents, or the odorous Effluvia of Partridges, Hares, Gunpowder, &c. when the Wind blows from the object towards the enory, than when it its the contrary way, which way oever the Notrils of the animal be obverted, o the Air be imbued with the odorous Steams: And conequently the difference eems to proceed from this, that when the Notrils are obverted
to the Wind, the Current of the Air drives the Steams forcibly upon the Senory, which otherwie it does not.
