That there is a brisknes of motion requiite, and more than ordinarily conducive to Electrical attractions, may be argued from the neceity that we uually find by rubbing Amber, Jett, and other Electrical bodies, to make them emit thoe Steams, by which 'tis highly probable their action is performed: And though I have elewhere hewn, that this precedent rubbing is not alwayes neceary to excite all Electrical bodies; yet in thoe that I made to attract without it, it would operate much more vigorouly after attrition; which I conconceive makes a reciprocal motion amongt the more table parts, and does thereby as 'twere dicharge and hoot out the attracting Corpucles; whoe real emiion, though it may be probably argued from what has been already aid, eems more trongly proveable by an Obervation that
I made many years ago, and which I have been lately inform'd to have been long ince made by the very Learned Fabri. The Obervation was this; That if, when we took a vigorouly excited Electrick, we did at a certain nick of time (which circumtances may much vary, but was uually almot as oon as the body was well rubbed) place it at a jut ditance from a upended Hair or other light body, or perhaps from ome light powder; the Hair, &c. would not be attracted to the Electrick, but driven away from it, as it eem'd, by the briskly moving teams that iue out of the Amber or other light body.
This Argument I could confirm by another Phaenomenon or two of affinity with this, if I hould not borrow too much of what I have elewhere noted about the Hitory of Electricity.

I know a certain ubtance, which though made by ditillation, does in the cold emit but a very mild and inoffenive mell, but when the veel
that holds it is heated, though no eparation of contituent Principles appear to be thereby made, (the Body being in all uual tryals homogeneous,) the Effluviums will be o altered, that I remember a Virtuoo, that, to atisfie his curioity would needs be melling to it, when 'twas heated, complain'd to me, that he thought the Steams would have killed him, and that the Effluviums of Spirit of Sal Armoniack it elf were nothing near o trong and piercing as thoe.

And even among olid Bodies, I know ome, which, though abounding much in a ubtance wherein ome rank mells principally reide, yet (if they were not chafed) were carce at all enibly odorous; but upon the rubbing of them a little one againt the other, the attrition making them, as it were, dart out their Emiions, would in a minute or two make them tink egregiouly.

And as the Celerity of motion may thus give a vigor to the Emanations of Bodies, o there may be
other modifications of motion, that may contribute to the ame thing, and are not to be wholly neglected in this place. For as we ee, that greater Bodies do operate differingly according to uch and uch modifications; as there is a great difference between the effects of a Dart or Javelin, o thrown as that its point be alwayes forwards, and the ame weapon if it be o thrown, that during its progreive motion the extremes turn about the Center of gravity or ome inward parts, as it happens when Boyes throw ticks to beat down fruit from the tops of trees; o there is little doubt to be made, but that in Corpucles themelves 'tis not all one, as to their effects, whether they move with or without rotation, and whether in uch or uch a line, and whether with or without undulation, trembling or uch a kind of conecution; and in hort, whether the motion have or have not this or that particular modification; which how much it may diverifie the Effects
of the Bodies moved, may appear by the Motion, that the Aerial particles are put into by Muical Intruments. For, though the effects of harmony, dicord and peculiar ounds be ometimes very great, not only in Human bodies, but, as we hall hew in the following Tract, in Organical ones too; the whole efficacy of Muick and of Sounds that are not extraordinarily loud and different, eems, as far as 'tis acribable to Sonorous bodies, to depend upon the different manners of motion whereinto that Air is put, that makes the immediate impreion on our organs of hearing.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
I Should now proceed to hew, how the Celerity and other modes, that diverifie the motion of Effluviums, may be aited to make them operative by their determinate izes and figures,
and the congruity or incongruity which they may have upon that core with the Pores of the groer Bodies they are to work on: But I think it not fit to entrench upon the ubject of anotherOf the Pores of Bodies, and Figures of Corpucles. Tract, where the relation between the figures of Corpucles and the Pores of groer bodies is amply enough treated of. And therefore I hall only in this place take notice of thoe effects of Lightning, which eem referable, partly to the Celerity and manner of Appule, and partly to the ditinct izes and hapes of the Corpucles that compoe the detructive matter, and to the peculiar relation between the particles of that matter and the tructure of the bodies they invade. I know that many trange things that are delivered about the Effects of what the Latins call Fulmen (which our Englih word Lightning does not adaequately render) are but fabulous; but there are but too many that are not o; ome of which I have been
an Eye-witnes of, within les than a quarter of an hour after that the things happened. And though it be very difficult to explicate particularly many of thee true Phenomena, yet it eems warrantable enough to argue from them, that there may be Agents o qualified, and o wiftly moved, that notwithtanding their being o exceedingly minute, as they mut be, to make up a flame, which is a fluid Body, they mut in an imperceptible time pervade olid Bodies, and travering ome of them without violating their Texture, burn, break, melt, and produce other very great changes in other Bodies that are fitted to be wrought on by them. And of this I mut not forget to mention this remarkable intance; That a peron Curious enough to collect many rarities, bringing me one day into the Study where he kept the choicet of them, I aw there among other things a fine pair of Drinking-glaes that were omewhat lender, but extraordinarily tall; they eem'd to have
been deigned to reemble one another, and made for ome drinking entertainment. But before I aw them, that reemblance was much leen'd by the Lightning, that fell between them in o trange a manner, that, without breaking either of them, that I could perceive, it alter'd a little the figure of one of them, near the lower part of the Cavity; but the other was o bent near the ame place as to make it tand quite awry, and give it a poture, that I beheld not without ome amazement. And I cannot yet but look upon it as a very trange thing, and no les coniderable to our preent purpoe, that Nature hould in the free Air make of Exhalations, and that uch as probably when they acended were inviible, uch an aggregate of Corpucles, as hould without breaking uch frail Bodies as Glaes, be able in its paage thorow them, that is, in the twinkling of an Eye, to melt them; which to do is wont even in our Reverberatory Furnaces to cot
that active flames a pretty deal of time.

And this calls into my memory, that upon a time, hearing not far off from me uch a clap of Thunder as made me judge and ay, that quetionles ome of the neighbouring places were thunder-trook, I ent preently to make inquiry; which having jutified my conjecture, I forthwith repaired to the houe, where the michief was done, by omething, which thoe, that pretended to have een it coming thither, affirm'd to be like a flame moved very obliquely. To omit the hurt, that eemed to have been done by a Wind that accompanied it, or was perhaps produced by it, to divers perons and cattel; that which makes me here mention it, was, that oberving narrowly what had happen'd in an upper room, where it firt fell, I aw, that it had in more than one place melted the Lead in its paage, (though that poibly outlated not the twinkling of an Eye,) without breaking to
pieces the glas-caements, or burning (that I took notice of) either the Bed or Hangings or any other combutible houhold-tuff; though near the window it had thrown down a good quantity of the olid ubtance of the Wall, through which it eem'd to have made its paage in or out. And that, which made me the les cruple to mention this accident, is, that having curiouly pry'd into the Effects of the Fulmen, not only in that little upper room, but in other parts of the Houe, beneath whoe lowermot parts it eem'd to have ended its extravagant coure, I could not but conclude, That if o be it were the ame Fulmen, it mut have more than once gone in and out of the Houe, and that the line of its motion was neither traight, nor yet reducible to any curve or mixed line, that I had met with among Mathematicians; but that, as I then told ome of my Friends, it moved to and fro in an extravagant manner, not unlike the irregular and wrigling motion of
thoe fired Squibs that Boys are wont to make by ramming Gunpowder into Quills. But about Thunder more perhaps elewhere. I hall here only add, That whereas 'tis a known Tradition, which my own Obervations heedfully made eem now and then to confirm, that vehement Thunder, if Beer be not very trong, will uually (for I do not ay alwayes) owre it in a day or two; if this degeneration be not one of the conequences of the great and peculiar kinds of the concuions of the Air that happens in lowd Thunder (in which cae the Phenomenon will belong to the next Dicoure,) the effect may probably be imputed to ome ubtile Exhalations diffued thorow the Air, which, penetrating the pores of the Wooden veels, whoe contexture is not very cloe, imbue the liquor with a kind of acetous Ferment; which conjecture I hould think much confirmed by a tryal, it uggeted to me, if I had made it often enough to rely upon it. For conidering that the
pores of Glas are traight enough to be impervious (for ought I have yet oberved) to the Steams or pirituous parts of Sulphur as well as to other odorous Exhalations, I thought it worth trying, whether there be any ulphureous Steams or other Corpucles diffued thorow the Air in time of Thunder, that would not be too gros to get in at uch minute pores as thoe of Glas. And accordingly having Hermetically ealed up both Beer and Ale apart, I kept them in Summer time till there happen'd a great Thunder, a day or two, after which the Beer which we drank, that was good before, being generally complained of as owred by the Thunder, I uffer'd my liquors to continue at leat a day or two longer, that the owring Steams, if any uch there were, might have time enough to operate upon them, and then breaking the Glaes, I found not that the liquors had been owred, though we had purpoely forborn to fill the Glaes, to facilitate the degeneration of
the liquors. Perhaps it will be pardonable on this occaion to mention a practice, which is uual in ome places where I have been, and particularly employ'd by a great Lady, that is a great houe-keeper, and is very curious and expert in divers Phyical Obervations; for, talking with her about the remedies of the Sowring of Beer and other drinks by Thunder, which is ometimes no mall prejudice to her, he affirm'd to me, that he uually found the practice, I was mentioning, ucceed: And that before the then lat great Thunder, of which I had oberved the Effects upon Beer, he preerved hers by putting, at a convenient ditance, under the Barrels, Chaffing-dihes of Coals, when he perceiv'd that the Thunder was like to begin, which practice, if it contantly ucceed, may put one a conidering, whether the Fire do not by rarifying the Air and dicuing the ulphureous or other Steams, by altering them, or by uniting with them the Exhalations
of the Coals, or by ome uch kind of way, render ineffectual thee owring Corpucles, which perhaps require a determinate bulk and hape, beides their being crowded very many of them together, to have their full Operation on Barrell'd Liquors. But thee things are but meer Conjectures, and therefore I proceed.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p: THE fifth way whereby Effluviums may perform notable things, is the Motion of one part upon another, that they may excite or occaion in the Body they work on according to its tructure.

I hall in the following Tract have occaion to ay omething of the Motions into which the Internal parts of Inanimate Bodies may put one another; but the Examples now produced are deigned to manifet the Efficacy, that Effluviums may, on the
newly mentioned accounts, have on Organical and living Bodies. To which Intances it would yet be proper to premie, That even Inanimate and Solid Bodies may be of uch a tructure as to be very much alterable by the appropriated Effluviums of other Bodies, as may be intanc'd in the power, that I have known ome vigorous Loadtones to have, of taking away in a trice the attractive virtue of an excited Needle, or giving a verticity directly contrary to the former without o much as touching it.

And we may pertinently take notice of the attractive virtue of the Loadtone, as that, which may afford us an eminent Example of the great power of a multitude of inviible Effluviums, even from Bodies that are not great, upon Bodies that are Inorganical or liveles: For taking it for granted, what both the Epicureans, Carteians, and almot all other Corpucularian Philoophers agree in, that Magnetim is performed by corporeal Emiions, we may conider,
that thee paing unreitedly thorow the pores of all olid Bodies, and even Glas it elf, which neither the ubtilet Odours nor Electrical Exhalations are oberv'd to do, eem to be almot incredibly minute, and much maller than any other Effluviums, though themelves too mall to be viible; and yet thee o incomparably little Magnetical Effluxions proceeding from vigorous Loadtones, will be able to take up coniderable quantities of o ponderous a Body as Iron; in o much that I have een a Loadtone not very great, that would keep upended a weight of Iron, that I could hardly lift up to it with one Arm; and I have een a little one, with which I could take up above eighty times its weight. And thee Effluvia do not only for a moment faten the Iron to the Stone, but keep the Metal upended as long as one pleaes.

This being premied, I come now to oberve, That the chief effects of Effluvia belonging to the fifth Head
are wrought upon Animals, which by virtue of their curious and elaborate tructure, have their parts o connected and otherwie contrived, that the motions or changes that are produced in one, may have by the conent of Parts a manifet operation upon others, although perhaps very ditant from it, and o fram'd as to declare their being affected by actions that eem to have no affinity at all with the Agents that work upon the part firt affected.

I have hewn at large in another The efulnes of Experimental Philoophy. Treatie, that a Humane Body ought not to be look'd upon meerly as an aggregate of Bones, Fleh, and other conitent parts, but as a mot curious and a living Engin, ome of whoe parts, though o nicely fram'd as to be very eaily affected by external Agents, are yet capable of having great Operations upon the other parts of the Body, they help to compoe. Wherefore without now repeating what is there already deliver'd,
I hall proceed to deliver uch Effects as are wrought on Human Bodies by thee Effluviums without any immediate contact of the Bodies that emit them.

And firt, not to mention Light, becaue its being or not being a Corporeal thing is much diputed even among the Moderns; 'tis plain, that our organs of Smelling are enibly affected by uch minute Particles of matter as the finet odours conit of. Nor do they alwayes affect us preciely as odours, ince we ee, that many perons, both men and women, are by Smells, either weet or tinking, put into troubleom Headaches.

If it were not almot ordinary, it would be more than almot incredible, that the mell of a pleaing Perfume hould preently produce in a Human Body, that immediately before was well and trong, uch faintnees, woons, los of enible repiration, intumecence of the Abdomen, eeming Epilepies, and really convulive motions of the Limbs, and
I know not how many other frightfull Symptoms, that by the unskilful are often taken for the effects of Witchcraft, and would impoe upon Phyicians themelves, if their own or their Predeceors Experience did not furnih them with Examples of the like Phaenomena produc'd by Natural means. Thoe Symptoms manifet, what the conent of Parts may do in a Humane Body; ince even Morbifick Odours, if I may o call them, by immediately affecting the organs of Smelling, affect o many other parts of the genus Nervoum, as oftentimes to produce Convulive motions, even in the extreme parts of the Hands and Feet.

Nor is the efficacy of Effluviums confined to produce Hyterical fits, ince thee inviible Particles may be able (and ometimes as uddenly as Perfumes are wont to excite them) to appeae them, as I have very frequently, though not with neverfailing ucces, tryed, by holding a Spirit, I uually make of Sal Armoniack,
under the Notrils of Hyterical perons. My remedy did not only often recover, in a trice, thoe whoe Fits were but ordinary, but did more than once, omewhat to the wonder of the By-tanders, relieve, within a Minute or two, perons of differing Ages and Contitutions, that were uddenly fallen down by Fits, that the By-tanders judg'd Epileptical, (but I, Hyterical.)

If it were not for the Sex of this peron, I could relate an Intance that would be much more coniderable of the Operation of Roes. For I know a dicreet Lady to whom their mell is not unpleaing, (for he anwer'd me that 'twas not o at all,) but o hurtful, that it preently makes her ick, and would make her woon if not eaonably prevented: And he told me that being once at a Court in which he was a Maid of Honour, though he her-elf did not know whence it came, he found her elf extremely ill on a udden, and ready to ink down for faintnes; but being then in dicoure with a peron, whoe High Quality he payd her profound repect to, her Civility, that kept her from complaining or withdrawing, might have been dangerous if not fatal to her, had not the Princes
who was peaking with her, and who knew her Antipathy to Roes, taken notice that her Face grew trangely pale, and was covered with a cold weat. For thereby preently gueing what might be the caue, which the ick Lady her elf did not, he asked aloud whether ome body had not brought Roes (which were then in eaon) into the Bed-chamber, which quetion occaioned a peedy withdrawing of a Lady, that tood at a ditance off, and had about her Roes, which were not een by the Patient, who was by this means preerved from falling into a woon, though not from being for a while very much dicompoed.

But this you may tell me was the cae of a Woman, who complain'd her malady affected her Heart, not her Head. Wherefore returning to what I was peaking of before I mention'd Her, I hall proceed to tell you, that as Odours may thus give Men the Headach, o I have often found the mell of rectified-Spirit of Sal Armoniack
to free Men as well as Women from the Fits of that ditemper; and that ometimes in o few Minutes, that the peron reliev'd could carcely imagine, they could o quickly be o.

To which I hall not add the Tryals that I have uccesfully made upon my elf, becaue being, thanks be to God, very eldom troubled with that ditemper, the occaions I have had of making them have not been many. And though I have not alwayes found o light a Remedy to work the deired Cure, yet that it does it often, even in Men, is ufficient to hew the Efficacy of Sanative Effluviums.
Now, to manifet, that Steams do not Operate only upon Hyterical Women, or perons ubject to the Head-ach, I will add ome Intances of the Effects they may produce upon other perons, and parts.

'Tis but too well known an Obervation, that Women with Child have been often made to micarry by the tink of an ill-extinguiht Candle,
though perhaps the moak acending from the Snuff were diipated into the inviible Corpucles, a good while before it arriv'd at the Notrils of the unhappy Woman; and what violent and training motions Abortions are frequently accompanied with, is ufficiently known already.

I think I have elewhere mentioned, that a Gentleman of my acquaintance, a proper and luty man, will be put into the fits of Vomiting by the mell of Coffee, boyl'd in Water; I hall therefore rather mention, that I know a Phyician, who having been, for a long time when he was young, frequently compelled to take Electuarium lenitivum, one of the gentlet and leat unpleaant Laxatives of the Shops, conceived uch a dilike of it, that till, as himelf has complained to me, if he mell to it, as he ometimes happens to do in Apothecaries Shops, it will work (now and then for everal times) upwards and downwards with him.

I know another very ingenious
perons of the ame faculty, that has been a Traveller by Sea and Land, who has complain'd to me, that the mell of the Greae of the Wheels of a Hackney-coach, though it do but pas by him, is wont to make him ick and ready to Vomit.

Every body knows, that Smoak is apt to make mens Eyes water, and excite in the organs of Repiration that troubleom and vehement commotion we call Coughing. But we need not have recoure at all to viible Fumes, for the production of the like Effects; ince we have often oberved them, and repeated Sneezings to boot, to proceed from the inviible Steams of Spirit of Sal Armoniack, when Vials containing that liquor, though they were perhaps but very mall, were approached too hatily, or perhaps too near to the Notrils.

And becaue in mot of the foregoing Intances, the chief Effects eem to be wrought, by the conent of parts, on the genus Nervoum and the action of one of them upon the
other, and thereby upon everal other parts of the Body, I will ubjoyn a remarkable intance of the Operation of a mild and grateful Odour upon the Humors themelves, and that in a Man.

A famous Apothecary, who is a very tall and big man, everal times told me, that though he was once a great lover of Roes, yet having had occaion to employ great quantities of them at a time, he was o altered by their Steams, that now, if he come among the Roe-buhes, the mell does much dicompoe him. And the odour of Roes, (I mean Incarnate-Roes, which we commonly call Damask-Roes, though they be not the true ones,) makes uch a colliquation of Humors in his Head, that it ets him a coughing, and makes him run at the Noe, and gives him a ore throat; and by an affluence of Humors makes his Eyes ore, in o much that during the eaon of Roes, when quantities of them are brought into his Houe, he is oblig'd
for the mot part to abent himelf from home.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p:
ONE may hew on this occaion, that as there might be coniderable things performed by Effluviums, as they make one part of a living Engine work upon another by virtue of its tructure, o the action of uch inviible Agents may in divers caes be much promoted by the fabrick and laws of the Univere it elf, upon this account, that, by the Operation of Effluvia upon particular Bodies, they may dipoe and qualifie thoe Bodies to be wrought upon, which before they were not fit to be, by Light, Magnetims, the Atmophere, Gravity or ome other of the more Catholick Agents of Nature, as the World is now contituted. But not to injure another Tract, I hall conclude this, when I hall have taken
notice, that in the Intances hitherto produced, there has been a viible Local ditance between the Body that emits Steams, and that on which they work. But if I thought it neceary, it were not difficult to hew, that one might woll enough referr to the title of this Tract divers Effects of Bodies that are applied immediately to ours; uch as are Blood-tones, Cornelions, Nephritick-tones, Lapis Malacenis, and ome Amulets, and other olid ubtances applied by Phyicians outwardly to our Bodies. For in thee applications the gros Body touches but the Skin, and the great Effects, which I elewhere relate my elf to have ometimes (though not often, much les alwayes) oberved to have followed upon this External contact or near application, may reaonably be derived from the ubtle Emanations, that pas thorow the Pores of the Skin to the inward parts of the Body: As is evident in thoe, who by holding Cantharides in their Hands, or having them apply'd
to ome remote External part, have grievous pains produc'd in their Urinary parts, as it has happen'd to Me as well as to many others. And to the ininuation of thee minute Corpucles, that get in at the Pores of the Skin, eems to be due the Efficacy of ome Medicines, that purge, vomit, reolve the Humors, or otherwie notably alter the Body being but externally applied; of which I could here give everal Intances, but that they belong more properly to another place, and are not neceary in this, where it may uffice to name the notorious Power, that Mercurial Oyntments or Fumes, either together or apart, have of producing Copious Salvations, to hew in general, that both the Steams and the Emanations of outwardly applied Medicinal Bodies may have ome great Effects on Human ones.
OF THE Determinate Nature OF EFFLUVIUMS.

div.head: OF THE DETERMINATE NATURE OF EFFLVIMS.
CHAP. I.
div.p:
THE Effluviums of Bodies, Pyrophilus, being for the mot part inviible, have been wont to be o little conider'd by vulgar Philoophers, that carce vouchafing to take notice of their Exitence, 'tis no wonder that men have not been olicitous to dicover their ditinct Natures and Differences. OnlyLib. 1. Meteor. cap. 3, & 4. Aritotle, and (upon his account) the Schools, have been pleaed to
think, that the two grand parts of our Globe do ometimes emit two kinds of Exhalations or Steams; the Earthy part affording thoe that are hot and dry, which they name Fumes, and very often, imply, Exhalations; and the Aqueous part, others that are (not as many of his Diciples mitake him to have taught, Cold and Moit, but) Hot and MoitCap. 3. < in non-Latin alphabet > ., which they uually call Vapours, to dicriminate them from the Fumes (or Exhalations,) though otherwie, in common acceptation, thoe Appellations are very frequently confounded.

But, though the Aritotelians have thus perfunctorily handled this Subject, it would not become Corpucularian Philoophers, who attribute o much as they do to the Inenible Particles of Matter, to acquiece in o light and jejune an account of the Emanations of Bodies. And ince we have already hewn, that beides the greater and more imple Maes
of Terretrial and Aqueous matter newly mention'd, there are very many mixt Bodies, that emit Effluviums, which make, as it were, little Atmopheres about divers of them, it will be congruous to our Doctrine and Deign, to add in this place, That beides the light and obvious differences, taken notice of by Aritotle, the Steams of Bodies may be almot as various as the Bodies themelves that emit them; and that therefore we ought not to look upon them barely under the general and confued notion of Smoak or Vapours, but may probably conceive them to have their ditinct and determinate Natures, oftentimes (though not always) uitable to that of the Bodies from whence they proceed.

And indeed the newly mentioned Diviion of the Schools gives us o light an account of the Emanations of Bodies, that, methinks, it looks like uch another, as if one hould divide Animals into thoe that are Horned, and thoe that have Two Feet:
For, beides that the Ditinction is taken from a Difference that is not the coniderablet, there are divers Animals (as many four-footed Beats and Fihes) that are not compried in it; and each member of the Diviion comprehends I know not how many ditinct orts of Animals, whoe differences from one another are many times more coniderable, than thoe that contitute the two upreme Genus's, the one having Bulls and Goats, and Rhinoceros's, and Deer, and Elks, and certain Sea-Monters whoe Horns I have een; and the other Genus compriing alo a greater Variety, namely, a great part of Four-footed Beats, and, beides Men, all the Birds (for ought we know) whether of Land or Water. And as it would give us but a very lender Information of the Nature of an Elk or an Unicorn, to know that 'tis an Horned Beat; or of the Nature of a Man, an Eagle, or a Nightingale, to be told, that 'tis an Horn-les Beat; o it will but very little intruct a man
in the Nature of the Steams of Quickilver or of Opium, to be told, that they are Vapours Hot (or rather Cold) and Moit; or of the Steams of Amber or Cantharides, or Cinnamon, or Tobacco, to be told, that they are Hot and Dry. For, beides that there may be Effluviums, which, even by their Elementary Qualities, are not of either of thee two upreme Genus's, (for they may be Cold and Dry, or Cold and Moit,) thee Qualities are often far from being the Noblet, and conequently thoe that deerve to be mot conider'd in the Effluviums of this, or that, Body; as we hall by and by have occaion to manifet.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p:
ANd here it may not be improper to mention an Experiment, that, I remember, I divers years ince
employed to illutrate the Subject of our preent Dicoure.

I conider'd then, that Fluid Bodies may be of very unequal denity and gravity, as is evident in Quickilver, Water and pure Spirit of Wine; which, notwithtanding their great difference in pecifick gravity, may yet agree in the conditions requiite to Fluid Bodies. Therefore preuming, that by what I could make appear viible in one, what happens analogically in the other, may be ocularly illutrated, I took ome Ounces of Roch-allom, and as much of fine Salt-peter. I took ome Ounces of each, becaue, if the quantity of the ingredients be too mall, the concoagulated grains will be o too, and the ucces will not be o conpicuous. Thee being diolved together in fair Water, the filtrated olution was et to evaporate in an open-mouthed Glas, and being then left to hoot in a cool place, there were fatned to the ides and other parts of the Glas everal mall Crytals, ome Octoedrical,
which is the figure proper to Rochallom, and others of the Primatical hape of pure Salt-peter; beides ome other Saline concretions, whoe being ditinctly of neither of thee two hapes, argued them to be concoagulations of both the Salts. And this we did by uing uch a degree of Celerity in Evaporating the liquor, as was proper for uch an effect. For, by another degree, which is to be employ'd when one would recover the Salts more ditinctly and manifetly, the matter may (as I found by tryal) be o ordered, that the aluminous Salt may, for the mot part, be firt coagulated by it elf, and then from the remaining liquor curiouly hap'd Crytals of Nitre may be copiouly obtained.

Tryals like this we alo made with other Salts, and particularly with Sea-Salt, and with Allom and Vitriol; the Phaenomena of which you may meet with in their due places. For the recited Experiment may, I hope, alone erve to ait the imagination
to conceive, how the Particles of Bodies may wim to and fro in a Fluid, (which the Air is,) and though they be little enough to be inviible, may many of them retain their ditinct and determinate natures, and their aptnes to cohere upon occaion; and others may, by their various occurions and coalitions, unite into leer Corpucles or greater Bodies differing from the more imple Particles, that compoed them, and yet not of indeterminate though compounded Figures.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
THee things being premis'd, we may now proceed to the particular Intances of the Determinate Nature of Effluviums; and thee we may not inconveniently reduce to the three following Heads, to each of which we hall aign a ditinct Chapter; the firt of thee I hall
briefly treat of in this third Chapter, and treat omewhat more largely of the others in the two following.

In the firt place then, That the Effluviums of many Bodies retain a determinate Nature oftentimes in an inviible mallnes, and oftener in uch a ize as makes them little enough to fly or wim in the Air; may appear by this, that thee Effluvia being by Condenation or otherwie reunited, they appear to be of the ame nature with the Body that emitted them. Thus in moit weather, the Vapours of Water, that wander inviibly through the Air, meeting with Marble-Walls or Pavements, or other Bodies, by their Coldnes and other Qualifications, fit to condene and retain them, appear again in the form of Drops of Water; and the ame Vapours return to the viible form of Water, when they fall out of the Air in Dews, or Rains.

Quickilver it elf, if it be made to acend in ditillation with a convenient degree of Fire, will almot all
be found again in the Receiver in the form of running Mercury. Which trange and piercing Fluid, is in ome caes o dipoed to be trip'd of its Diguies, and re-appear in its own form, that divers Artificers, and epecially Gilders, have found, to their cot, that the fumes of it need not be, as in Ditillation, included in cloe Veels to return to their pritine nature, Mercury having been everal times found in the Heads and other parts of uch People, who have in tract of time been killed by it, and ometimes made to dicover it elf during the Lives of thoe that dealt o much in it; of which I elewhere give ome Intances. Wherefore I hall only oberve at preent, that 'tis a common Practice, both among Gilders, and ome Chymits, that, when they have occaion to make an Amalgam, or force away the Mercury from one by the fire, they keep Gold in their Mouthes, which by the Mercurial fumes, that wander through the Air, will now and then,
by that time 'tis taken out of their Mouths, be turned white almot, as if it had been ilver'd over.

A mas of purified Brimtone being ublimed, the acending fumes will condene into what the Chymits call Flores Sulphuris, which is true Sulphur of the ame nature with that, formerly expoed to ublimation; and may readily by melting be reduced into uch another mas.

And to give you another like Example of dry Bodies; I tryed, that by ubliming good Camphire in cloe veels, it would all, as to ene, be raied into the upper veel, or part of the Subliming-glas in the form of dry Camphire as it was before.

Nay though a Body be not by Nature, but Art compounded of uch differing Bodies as a Metal and another Mineral, and two or three Salts; yet, if upon Purification of the mixture from its groer parts, the remaining and finer parts be minute enough and fitly hap'd, the whole liquor will acend, and yet in the
Receiver altogether recover its pritine form of a tranparent Fluid, compoed of differing Saline and Mineral parts. This is evident in the Ditillation of what Chymits call Butter, or Oyl of Antimony, very well rectified. For, this Liquor will pas into the Receiver diaphanous and fluid, though, beides the Particles of the Sublimate, (which is it elf a factitious compounded Body) it abounds with Antimonial Corpucles, carried over and kept inviible by the corroding Salts; whatever Angelus Sala, and thoe Chymits that follow him, have affirm'd to the contrary; as might be eaily here proved, if this were a fit place to do it in.

I found by inquiring of an Ingenious peron, that had an interet in a Tin-Mine, that I was not deceived in gueing, that Tin it elf, though a Metal whoe Ore is of a very difficult fuion, and which I have by it elf kept long upon the Cupel without finding it to fly away, would yet retain its Metalline nature in the form
of fumes or flowers. For this experienc'd Gentleman anwer'd me, that divers times they would take great tore of a whitih Sublimate from the upper part of the Furnaces or Chimnies, where they brought their Ore to fuion, or wrought further upon it; and that this Sublimate, though perhaps elevated to the height of an ordinary Man, would, when melted down, afford at once many Pounds of very good Tin. On which occaion I hall add, that I have my elf more than once raied this Metal in the form of white Corpucles by the help of an Additament, that did carce weigh half o much as it.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p:
THe econd way, by which we may dicover the Determinate Nature of Effluviums, is, by the difference that may ometimes be oberv'd in their Senible Qualities. For,
thee Effluviums that are endow'd with them, proceed from the ame ort of Bodies, and yet thoe afforded by one kind of Bodies being in many caes manifetly differing from thoe that fly off from another, this evident diparity in their Exhalations argues their retaining ditinct natures, according to thoe of the repective Bodies whence they proceed.

I will not now tay to examine, whether in the Steams, that are made viibly to acend from the Terretrial Globe by thoe grand Agents and uual raiers of them, the Sun, and the agitation of the Air, the Eye can manifetly ditinguih the diverity of colours: But in ome productions of Art uch different colours may be dicovered in the Exhalations, even without the application of any external heat to raie them. For, when Spirit of Nitre, for example, has been well rectified, I have often oberv'd, that even in the cold the fumes would play in the unfill'd part of the top'd Vials it was kept in, and appear in
it of a reddih colour, and, if thoe veels were open'd, the ame fumes would copiouly acend into the Air, in the form of a reddih or orange-tawny Smoak. Spirit or Oyl of Salt alo, if it be very well dephlegm'd, though it will carce in the cold viibly acend in the empty part of a Vial, whilt it is kept well top'd; yet, if the free Air be allow'd acces to it, it will, in cae it be ufficiently rectified, fly up in the form of a whitih fume. But this is inconiderable in comparion of what happens in a volatile Tincture of Sulphur, I have elewhere taught you to make with Quick-lime. For, not only upon a light occaion the vacant part of the Vial will be fill'd with white fumes, though the Glas be well top'd; but upon the opening the Vial thee fumes will copiouly pas out at the neck, and acend into the Air in the form of a Smoak, more white than perhaps you ever aw any. And both this and that of the Spirit of Salt-peter do by their operation, as well as mell,
dicloe what they are; the latter being of a Nitrous nature, (as is confes'd) and the former, of a Sulphureous: In o much that having for curioities ake in a fitly hap'd Glas caught a competent quantity of the acending white fumes, I found them to have conven'd into Bodies tranparent and Geometrically figur'd, wherein 'twas eaie to dicover by their enible qualities, that there were tore of Sulphureous particles mixt with the Saline ones. That the liquors of Vegetables, ditill'd in Balneo or in Water, are not wont to retain any thing of the colour of the Bodies that afforded them, is a thing eaie to be oberv'd in Ditillations made without Retorts or the violence of the Fire. But it may be worth while to make tryal, whether the Eential Oyl of Wormwood acend colour'd like the Plant, whence 'tis firt drawn over with Water in the Limbec, or rectified in Balneo. For, I forgot to take notice of it, when upon ome particularities, I oberv'd in that Plant,
my curioity led me to find, that not only in the firt ditillation in a Copper Limbec, tinn'd on the inide, the Oyl came over green, but by a rectification purpoely made in a Glas-veel, the purified liquor was not depriv'd of that colour.

The mention of thee Eential Oyls, as Chymits call thoe that are drawn in Limbecs, leads me to tell you, that, though thee liquors be but Effluvia of the Vegetables they are ditill'd from, condens'd again in the Receiver into liquors; yet, as ubtile as they are, many of them retain the genuine tate of the Bodies, whence the heat elevated them; as you will eaily find, if you will tat a few drops of the Eential Oyl of Cinamon, for example, or of Wormwood diolv'd by the intervention of Sugar or Spirit of Wine in a convenient quantity of Water, Wine, or Beer. For, by this means you have the natural tate of this Spice or Herb. And Wormwood is a Plant, whoe Effluvia do o retain the nature of the Body that parts with
them, that I mut not forbear to alledge here an Obervation of mine, that may hew you, that 'tis poible, though not uual, that even without the help of the Fire the expirations of a Body may communicate its tat. For, among other things, that I had occaion to oberve about ome quantity of Wormwood laid up together, I remember, I took notice, and made others do the like, that coming into a room, where 'twas kept, not only the organs of melling were powerfully wrought upon by the Corpucles that warm'd in the Air, but alo the Mouth was enibly affected with a bitter tat. Perhaps you will carce think it worth while, that after this intance I hould add, that I found the expirations of Amber, kept a while in pure Spirit of Wine, tat upon the tongue like Amber it elf, when I chew'd it between my teeth. But I chooe to mention this intance, becaue it will connect thoe lately mention'd with another ort, very pertinent to our preent purpoe. For,
the expirations that I have obtain'd from Amber, both with pure Spirit of Wine, and a more piercing Menstruum, did manifetly retain in both thoe liquors a peculiar mell, with which I found it to affect the Notrils, when, for tryals ake, I excited the Electrical faculty of Amber by rubbing. And as for Odours, 'tis plain, that the Eential Oyls of Chymits, well drawn, do many of them retain the peculiar and genuine ent of the Spices or Herbs that afforded them. And that thee Odours do really conit of, or reide in certain inviible Corpucles that fly off from the viible Bodies, that are aid to be endow'd with uch Smells, I have elewhere prov'd at large; and it may ufficiently appear from their ticking to divers of the Bodies they meet with, and their lating adheion to them.

And firt, though the Touch be reckon'd one of the mot dull of the five Senes, and be reputed to be far les quick in Men than in divers other Animals; yet the gros Organs of that, may, in Men themelves, even by accident, be o dipos'd, as to be uceptible of impreions from Effluvia: Of this in another Paper I give ome Intances. And I know not whether divers of the Preages of Weather to be oberv'd in ome Animals, and the Aches and other pains, that, in many crazy and wounded
men, are wont to fore-run great changes of Weather, do not often (for I do not ay alwayes) proceed (at leat in part) from inviible and yet incongruous Effluxions, which, either from the ubterraneal parts, or from ome Bodies above ground, do copiouly impregnate the Air. And on this occaion it will not be impertinent to mention here what an experienc'd Phyician being (if I much miremember not) the Learned Dimmerbrook, relates concerning himelf, who having been infected with the Plague by a Patient that lay very ill of it, though by Gods bleing, which he particularly acknowledges, upon a light but eaonable Remedy, he was very quickly cured, and that without the breaking of any Tumor; yet it left uch a change in ome parts of his Body, that he ubjoyns this memorable paage; Ab illo periculo ad contagioos mihi appropinquanti in emunctoriis ucceit dolor, vix fallax Pestis indicium.

Two or three other Obervations
of the like nature you meet with in another of my Papers About Comical Supitions.. And I hall now add, that I know an ingenious Gentlewoman (Wife to a famous Phyician) who was of a very curious and delicate complexion, that has everal times aur'd me, that he can very readily dicover, whether a peron, that comes to viit her in Winter, came from ome place where there is any coniderable quantity of Snow; and this he does, (as he tells me) not by feeling any unuual cold (for if the ground be frozen but not cover'd with Snow, the Effect ucceeds not,) but from ome peculiar impreion, which he thinks, he receives by the organs of Smelling. I might add, that I know alo (as I may have formerly told you) a very ingenious Phyician, who falling into an odd kind of Feaver, had his ene of Hearing thereby made o very nice and tender, that he very plainly heard oft whipers, that were made at a coniderable ditance off, and which were
not in the leat perceiv'd by the healthy by-tanders, nor would have been by him before his icknes. Which (icknes) I mention as the thing, that gave his organs of Hearing this preternatural quicknes, becaue when the Feaver had quite left him, he was able to hear but at the rate of other men. And I might tell you too, that I know a Gentleman of eminent parts and note, who, during a ditemper he had in his Eyes, had his organs of Sight brought to be o tender, that both his friends and himelf alo have aur'd me, that when he wak'd in the Night he could for a while plainly ee and ditinguih Colours, as well as other objects, dicernable by the Eye, as was more than once try'd, by pinning Ribbands or the like Bodies of everal colours, to the inide of his Curtains in the dark. For if he were awaken'd in the Night, he would be able to tell his bed-fellow, where thoe Bodies were plac'd, and what colour each of them was of.

I have mention'd thee Intances only to hew you, that if our Senories were more delicate and quick, they would be ufficiently affected by Objects, that, as they are generally contituted, make no impreions at all upon them. For otherwie I know, that the Species (as they call them) both of Sounds and Colours, are not held by many of the Moderns, (from whom in that I dient not,) to be o much corporeal Effluxions, trajected through the medium, as peculiar kinds of Local Motion convey'd by it. Therefore I hall now confirm the conjecture I would countenance by the dicrimination made by the organs of other Animals of uch Effluvia as to us men are not only inviible but inenible. And therefore partly to trengthen what I deliver'd, and partly to confirm what I am now dicouring of, it will not be impertinent to ubjoyn two or three Relations, that I had from perons of very good credit, whom I thought likely to make me no unatisfactory returns
to my Quetions about things they were very well vers'd in.

A peron of Quality, to whom I am near allied, related to me, that to make a tryal, whether a young Blood-hound was well intructed, (or as the Huntmen call it, made) he caus'd one of his Servants, who had not kill'd, or o much as touch'd any of his Deer, to walk to a Countrey-town, four Mile off, and then to a Market-town three Miles ditant from thence; which done, this Nobleman did, a competent while after, put the Blood-hound upon the cent of the man, and caus'd him to be follow'd by a Servant or two, the Mater himelf thinking it alo fit to go after them to ee the event; which was, that the Dog, without ever eeing the Man he was to purue, follow'd him by the cent to the above-mentioned places, notwithtanding the multitude of Market-people that went along in the ame way, and of Travellers that had occaion to cros it. And when the Blood-hound came to the
chief Market-town, he pas'd through the treets, without taking notice of any of the people there, and left not till he had gone to the Houe, where the Man, he ought, reted himelf, and found him in an upper Room to the wonder of thoe that follow'd him. The particulars of this Narrative the Nobleman's Wife, a peron of great veracity, that happen'd to be with him when the tryal was made, confirm'd to me.

Enquiring of a tudious peron, that was Keeper of a Red-dear-park and vers'd in making Blood-hounds, in how long time, after a Man or Deer had pas'd by a gray place, one of thoe Dogs would be able to follow him by the cent? He told me, that it would be ix or even Hours: Whereupon an ingenious Gentleman, that chanc'd to be preent, and liv'd near that Park, aur'd us both, that he had old Dogs of o good a cent, that if a Buck had the day before pas'd in a Wood, they will, when they come where the cent lies,
though at uch a ditance of time after, preently find the cent and run directly to that part of the Wood where the Buck is. He alo told me, that though an old Blood-hound will not o eaily fix on the cent of a ingle Deer, that preently hides himelf in a whole herd; yet if the Deer be chas'd a little till he be heated, the Dog will go nigh to ingle him out, though the whole herd alo be chas'd. The above-nam'd Gentleman alo affirm'd, that he could eaily ditinguih whether his Hounds were in chae of a Hare or a Fox by their way of running, and their holding up their Noe higher than ordinary when they purue a Fox, whoe cent is more trong. Thee Relations will not be judg'd incredible by him that reflects on ome of the Intances that have already (in the foregoing Eay) been given of the trange ubtilty of Effluvia: To which I hall now add, that I remember, that to try whether I could in ome meaure make Art imitate Nature, I prepared a Body
of a vegetable ubtance, which, though it were actually cold, and both to the Eye and Touch dry, did for a while emit uch determinate and piercing, though inviible, Exhalations, that having for Tryals ake applied to it a clear Metalline Plate (and that of none of the very oftet kind neither) for about one Minute of an Hour, I found, that, though there had been no immediate contact between them, I having purpoely interpoed a piece of Paper to hinder it; yet there was imprinted on the urface of the Plate a conpicuous tain of that peculiar colour, that the Body, with whoe Steams I had imbued the vegetable ubtance, was fitted to give a Plate of that mix'd Metal. And though it be true, that in ome circumtances, the lately mention'd Intances about Blood-hounds have a coniderable advantage of this I have now recited; yet that advantage is much leen'd, not to ay countervail'd, by ome circumtances of our Experiment. For, not to repeat,
that the emittent Body was firm and cold, the Effect produced by the Effluvium that guided the Settingdog, was wrought upon the Senory of a living and warm Animal; and uch an one, whoe organs of Smelling are of an extraordinary tender Contitution above thoe of Men and other Animals, and probably the Impreion was but tranient; whereas in our cae the inviible Steams of the vegetable ubtance wrought upon a Body which was of o trong and inorganical a Texture as a (compounded) Metal, though it were fenc'd by being lapt up in Paper, notwithtanding which thee Steams invaded it in uch numbers, and o notably, as to make their Operation on it manifet to the Eye, and coniderably permanent too; ince coming to look upon the Plate after the third day, I found the induced Colour yet conpicuous, and not like uddenly to vanih.

Hitherto in this Chapter I have argued from the contant and etled
difference of the enible Qualities of Effluviums, that they do not always loe their ditinct natures, when they eem to have lot themelves by vanihing into Air. But before I dimis this Subject, I mut conider an Objection, which I know may be made againt the Opinion we have been countenancing. For it may be alledg'd, that there may be many caes, wherein the Effluviums of Bodies are, in their paage through the Air, enibly alter'd, or do affect the Organs of ene otherwie than each kind of them apart would do: Nor is this difficulty altogether irrational. For it eems cononant enough to Experience, that ome uch caes hould be admitted, and therefore in the foregoing Dicoure I have, where I thought it neceary, forborn to expres my elf in uch general and abolute terms, as otherwie I might have done. But, as for uch caes as I have inited upon, and many more, I hall now repreent, that the objected alterations need not hinder, but that
Effluviums at their firt parting from the Bodies, whence they take wing (if I may o peak,) may retain as much of the nature of thoe Bodies, as we have acribed to them, ince the ubequent change may very probably be deduc'd from the combinations or coalitions of divers Steams aociating themelves in the Air, and acting upon the Senory, either altogether and conjointly, or at leat o near it, that the Sene cannot perceive their Operations as ditinct. This I hall elucidate, but not pretend to prove, by what happens in Sounds and Tats. For if, by way of intance, in a Muical intrument, two trings tun'd to an eight, be touch'd together, they will trike the Ear with a ound, that will be judg'd one, as well as pleaing, though each of the trembling trings make a ditinct noie, and the one vibrates as fat again as the other. And if, into Oyl of Tartar per Deliquium, you drop a due proportion of Spirit of Nitre, and exhale the uperfluous moiture,
the Acid and Alcalizate Corpucles, that were o mall as to wim inviibly in thoe liquors, will convene into Nitrous Concretions, whoe tat will be compounded of, but very differing from, both the tats of the Acid and Tartareous Particles; which Particles may yet, for the mot part, by a skilful Ditillation, be divorc'd again. And o, if to a trong olution of Pot-ahes or Salt of Tartar you put as much in weight of Sal Armoniack, as there is of either of thoe fixt Salts contain'd in the liquor; you may, beides a ubtil Urinous Spirit that will eaily come over in the ditillation, obtain a dry Caput mortuum, which is almot totally a compounded Salt, differing enough from either of the ingredients, epecially the Alcalizate, as well in Tat as in ome other Qualities: This Salt (free'd from its faeces) being that Diuretick Salt, I everal years ago gave quantities of, to ome Chymits and Phyicians, from the mot of whom I received great thanks, accompanied
with the (more acceptable) accounts of the very happy ucces they had employed it with, though uually but in a mall Doe, as from ix, eight or ten Grains to a Scruple. But this being mentioned only upon the by, I hall proceed to tell you, that, ince I intimated to you already, that I would mention Examples of Sounds and Tasts only to illutrate what I had been delivering; I hall now add ome Intances by way of Proof, of the Coalition and reulting change of Steams in the Air. 'Tis eaily obervable in ome Noe-gays, where the differing Flowers happen to be conveniently mix'd, that in the mell afforded by it, at a due ditance, the Odours of the particular Flowers are not perceiv'd, but the Organ is affected by their joynt-action, which makes on it a confued but delightful impreion. And o, when in a Ball of Pomander, or a perfum'd Skin, Musk, and Amber, and Civet, and other weets are skilfully mix'd, the coalition of the ditinct Effluvia of the
ingredients, that aociate themelves in their paage through the Air, produce in the Senory one grateful perfume, reulting from all thoe Odours. But if you take Spirit of fermented Urine and Spirit of Wine, both of them Phelgmatick, and mix them together, they will incorporate like Wine and Water, or any other uch liquors, without affording any dry concretions. But if you expoe them in a convenient Veel but to the mild heat of a Bath or Lamp, the acending Particles will aociate themelves, and adhere to the upper part of the Glas in the form of a white but tender Sublimate, coniting both of Urinous and Vinous Spirits, aociated into a mixture, which differs from either of the liquors, not only in Conitence, Tat and Smell, but in ome coniderable Operations performable by this odd mixture; which, this is not the place, to take further notice of. And if Spirit of Salt and Spirit of Nitre be, by Ditillation, elevated in the form of Fumes,
o order'd as to convene into one liquor in the Receiver, this liquor will readily diolve crude Gold, though neither the Spirit of Nitre alone, nor that of Salt would do o.

And that you may have an ocular proof of the Poibility of the ditinctnes and ubequent Commixture of Steams in the Air; I hall now add an Experiment, which I long ince devis'd for that purpoe, and which I oon after hew'd to many curious perons, mot of whom appear'd omewhat urpriz'd at it. The Experiment was; that I took two mall Vials, the one fill'd with Spirit of Salt, but not very trong, the other with Spirit of fermented Urine or of Sal Armoniack very well rectified: Thee Vials being plac'd at ome ditance, and not being top'd, each liquor afforded its own mell, at a pretty ditance, by the Steams it emitted into the Air, but yet thee Steams were inviible. But when thee Vials, (which hould be of the ame ize) came to be approach'd
very near to each other, though not o, as to touch; as when the two liquors are put together in the form of liquors, they will notably act upon one another; o their repective Effluviums meeting in the Air, would, anwerably to the littlenes of their bulk, do the like, and, by their mutual occurions, become manifetly viible, and appear moving in the Air like a little portion of Smoak or of a Mit, which would quickly ceae, if either of the Vials were remov'd half a Foot or a Foot from the other. And I remember, that, to add to the oddnes of the Phaenomenon, I ometimes made a drop of the Spirit of Salt hang at the bottom of a little tick of Glas or ome other convenient Body, and held this drop thus upended in the Orifice of a Vial that had Spirit of Sal Armoniack in it, and was furnih'd with a omewhat long neck; for by this means it happen'd, as I expected, that the acending Urinous Particles, though inviible before, invading plentifully the
Acid ones of the drop, produced a notable Smoak, which, if the drop were held a little above the neck of the Glas, would mot commonly fly upwards to the height of a Foot or half a Yard: But if the drop were held omewhat deep within the Cavity of the neck, a good part of the produced Smoak would oftentimes fall into the Cavity of the Vial, which was left in great part empty, ometimes in the form of drops, but uually in the form of a lender and omewhat winding tream of a white colour, that eem'd to flow down jut like a Liquor from the depending drop, till it had reach'd the Spirit of Sal Armoniack; upon whoe urface it would pread it elf like a Mit. But this only upon the by. As for the main Experiment it elf, it may be, as I have found, uccesfully try'd with other Liquors than thee; but 'tis not neceary in this place to give an account of uch Tryals; though perhaps, if I had leiure, it might be worth while to conider, whether
thee Coalitions of differing orts of Steams in the Air, and the Changes reulting thence of their particular precedent Quantities, may not ait us to invetigate the caues of divers udden Clouds and Mits, and ome other Meteorological Phaenomena, and alo of divers changes that happen in the Air in reference to the coming in and ceaing of everal either Epidemical or contagious Dieaes, and particularly the Plague, that eem to depend upon ome occult temperature and alterations of the Air, which may be copiouly impregnated by the differing ubterraneal (not to add here, Sidereal) Effluviums, that not unfrequently acend into it (or otherwie invade it,) with Petiferous or other Morbifick Corpucles, and ometimes with others of a contrary Nature, and ometimes too perhaps, neither the one ort of Steams, which may be uppos'd to have imbued the Air, is in it elf deleterious; nor the other alutary, but becomes o upon their caual coalition in the Air. You
will perhaps think this Conjecture of the reultancy of petilential Steams, the les improbable, if I here add that odd Obervation, which was frequently made in the formerly mentioned Plague at Nimmegen by a Phyician o Judicious as Tract. de Pete, lib. 2. cap. 3. Dimmerbrook, whoe words are thee; Illud notatu dignum aepiime obervavimus, nempa in illis aedibus in quibus nulla adhuc petis erat, i linteamina ordida aquâ & apone notrate (ut in Belgio moris et) illio lavarentur, eo ipo die, vel interdum potridie, duos tres-ve imul pete correptos fuie, ipique aegri test abantur faetorem aquae aponatae illis primam & maximam alterationem intulie. Hoc ipum quoque in meo ipius hopitio infelix experientia docuit, in quo pot lota linteamina tatim gravem alterationem perceperunt plaerique domestici, & proximè equenti nocte tres pete correptae, ac brevi pot mortuae fuere. I omit the Intances he further ets down to confirm this odd Phaenomenon, of which, though perhaps ome
other Caue may be devied, yet that I lately aign'd eems at leat a probable one, if not the mot probable; ince, as 'tis manifet by daily experience, that the mell occaion'd by the wahing of foul Linnen with the Soap commonly ued in the Netherlands, produces not the Plague; o by our Learned Author's Obervation it appears, either that there were not yet any Petilential Effluxions in the Air of thoe places, which on the occaions of thoe wahings became infected, or at leat that by the addition of the fetid Effluvia of the oapy Water, thoe Morbifick Particles, that were dipers'd through the Air before, had not the power to introduce a malignant contitution into the Air, and to act as truly Petilential, till they were enabled to do o by being aociated with the ill-cented Effluvia of the Soap.

Whether alo Salutary, and, if I may o call them, Alexipharmacal Corpucles may not be produc'd in the Air by Coalition, might be very
well worth our Enquiry: Epecially if we had a competent Hitorical Account of the yearly ceaing of the Plague at Grand Cayro. For, as I have elewhere noted out of the Learned Proper Alpinus, who practis'd Phyick there; and as I have alo been inform'd by ome of my Acquaintance who viited that vat City, that almot in the midt of Summer as oon as the River begins to rieThe Plague which here mierably rageth upon the firt of the Flood doth instantly ceae; in o much as when five Hundred dye at Cayro the day before, which is nothing rare, (for the ound keep company with the ick, holding Death fatal, and, to avoid them, Irreligion,) not one doth dye the day following; ays Mr. Sandys in his Travels, Lib. 2., the Plague has its malignity uddenly check'd, even as to thoe that are already infected, and oon after ceaes; o if other Circumtances contradict not, one might gues, that this trange Phaenomenon may be chiefly occaion'd by ome Nitrous or other Corpucles that accompany the overflowing Nile, and by aociating themelves with what Hippocrates
omewhere calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , diable them to produce their wonted pernicious Effects. To which Hypotheis uits well what is deliver'd by more than one Traveller into Egypt, and more particularly by our Ingenious Countreyman Mr. George Sandys, who not only takes notice, that about the time of the overflowing of Nilus, whoe abounding with Nitre has been oberved even by the Antients, there is a certain moitening Emanation diffus'd thorow the Air. To prove, ayes heMr. Sandys in the Book abovecited., peaking of the overflowing of Nilus, that it proceedeth from a natural Caue, this one, though trange, yet true Experiment will uffice. Take of the Earth of Egypt adjoining to the River, and preerve it carefully, that it neither come to be wet nor wated, weight it daily, and you hall find it neither more nor les heavy until the eventeenth of June, at which day it beginneth to grow more ponderous, and augmenteth
with the augmentation of the River, whereby they have an infallible knowledge of the tate of the Deluge, proceeding without doubt from the Humidity of the Air, which having a recoure through all paible places, and mixing therewith increaeth the ame, as it increaeth in moiture.

That thee Sanative Steams perform their Effects meerly becaue they are moit, I preume Naturalits will carce pretend; but that they may be of uch a nature as by their Coalition with the Morbifick Corpucles to increae their Bulk and alter their Figure, or precipitate them out of the Air, or clog their Agility, or pervert their Motions, and in a word detroy all or ome Tat leat of thoe Mechanical Affections which made thoe Corpucles Petilential: That, I ay, thee Antidotal Vapours (if I may o call them) may have thee Effects upon thoe that formerly were Morbifick, and that o there may reult from the Aociation of
two orts of Particles, whereof one was of a highly noxious nature, a harmles mixture, might here be made probable by everal things; but that I hope what I have lately recited about the Coalitions of the Effluvia of Spirit of Salt and of Urine (Liquors known to be highly contrary to each other) is not already forgotten by you.

And the Experiment with which I am to conclude this Eay will perhaps make you think it poible, that the Petiferous Steams that have already pas'd out of the Air, and invaded, but not too much vitiated, the Bodies of Men, may have their malignity much debilitated by the upervening of thee Antidotal Particles. For in that Experiment you will find, that the Steams emitted into the Air from the Liquor there decribed, though that were actually cold, were able to reach, and manifetly to Operate, (and that probably by way of Praecipitation,) upon Corpucles that were fenc'd from them
by the Interpoition of other Bodies; not more porous than thoe of living Men. Whether the fume of Sulphur, which by many is extoll'd to prevent the Infection of the Air, do by its acid or other Particles diarm, if I may o peak, the Petilential ones, I have not now time to inquire: No more than whether in Ireland and ome few other Countries, that breed or brook no poyonous Animals, that hotility may proceed, at leat in great part, from the peculiar Nature of the Soyl, which both from its uperficial and deeper parts, contantly upplies the Air with Corpucles detructive to venemous Animals. And ome other Particulars, that may be pertinently enough conider'd here, you may find treated on in other Papers. And therefore at preent I hall only intimate in a word, that having purpoely made a viible and lating Stain on a olid Body barely by cold Effluvia, I did by the inviible and cold Steams of another Body make in two or three Minutes a
viible change in the colour of that Stain.

And as for the other part of the Conjecture, (viz.) That Meteors may ometimes be produc'd by the Occurions of Subterraneal Effluvia, ome of them of one determinate Nature, and ome of another, I think I could, to countenance it, give you divers Intances of the plentiful Impregnation) of the Air at ome times, and in ome places, with Steams of very differing Natures, and uch as are not o likely to be attracted by the Heat of the Sun, as to be ent up from the Subterraneal Regions, and ometimes from Minerals themelves. But for Intances of this kind, I hall, for brevities ake, refer you to another PaperAn Eay of Subterraneal Exhalations. , where I have purpoely treated of this Subject, and particularly hewn, That though uually the Effluxions that come from under ground are ill-cented, yet they are not alwayes o; and alo that Sulphureous
Exhalations even from cold, and, for the mot part, Aqueous Liquors may retain their determinate nature in the Air, and act accordingly upon olid Bodies themelves, to whoe Contitution thoe Effluvia chance to be proportionate.

But one memorable Story not mention'd
<…> that Dicoure is too much to our preent purpoe to be here omitted, epecially having met with it in o approved an Author as the experienc'd Agricola, who having mention'd out of antient Hitorians the Raining of White and Red liquors, which they took (erroneouly I doubt not) for Milk and Blood, ubjoyns,
Agric. de Nat. eorum quae effluunt è Terra, Lib. 12. pag. 236. Ut autem majorèm fidem habe amus Annalium monumentis facit res illa decantata, quae Patrum memoriâ (in another place he pecifies the Year of our Lord) in Suevia accidit; Aer enim ille tillavit guttas, quae lineas vetes crucibus rubris quai anguineis imbuebant. Which I the rather mention, becaue it does
not only prove what I alledge it for; but may keep, what is lately and very credibly reported to have happen'd in divers places of the Kingdom of Naples oon after the Fiery Eruption of Veuvius, from being judg'd a Phaenomenon either altogether fabulous, (as doubtles many have thought it,) or a Prodigie without all example, as is preum'd even by thoe that think it not miraculous. And to this I add, that 'twill be the les improbable, that the more agile Corpucles of Subterraneal Salts, Sulphurs and Bitumens, may be rais'd into the Air, and keep ditinct natures there, if o fixt a Body as common Earth it elf can be brought to wim in the Air. And yet of this the worthy Writer newly quoted gives us, beides what Annals relate, this Tetimony upon his own knowledge:
Agric. de Nat. eorum quae è Terra effluunt, Lib. 12. pag. 263. Certè hîc Kempnicii undecimum abhinc annum mene Septembri effluxerunt imbres, ic cum terra lutea
commiti, ut eâ paim plateas cilicet tratas viderem conperas.

And to hew you that in ome caes the Particles even of Vegetable Bodies may not o oon perih in the Air as they vanih there, but may retain ditinct natures at a greater ditance, than one would think, from the Bodies that copiouly emit them; I hall add, that having deir'd an ingenious Gentleman, that went on a coniderable Employment to the Eat-Indies, to make ome Obervations for me in his Voyage; he ent me among other things this Remarque: That having ayl'd along the Coat of Ceylon, (famous for Cinnamon-trees and well-cented Gums,) though they Coated it almot a whole day, the Wind, that then chanc'd to blow from the hoar, brought them a manifetly odoriferous Air from the Iland, though they kept off many miles (perhaps twenty or twentyfive) from the hoar. Nor hould this be thought incredible, becaue the diffuion eems o diproportionate to
that of other Bodies diolved by Fluids; as, for intance, though Salt be an active Body and reoluble into abundance of minute Particles, yet one part of Salt will carce be tatable in an hundred parts of Water. For enibly to affect o gros an Organ as that of our Tat, there is uually required in apid Particles a bignes far exceeding that which is neceary to the making Bodies fit Objects for the ene of Smelling, and, which is here mainly to be conidered, there is a great difference between the power a Body has to impregnate o thin and fine a Fluid as Air, whoe parts are o rare and lax, and that which it has to impregnate Liquors, uch as Water or Wine, whoe parts are o contipated as to make it not only viible and tangible, but ponderous. On which occaion I remember that having had a Curioity to try how far a apid Body could be diluted without ceaing to be o, I found by Tryal, that one drop of good Chymical, and, as Artits call it, Eential
Oyl of Cinnamon being duly mix'd by the help of Sugar with Wine, retain'd the determinate tat of Cinnamon, though it were diffus'd into near a quart of Wine. So that making a moderate etimate, I concluded, that upon the common uppoition, according to which a drop is reckon'd for a Grain, one part of Oyl had given the pecifick Tat of the Spice, it was drawn from, to near fourteen thouand parts of Wine. By comparing which Experiment with what I noted about the proportion of Salt requiite to make Water tat of it, you will eaily perceive; that there may be a very great difference in point of diffuivenes between the little Particles that make Bodies apid: Which may erve to confirm both ome part of the firt Chapter of the foregoing Eay of the Subtilty of Effluvia and what I was lately aying to hew it poible, that Antimonial Glas might impart tore of Steams to the Emetick Wine, without appearing upon common Scales to have lot of its
weight; ince we ee, that one Drop of o light a Body as Oyl may communicate not inenible Effluvia, but tatable Corpucles to near a Quart of Liquor. But this is not all for which I mention our Experiment: for I mut now add, that beides the almot innumerable Sapid parts of a picy Drop communicated to the Wine, it thence diffued a vat number of odorous Particles into the Air, which both I, and others perceived to be imbued with the ditinct cent of Cinnamon, and which perhaps the Liquor would have been found able to have Aromatized for I know not how long a time, if I had had leiure to proecute the Obervation.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
THE third and lat way I hall mention of hewing the Determinate Nature of Effluviums, is to
be taken from the Conideration of their Effects upon other Bodies than the Organs of our Senes; (for of their Operations upon thee we have already poken in the foregoing Chapter) For the Effects, that certain Bodies produce on others by their Effluviums, being contant and determinate, and oftentimes very different from thoe, which other Agents by their Emiions work upon the ame and other ubjects, the ditinct nature of the Corpucles emitted may be thence ufficiently gather'd.

We may from the foregoing Tract of the Subtilty of Effluvia, borrow ome Intances very pertinent to this place. For the temporary benumbednes or tupefaction, for example, produc'd in the Fiherman's Foot by the Effluvia See the Eay of the Subtilty of Effluviums, Chap. 4. of the Fih (Amoreatim) mention'd by the Ingenious Pio, manifets, that thoe tupifying Emanations retain'd a peculiar and venemous nature during their whole paage
through the Shoe, Stocking and Skin, interpos'd betwixt the Fih and the nervous part of the Foot benumb'd by it. And though there are very few other Bodies in the World, that are minute enough to pas through the pores of Glas, 'tis apparent, by the Experiment there recited of the oblong Iron Hermetically eal'd up in a Glas-pipe, that the Magnetical Effluvia of the Earth may retain their peculiar and wonderful nature in a mallnes that qualifies them to pas freely through the pores of Glas it elf.

But that I may neither repeat what you have already met with in the foregoing Tract, nor anticipate what I have to ay in the next; I will employ in this Chapter ome Intances that may be par'd from both.

That divers Bodies of a Venemous nature may exercie ome uch Operations upon others by their Effluviums tranmitted through the Air, as they are wont to do in their gros ubtance, is a Truth, whereof though
I have not met with many, yet I have met with ome Examples among Phyicians.

The LearnedLib. 6. parte 7. cap. 1. Sennertus oberves as a known thing, that the Apprentices of Apothecaries have been cat into profound Sleeps, when in ditilling Opiat and Hypnotick Liquors they have received in at their Notrils the Vapours exhaling from thoe Bodies.

'Tis recorded by theIn Explicatione Herbarum Biblicarum, cap. 2. Writers about Poyons, that the root and juyce of Mandragora cats thoe, that take it, into a deep Sopor not unlike a Lethargy. And though the Apples of the ame Plant be thought to be much les malignant; yet Levinus Lemnius relates that it happen'd to him more than once, that having laid ome Mandrake-Apples in his Study, he was by their Steams made o leepy, that he could hardly recover himelf; but the Apples being taken away he
regain'd alacrity, and threw off all drowines.

Among all Poyons there is carce any whoe Phaenomena are in my opinion more trange than thoe that proceed from a mad Dog; and yet even this Poyon, which eems to require Corpucles of o odd and determinate a nature, is recorded by Phyicians to have been conveyed by Exhalations. Aretaeus writes (as a Learned modern quotes him,) Quòd à rabido cane, qui in faciem, dum piritus adducitur, tantummodò inpiraverit, & nullo modo momorderit, in rabiem homo agatur. And as there are relations, among Phyicians, of Animals, that have become Rabioi by having eaten of the parts or excrements of rabid Animals; o Libro 3. Acutor. Morbor. Caelius Aurelianus, who writes, that ome have been made to run mad, not by being bitten, but wounded only with the Claws of a mad Dog, tells us alo of a man, that fell into a Hydrophobia (which is wont to be a high
degree of the Rabies, and by ome of the antienter Writers was employ'd to ignifie that Dieae) without being bitten by a mad Dog, but infected olo odore ex rabido cane attracto. By which Odours in this and other Narratives of Poyons I undertand not a bare Scholatick pecies, but a warm of Effluvia, which mot commonly are all or at leat ome of them odorous. And though it may jutly eem trange to many, that the Venom of a mad Dog hould be communicated otherwie than by biting, which is uppos'd to be the only way he can infect by, it may appear les improbable, becaue Matthaeus de Gradibus names a peron, who, he ays, prov'd infected after many days, by only having put his Hand into the Mouth of a mad Dog, who did not bite him. And the formerly mentioned Matthiolus relates, that he aw two, that were made rabid without any would by the labber of a mad Dog, with which they had the mifortune to be bemear'd.

Sennert. Libr. 6. part. 6. cap. 2. Sennertus himelf affirms of a Painter of his acquainance, that, when he had open'd a Box, in which he had long kept included Realgar, a noxious Mineral, ometimes ued by Painters and not unknown to Chymits, and had unfortunately nuff'd in the Steams of it, he was eis'd with a giddines in his Head and fainting fits, his whole Face alo welling, though by taking of Antidotes he ecap'd the danger.

Divers other Examples we have met with in the writings of Phyicians, which I forbear to add to thee, becaue, I confes, I very much doubt the Truth of them, though the deliverers of ome of them be men of Note. But the probability of mot of the things already cited out of credible Authors may be trengthned by what I hall now ubjoyn, as a further proof of the ditinct Nature of Effluvia; of which it will be a very coniderable Proof, if Medicines, which are of a milder and
more familiar nature and operation than Poyons, hall yet be able in ome caes to retain, in their inviible Particles wimming in the Air, the ame, (though not o great) power of Purging, which is known to belong to them when their gros Body is taken in at the Mouth. Of this I have elewhere, on another occaion, given ome Examples. To which I hall now add, that I know a Doctor of Phyick, that is uually Purg'd by the Odours or Exhalations of a certain Electuary, whoe Cathartick Operation, when it is taken in ubtance, is wont to be but languid. And another Doctor of my acquaintance, cauing good tore of the root of black Hellebore to be long pounded in a mortar, mot of thoe, that were in the room, and epecially the party that pounded it, were thereby purg'd, and ome of them trongly enough. And the Learned Sennertus omewhere affirms, that ome will be purg'd by the very Odour of Colocynthis. And 'tis not to be pas'd by
unregarded; that in the caes I have alledg'd, Exhalations, that are endow'd with Occult Qualities, (for thoe of Cathartick Medicines are reckon'd among uch) acend into the Air without being forc'd from the Bodies they belong'd to by an External heat.

And if I would in this place alledge Examples of the Operations of uch Effluvia, as do not pas into the Air, but yet operate only by the contact of the External parts of the Body, I could give Intances, not only of the Purgative, but the Emetick Qualities of ome Medicines exerted without their being taken in at the Mouth, or injected with Intruments.

There are alo other orts of Examples than thoe hitherto mentioned, that argue a Determinate Nature in the Effluxions of ome Bodies emitted into the Air. Approv'd Writers tell us, that the Shadow of a Walnut-tree with the Leaves on it is very hurtful to the Head; and ome Intances they give us of great michief it has
ometimes done. And though the Shadow, as uch, is not likely to be guilty of uch bad Effects; yet the Effluvia of the neighbouring Plant may be noxious enough to the Head. For I, that was not at all prepoes'd with an opinion that it was o, and therefore without cruple reorted to the Shade of Walnut trees in a hot Countrey, was by experience forc'd to think it might give others the Head-ach, ince it did to me, who, thanks be to God, both was, and am till very little ubject to that ditemper.
