And this brings into my mind an Obervation that I have met with among ome ingenious Travellers into the Wet-Indies, who oberve in general, and of late a Country-man of our own affirms it in particular, of the poyonous Manchinello-tree, that Birds will not only forbear to eat of the Fruit of venemous Plants, but, as to ome of them, will not o much as light on the Trees: Which I therefore mention, becaue probably Nature intructs them to avoid
uch Trees by ome noxious Smell, or other Emanation, that offends the approaching Birds. And I remember, that ome of our Navigators give it for a Rule to thoe that happen to land in unknown Ilands or Coats, that they may venture to eat of thoe parts of Fruits which they can perceive, the Birds, like kind Taters, to have been pecking at before.

Nicolaus Florentinus (cited by Sennertus) tells us of a certain Lombard, that having in a Houe, that he nam'd, at Florence, burn'd a great black Spider at the flame of a Candle, o unwarily, that he drew in the Steams of it at his Notrils, preently began to be much diorder'd and fell into a fainting fit, and for the whole night had his Heart much diaffected, his Pule being o weak, that one could carce perceive he had any; though afterwards he was cured by Treacle, Diamoe, and the powder of Zedoary mixt together.

And I remember, that being ome years ago in Ireland, I gather'd a
certain Plant (peculiar to ome parts of that Countrey) which the Natives call Maccu-buy, becaue of trange Traditions that go about it; the chief of which I found by tryal not to be true: But yet being atisfied, that its Operations were odd and violent enough, I was willing to gratifie the chief Phyician of the Countrey, who was deirous I hould propoe to him ome wayes of correcting it; and whilt I was peaking of one that required the pounding of it, he told me on that occaion, that intending to make an extract of it with Vinegar, he caus'd his man to beat it well in a Mortar, which the man oon repented he had begun to do: And the Doctor himelf, though at a pretty ditance off, was o wrought upon by the Corpucles that iued out into the Air, that his Head, and particularly his Face, well'd to an enormous and disfiguring bulk, and continued tumid for no inconiderable time after.

I have not leiure to ubjoyn many
more Intances to hew the Determinate Nature of Effluviums, mall enough to wander through the Air; nor perhaps will it be neceary, if you pleae but to conider thee two things. The firt, that many odoriferous Bodies, as Amber, Musk, Civet, &c. as they will, by the adheion of their whole ubtance, perfume Skins, Linnen, &c. o they will in time perfume ome Bodies dipoed to admit their action, though kept at a ditance from them. And the other is, that in Petilential Feavers and divers other Contagious icknees, as the Plague, Small-pox, or Meaels, the ame determinate Dieae is communicable to found perons, not only by the immediate contact of the infected party; but without it, by the Contagious Steams that exhale from his Body into the Air. And having aid this and deir'd you to reflect upon it, I hall conclude this Chapter with an Experiment, that poibly will not a little confirm a great part of it.

Conidering then with my elf, how I might bet devie a way of hewing to the very Eye, That Effluvia elevated without the help of Heat, and wandering in the Air, may both retain their own Nature, and upon determinate Bodies produce Effects, that a Vulgar Philoopher would acribe to Occult Qualities: I remember'd, that I had found by tryals (made to other purpoes) that Volatile and Sulphureous Salts would o work upon ome Acid ones ublim'd with Mercury, as to produce an odd diverity of Colours, but chiefly an Inky one; on which account I judg'd it likely that my aim would by anwer'd by the following Experiment.

I took an Ounce, or better, of uch a Volatile Tincture of Sulphur, as I have elewhereThe Liquor here mention'd is, for the main, the ame with that decrib'd by the Author in his Book of Colours, Experiment the <…>
taught you to make of Quick-lime, Sulphur and Sal Armoniack, and top'd it up in a Vial
capable of containing at leat twice as much; then taking a Paper whereon omething had been written with inviible Ink, I laid it down ix Inches off of the Vial, which, being untop'd, began, upon the acces of the Fire, to emit white Fumes into it; and by thee, what was written upon the Paper, notwithtanding its ditance from the Liquor, quickly became very legible, though not quite o uddenly, as if a Paper, written with the ame clear Liquor, were held at the like ditance directly over the orifice of the Vial. And having caus'd everal pieces of clean Paper to be written on, with a new Pen dip'd in the clear Solution of Sublimate made in Water, 'twas pleaant to ee, how divers of the Letters of everal of thee Papers, being plac'd within ome convenient ditance of the Vial, would be made plainly legible, and ome of them more, ome les blackih, according to their ditances from the moaking Liquor, and other Circumtances. But 'twas
more urprizing to ee, that when I held or laid ome of thee Papers, though with the written ide upwards, jut upon or over the orifice of the Vial, though the contained Liquor did not by ome Inches reach o high, yet the latent Letters would become not only legible but conpicuous in about a quarter of a Minute of an Hour (meaur'd by a good Watch fit for the purpoe, as more than one tryal aur'd me.) And as it may be oberv'd, that in ome Circumtances the moaking Liquor and the Solution of Sublimate will make an odd Precipitate almot of a ilverih colour, o in one or two of our Tryals we found a like colour produc'd, by the Steams of that Liquor, in ome of the colourles Ink. Nor is it o neceary to employ a viibly moaking Liquor for the denigrating of inviible Ink at a ditance. For I have, to that purpoe, with good ucces, though not equal to that I have recited, employ'd a couple of Liquors, wherein there was neither Sulphur,
nor Sal Armoniack, nor Sublimate. What other Tryals I made with our Volatile Tincture of Sulphur, 'tis not neceary here to relate, only one Experiment, which you will poibly think odd enough, I hall not omit; becaue it will not only confirm the precedent Tryals, but alo much of the foregoing Eay, by hewing the great Subtilty and penetrating power of Effluviums that eem rather to iue out very faintly, than to be darted out with any brisknes.

Cauing then omething to be written with diolv'd Sublimate upon a piece of Paper, we folded the Paper with the written ide inwards, and then inclos'd this in the midt of ix heets of Paper, laid one upon another, not plac'd one within another, and folded up in the form of an ordinary Letter or packet to be eal'd, that, the edges of the encloing Paper being inerted one within the other, the Fumes might not get into this written Paper but by penetrating through the Leaves themelves: This
done, that ide of the Packet, on which there was no commiure, and on which, were it to be ent away, the Supercription hould be written, was laid upon the orifice of the Vial, which (as was before intimated) was ome Inches higher than the urface of the Liquor, and left there about ten Minutes; after which taking off the folded Papers, and opening them, we found, that the Steams had pervaded all the Leaves, in which the written Paper had been enclos'd. For, though the Leaves did not appear tain'd or alter'd, yet the formerly latent Characters appear'd conpicuous. I have not time to dicoure, whether and how far this Experiment may ait us to explain ome odd Effects of Thunder, or of that trange Phaenomenon, (glanc'd at in the foregoing Chapter,) which is aid to have happen'd lately in the Kingdom of Naples after the great Eruption of Veuvitus, which is aid to have been follow'd by the appearing of the Croes formerly mention'd, ome of
which have been found on the innermot parts of Linnen, that had been carefully folded up. But of thee and the like things, I ay, I have now no time to dicoure, whether any thing derivable from our Experiment may be pertinently apply'd to their Explication. For which reaon I hall add no more than that afterwards for further tryal we took a printed Book, that chanc'd to be at hand, and which we judg'd the fittet for our purpoe, becaue the leaves being broad they might the better preerve a mall Paper to be plac'd in the mid't of them from being acceible to the Exhalations idewie, and having put the deign'd Paper into this Book, and held it to the orifice of the Vial, though there were no les than twelve leaves between them; yet thoe Letters, that happen'd to be the mot rightly plac'd, were made inky in the hort pace of three Minutes at the utmot; though this Liquor had been o long kept and o often untop'd to try Concluions with it,
that it had probably lot a good part of the mot pirituous and piercing Particles.
NEW EXPERIMENTS, To make the PARTS OF FIRE and FLAME Stable & Ponderable.
BY The Honorable Robert Boyle.
LONDON: Printed by WILLIAM GODBID, for Moes Pitt, at the Sign of the White Hart in Little Britain. 1673.

div.head: A PREFACE; SHEWING The Motive, Deign, and Parts of the enuing Tract.
div.p: THE Inducements which put me upon the Attempt, expres'd in the Title of this Eay, were chiefly thee:

Firt, I conider'd, that the Interstellar part of the Univere, coniting of Air and Aether, or Fluids analogous to one of them, is diaphanous; and that the Aether is, as it were, a vat Ocean, wherein the Luminous globes, that here and there like Fihes wim by their own motion, or like Bodies in Whirlpools are carried about by the Ambient, are but very thinly dipers'd, and conequently that the proportion, that the Fixt Stars
and Planetary Bodies bear to the diaphanous part of the World, is exceeding mall and carce coniderable; though we hould admit the Sun and Fixt Stars to be Opacous Bodies upon the account of their terminating our ight: Which diffident Expreion I employ, becaue I have elewhere hewn by two or three Experiments, purpoely devied, that a Body may appear opacous to our Eyes, and yet allow free paage to the beams of Light.

I further conider'd, that there being o vat a diproportion between the diaphanous part of the World and the Globes, about which 'tis every way diffued, and with which it is ometimes in great portions mingled, as in the water, which together with the Earth makes up the Globe we inhabit; and the nature of Diaphanous Bodies being uch, that, when the Sun or any other Luminous Body illutrates them, that which we call Light does o penetrate and mix it elf per minima with them, that there is no enible part of the tranparent Body uninlightned; I thought it worth the enquiry, whether a thing, o vatly diffued
as Light is were ome thing Corporeal or not? And whether, in cae it be, it may be ubjected to ome other of our Senes beides our Sight, whereby we may examine; whether it hath any affinity with other Corporeal beings, that we are acquainted with here below?

I did not all this while forget, that the Peripateticks make Light a meer Quality, and that Carteius ingeniouly endeavours to explicate it by a modification of Motion in an Aetherial matter: But I remember'd too, that the Atomits of old, and of late the Learned Gaffendus, and many other Philoophers aert Light to be Corporeal; and that ome Tears ince, though I declined to pas my Judgement about the Question, yet I had employ'd Arguments, that appear'd plauible enough to hew, That 'twas not aburd to uppoe, that the Sun, which is the Fixt Star mot known to us, might be a Fiery Body. And therefore doubting, whether the Corporeity of Light would be in hate Determined by meer Ratiocinations, I thought it very well worth the endeavouring to try whether I could do any
thing towards clearing the dipute of it by Experiments; epecially being perwaded, that, though uch an attempt hould be ineffectual, it would but leave the controverie in its former state, without prejudicing either of the contending Hypothees; and yet, if it hould prove uccesful, the conequences of it would be very great and ueful towards the explicating of divers Phaenomena in divers parts of Natural Philoophy, as in Chymitry, Botanicks, and (if there be any uch) the allowable part of Atrologie. (Nor perhaps would it be impoible by the help of light Theorical alterations; to reconcile the Experiments, I deign'd, to either of the abovemention'd Hypothees, and o as to the Explication of Light, to one another.)

I know I might have aved both you and my elf ome time and pains by omitting everal of thee Tryals, and by a more compendious way of delivering the ret. But I rather choe the coure I have taken; partly becaue the Novelty and Improbabilities of the Truth I deliver eems to require, that it be made out by a good number of Tryals; partly becaue I thought it might not be altogether ueles to you and your Friends, to ee upon what Inducements the everal steps were made in this Inquiry; partly becaue I was willing to contribute omething towards the Hitory that now perhaps will be thought fit to be made of the Increment or Decrement that particular Bodies may receive by being expoed to the Fire; and partly (in fine) becaue the Incongruity of the Doctrine here aerted to the Opinions of the Schools, and the general Prepoeions
of Mankind, made me think it fit by a coniderable Variety, as well as number, of Experiments to obviate, as far as may be, the differing Objections and Evaions wherewith a Truth o paradoxical may expect to be encountred.

div.head: New EXPERIMENTS, To make FIRE and FLAME PONDERABLE.
div.p: THough there be among the following Tryals a Diverity that invites me, as to rank them into four or five differing orts, o to aign them as many ditinct Sections; yet for the conveniency of making the References, there will be occaion to make betwixt them, I hall wave the Ditinction, and et them down in one continued Series.

And becaue I am willing to comply with my hat, as well as to deal frankly and without Ceremony with you, I hall venture to ubjoyn the naked Trancripts of my Experiments, as I had in an artles manner
et them down with many others for my own remembrance among my Adveraria, without o much as retrenching ome Circumtances that relate les to my preent Argument, than to ome other purpoes.

I hall then begin with the mention of a couple of Experiments, which though they might conveniently enough be referr'd to another Paper; yet I hall here et them down, becaue it eems very proper to endeavour to hew in the firt place, that Flame it-elf may be as 'twere incorporated with cloe and olid Bodies o as to increae their bulk and weight.

div.head: EXPERIMENT I.
div.p:
[A Piece of Copper-plate not near o thick as a Half-crown, and weighing two Drachmes and twenty-five Grains, was o plac'd with its broad part Horizontal, in a Crucible, whoe bottom had a little hole in it, for Fumes to get out at, that it could not be removed from its Poition, nor be eaily made to drop down or loe its Level to the Horizon, though the Crucible were turned upide down: Then about an Ounce and half of common Sulphur being put into a taller and broader Crucible, that, wherein the Copper tuck, was inverted into the orifice of it, that the Sulphur being kindled, the flame, but not the melted Brimtone in ubtance, might reach the Plate, and have ome vent beyond it at the above-mentioned hole.
This Brimtone burn'd about two Hours, in which time it eem'd all to have been reolved into Flame, no flowers of Sulphur appearing to have ublimed into the inide of the upper Crucible; and though the Copperplate were at a coniderable ditance from the ignited Sulphur, yet the Flame eem'd to have really penetrated it, and to have made it viibly well or grow thicker; which appear'd to be done by a real acceion of ubtance: ince, after we had wip'd off ome little adhering ordes, and with them divers particles of Copper that tuck cloe to them, the Plate was found to weigh near two and thirty Grains more than at firt, and conequently to have increaed its former weight by above a fifth part.]

div.head: EXPER. II.
div.p:
[Having, by refining one Ounce of terling Silver with Salt-peter, according to our way reduc'd it to even Drachms or omewhat les;
we took a piece of the thus purified Silver, that weighed one Drachm wanting two Grains, and having order'd it as the Copper-plate had been in the former Experiment, after the flame of above one Ounce and a quarter of Sulphur, (that Quantity chancing to be uitable to the Capacity of the Crucible) had for about an Hour and a half beat upon it, the Silver-plate eem'd to the Eye omewhat well'd, and the lower urface of it, that was next the flame, was brought to a great moothnes, the weight being increas'd to one Drachm five Grains and three quarters; which increae of weight falling o hort of that which was gain'd by the Copper, I leave it to you to conider, whether the difference may be attributed to the cloenes and compactnes of the Silver, argued by its being heavier in pecie than Copper; or to the greater congruity of the pores of Copper to be wrought on by the fiery Mentruum; or to ome other caue.]

If you hould here ask me, by what Rational inducements I could be led to entertain o extravagant an expectation, as that uch a light and ubtile Body as Flame hould be able to give an augmentation of weight to uch ponderous Bodies as Minerals and Metals; I hall now, to avoid making anticipations here, or needles repetitions hereafter, return you only this Anwer: That the expectation you wonder at may jutly be entertained upon the ame or uch like inducements, as you may eaily dicover in another Paper, entitled Corollarium Paradoxum. For, uppoing upon the grounds there laid, that Flame may act upon ome Bodies as a Mentruum, it eems no way incredible, that, as almot all other Mentruums, o Flame hould have ome of its own Particles united with thoe of the Bodies expos'd to its action: And the generality of thoe Particles being, (as 'tis hewn in the Paradox about the Fewel of Flames,) either Saline, or of ome
uch piercing and Terretrial nature, 'tis no wonder, that being wedg'd into the Pores, or being brought to adhere very fat to the little Parts of the Bodies expos'd to their action, the acceion of o many little Bodies, that want not gravity, hould, becaue of their multitude, be coniderable upon a Ballance, whereon one or two, or but few of thee Corpucles would have no viible Effect.

I could here, if it were expedient, mention ome odd cruples about the preceding Experiments, and ome alo of the ubequent; but, let you hould, with ome other of my Friends, upbraid me with being too jealous and Sceptical, I will not trouble you with them; but proceed to the next ort of Tryals, wherein, though the matter were not always manifetly beaten on by a hining Flame; yet it was wrought on by that, which would be called Flame by thoe who take not that word trictly, but in a latitude, and which this Igneous ubtance may more properly be tiled,
than it can be call'd common Fire, this being viibly harbour'd in burning Coals or other gros materials, from which our Metals were fenc'd. And I have elewhere hewn by experiment, that Viibility is not in all caes neceary to Actual Flame, particularly when the Eye receives a predominant impreion from another Light.

div.head: EXPER. III.
div.p: INto a Crucible, whoe ides had been purpoely taken down to make it very hallow, was put one Ounce of Copper-plates; and this being put into our Cupelling-furnace, and kept there two Hours, and then being taken out we weighed the Copper (which had not been melted) having firt blown off all the ahes, and we found it to weigh one Ounce and thirty Grains.

div.head: EXPER. IV.
div.p: [Suppoing that Copper, being reduc'd to filings, and thereby gaining more of Superficies in proportion to its bulk, would be more expos'd to the Action of the Fire, than when 'tis in places as it was formerly; we took one Ounce of that Metal in filings, and putting them upon a very hallow Crucible, and under a Muffler, we kept them there about three Hours, (whilt other things that required o long a time were Cupelling;) and afterwards taking them off, we found them of a very dark colour, not melted but caked together in one Lump, and increas'd in weight (the ahes and dut being blown off) no les than about fortynine Grains. Part of which increment, above that obtained by the Copper-plates in the former Experiment, may not improbably be due to the longer time that in this Experiment the fil'd Copper was kept in the Fire.]

div.head: EXPER. V.
div.p:
[Being willing to ee, whether calcin'd Harts-horn, that I did not find eaie to be wrought on by corroive Mentruums, would retain any thing of the Flame or Fire to which it hould be expos'd; we weigh'd out one Ounce of mall Lumps of Hartshorn, that had been burnt till they appear'd white, and having put them into a Crucible, and kept them in a Cupelling-furnace for two Hours, whilt ome Metals were driving off there by the violence of the Fire; we found, that when they were taken out, they had lot ix or even Grains of their former weight; perhaps either becaue, notwithtanding the external whitenes of the Lumps, the internal Parts of ome of them might not be o exquiitely calcin'd, but retain ome Oleaginous or other Volatile Subtance or, becaue, having omitted to ignite them well before they were weigh'd, they may have
ince their firt Calcination imbib'd ome moit Particles of the Air. Which conjecture eem'd the likelier, becaue, having kept them a while in the Scales they were weigh'd in, they did within two or three Hours make it omewhat preponderate. On which occaion I hall add, that, at the ame time, with the Harts-horn we put in one Ounce of well-heated Brick, and kept that likewie in the Furnace for above two Hours; at the end of which weighing it whilt it continued hot, we did not find it to have either enibly got or lot; but, ome time after, it eem'd upon the Ballance to have imbib'd ome, though but very little, moiture from the Air.]

div.head: EXPER. VI.
div.p:
[Upon a good Cupel we put one Ounce of Englih Tin of the better ort, and having plac'd it in the Furnace under a Muffler, though it preently melted, yet it did not forake
its place, but remain'd upon the concave urface of the Cupel, till at the end of about two Hours it appear'd to have been well calcin'd; and then being taken out and weighed by it elf, the Ounce of Metal was found to have gained no les than a Drachm.]

div.head: EXPER. VII.
div.p: [An Ounce of Lead was put upon the Cupel, made of calcin'd Harts-horn, and placed under the Muffler after that the Cupel was firt made hot and then weighed. This Lead did not enter into the Cupel, but was turn'd into a pretty kind of Litharge on the top of it, and broke the Cupel, whereby ome part of the Cupel was lot in the Furnace, and yet the ret, together with the Litharge, weigh'd even Grains more than the Ounce of Lead and the heated Cupel did when they were put in.]

But becaue, though this tryal hew'd that ome weight was gain'd either by the Metal or Cupel, or both;
yet it did not by this appear, what either of them acquir'd; it eem'd fit to ubjoyn a further tryal.

div.head: EXPER. VIII.
div.p:
[We took a Cupel about two Ounces in weight, made of about ten parts of Bone-ahes, and one of Charcoal-ahes, made up together with Ale. This was by it elf put in a Cupelling-furnace, under a Muffler; and the Laborant, well vers'd in weighing, was order'd to take it out, when 'twas throughly and highly heated, and to weigh it whilt 'twas in that condition (I being then preent:) This being done, 'twas forthwith plac'd again under the Muffler, where ome Metalline Bodies were Cupelling, and kept there for about two Hours; at the end of which time 'twas taken out red-hot, and preently put into the ame Ballance, as before, which was already fatned to a Gibbet; where having caus'd the adhering ahes to be blown off,
I found, that whereas, when 'twas firt taken from under the Muffler, we had but two Ounces and two Grains, now the ame weight being put into the oppoite Scale, it had gain'd very near one and twenty Grains. And here note, that 'twas not without ome caue, that I was careful to have the Cupel weighed red-hot. For I had a upition, that, notwithtanding the drynes of the Bone, it might receive ome little alteration of weight by imbibing ome little Particles wandering in the Air; which upition the event jutified. For leaving the Cupel counterpois'd to cool in the Ballance, in a hort time it began enibly to preponderate; and uffering it to continue there nine or ten hours, till we had occaion to ue the Ballance, I found it at the end of that time to be about three Grains heavier than before.]

This was not the only tryal we made about the augmenting the weight of Cupels; but this being the fairet, and exempt from thoe
michances, from which the other were not altogether free; I hall content my elf to have et down this: In the mention of which I thought fit to take notice of the increae of the weight of the Cupel after it had layn in the Scales, and alo that we weighed it at firt whilt it was throughly hot, becaue thoe Circumtnces, as not being upected, may eaily be left unthought on, even by skilful Experimenters; and yet the weighing of the Cupel, when it had been well neal'd, and the not weighing it oon enough after 'tis taken from the Fire, may keep thoe, that hall reiterate this Experiment, from making it cautiouly and accurately enough. For if the former Circumtance be omitted, that which the Cupel may eem to have lot of its ubtance, was nothing but the adventitious moiture of the Air; and if the later Circumtance be neglected, the weight, it may eem to have gain'd from the Fire, was indeed due to the waterih Particles of the Air. I could
wih alo, that tryal were made, whether the ucces would be the ame in Cupels made in differing orts of Bone-ahes, and other materials, wont to be employed for that purpoe. For That I had not opportunity to do.

div.head: EXPER. IX.
div.p: Iron being a Metal, that experience had inform'd me will more eaily be wrought on by Fluids that have Particles of a Saline nature in them, than is commonly believed; 'twas not unreaonable to expect, that Flame would have a greater Operation on it, (epecially if it were before-hand reduc'd to mall Parts) than on any of the Bodies hitherto decrib'd. Which uppoition will be confirm'd by the hort enuing Note.
[Four Drachms of filings of Steel being kept two Hours on a Cupel under a Muffler, acquir'd one Drachm ix Grains and a quarter increae of weight.]

div.head: EXPER. X.
div.p: [A piece of Silver, refin'd in our own Laboratory, being put upon a Cupel under a Muffler, and kept there for an hour and half, whilt other things were refining, was taken out and weigh'd again, and, whereas before it weighed three Drachms, thirty-two Grains and a quarter, it now weighed in the ame Scales three Drachms, thirty-four Grains and a half, or but little les.]

Finding this Memorial among divers others about the Weight of Bodies, expos'd to the Fire, I thought it not amis to annex it in this place; though finding it to be but ingle, I would not have it to be rely'd on till further tryal have been made to dicover, whether it was more than a caual and anomalous Experiment; and if the Silver had not been refin'd, I hould have upected, that the Copper, that was blended with it, as 'tis uually blended with common
Silver, might have occaioned the increaed of weight.

div.head: (Potcript.)
div.p: Since the foregoing Experiment was firt et down, meeting with an opportunity to reiterate the tryal once more, we did it with half an Ounce of filings of Silver, well refin'd with Lead in our own Laboratory, and kept it about three hours upon the Cupel; after the end of which time taking it out, we found it to be of a les pleaant colour than it was of before, and melted (though not o perfectly) into a Lump, which weigh'd four Drachms and ix Grains; and yet, the ucces being o odd, and, if it prove contant, of uch moment, I could wih the tryal were further repeated in differing quantities of the Metal.

div.head: EXPER. XI.
div.p:
[We took a Drachm of filings of Zink or Spelter, and having put it
upon a Cupel under a Muffler, we kept it there in a Cupelling-fire about three Hours, (having occaion to continue the Cupellation o long for other tryals;) then taking it off the Cupel, we found it to be caked into a brittle and dark-colour'd Lump, which look'd as if the filings had been calcin'd. This being weigh'd in the ame Scales gain'd full ix Grains, and o a tenth part of its firt weight.]

div.head: EXPER. XII.
div.p: Among our various tryals upon common Metals, we thought fit to make one or two upon a Metal brought us from the Eat-Indies, and there call'd Tutenâg, which name being unknown to our European Chymits, I have elewhere endeavoured to give ome account of the Metal it elf; whence I hall borrow the enuing Note, as directly belonging to our preent purpoe.

[Two Drachms of filings of Tutenâg
being put upon a Cupel, and kept under the Muffler for about two hours, the filings were not melted into a Lump of Metal, but look'd as if Cerus and Minium being pouder'd had been mingled together; ome of the parts appearing ditinctly white; and others red: The Calx being put into the Ballance appear'd to have gained twenty-eight Grains and a quarter. Another time the Experiment being reiterated with the like Circumtances, we found, that two Drachms of the filed Tutenâg gained the like increae of weight, abating les than one Grain.]
So that this Indian Metal eems to have gain'd more in the fire, in proportion to its weight, than any we have hitherto made tryal of.

div.head: EXPER. XIII.
div.p:
[Being deirous to confirm by a clear Experiment, what I elewhere deliver contrary to the vulgar Opinion of thoe that believe, that in all Cupellations almot all the Lead
that is employ'd about them, does, together with the baer Metals that are to be purg'd off from the Silver or Gold, fly away in Smoak, as indeed in ome ort of Cupellations a good proportion may be blown off that way: We took two Ounces of good Lead and one Drachm of filings of Copper, and having caus'd a Cupel to be ignited, and nimbly taken out of the Furnace, and weighed, whilt 'twas very hot, 'twas preently put back, together with the two Metals laid on it, into the Cupelling-furnace, where having been kept for about two hours, it was taken out again, and 'twas found, according to what (as I elewhereEay the ixth of the Ueful. of Nat. Philo. note) ues to happen in uch Circumtances, to have nothing on the urface of it worth weighing ditinctly in the Scales, in which the Cupel with what was unk into it amounted to four Ounces three Drachms and eleven Grains, which wanted but nine Grains of the whole weight of
the Cupel and the two Metals, when they were all three together committed to the Fire.] So that, though we make a liberal allowance for the increment of weight that may with any probability be uppoed to have been attained by the Cupel and what was put upon it, yet it will eaily be granted, that very much the greater part of the Metals was not driven off in Fumes, but enter'd into the Subtance of the Cupel.

div.head: Tryals of the Third ort.
div.p:
AFter having hewn that either Flame or the Analogous Effluxions of the Fire will be, what Chymits would call, Corporified with Metals and Minerals expoed naked to its action; I thought it would be a deirable thing to dicover, whether this Flame or igneous Fluid were ubtile enough to exercie any uch Operation upon the Light Bodies helter'd from its immediate
contact by being included in cloe Veels; but it being very difficult to expoe Bodies in Glaes to uch vehement Fires without breaking or melting the Glas, and thereby loing the Experiment; I thought fit, firt to employ Crucibles carefully luted together, that nothing might viibly get in or out, and of that attempt I find among my Notes the following Account.

div.head: EXPER. XIV.
div.p: [We took an Ounce of Steel frehly filed from a Lump of that Metal, that the filings might not be ruty, and having included them betwixt two Crucibles, as formerly, kept them for two hours in a trong Fire, and uffer'd them to continue there till the Fire went out; the Crucibles being unluted, the filings appear'd hard caked together, and had acquir'd a dark colour omewhat between black and blew, and were increas'd five Grains in weight.]
The foregoing Experiment being the firt I mention of this kind, 'twill not be amis to confirm it by annexing the following Memorial.

[An Ounce of filings of Steel being put between the Crucibles luted together, after they had been kept about an hour and half in the fire, were taken out, and being weigh'd, were found to have gained ix Grains.]

div.head: EXPER. XV.
div.p:
[Two Ounces of Copper-plate were put into a new Crucible, over which a leer was whelmed, and the commiures were cloed with lute, that nothing might fall in. After the ame manner two Ounces of Tin were included betwixt Crucibles, and alo two Ounces of Lead; thee being put into the Cupellingfurnace were kept in a trong Fire about an hour and a half, while omething ele was trying there. And then being taken out, the event was, that the Copper-plates, though they
tuck together, were not quite melted, and eem'd ome of them to have acquir'd cales like Copper put into a naked Fire, and the two Ounces had gain'd eight Grains in weight. The Lead had broke through the bottom of the Crucible, and thereby hinder'd the deign'd Obervation. The Tin acquir'd ix Grains in weight, and was in part brought to a pure white Calx, but much more of it was melted into a Lump of a fine yellow colour, almot like Gold, but deeper.] The proecution of this tryal as to the Copper-plates you will meet with in Experim. XXI. to which I therefore referr you.

N. B. Becaue Lead in Cupellation enters the Cupel, we were willing to try, if we could o far hinder it from doing o, as to make ome etimate what change of Weight the Operation of the Fire would make in it: And therefore being able already to make a near gues, how much a quantity of Tin may gain by being calcined on a Cupel, and
remembring alo from ome of my former tryals the indipoition which Tin gives Lead to Cupellation, we mixed a Drachm of Tin with two Ounces of Lead, and expoing the mixture (in a Cupel) to the Fire under a Muffler, we firt brought it to fuion, and then it eem'd at the top dry and well'd and dicolour'd; notwithtanding which, having continued the Operation a good while, becaue of other things that were to be done with the ame Fire, we were not lucky enough to bring the Experiment to an iue worth the relating here, in reference to the cope above-propos'd, though in relation to another the ucces was welcome enough.]

div.head: EXPER. XVI.
div.p:
[Suppoing that if Copper were beaten into thinner plates than thoe we lately us'd, and kept longer in the fire, this would have a more coniderable Operation upon them, we
took one Ounce of very thinly hammer'd pieces of Copper, and putting them betwixt two Crucibles (one whelm'd over another) as in Experim. XV. with ome lute at the corners of the juncture, to keep the fire from coming immediately at the Metal, we kept them in the Cupelling-furnace about three hours, and then disjoyning the Veels, we found the Metal covered with a dark and brittle ubtance, like that decrib'd in the above recited Experiment. Which ubtance, when cal'd off, diclos'd a finely colour'd Metal, which, together with thee burnt cales, amounted to one and twenty Grains above the weight that was firt put in.]

If, when thee things were doing, I had been furnihed with a very good Lute, which is no uch eaie thing to procure, as Chymits, that have not frequently employed vulgar Lutes, are wont to think; I would have made a tryal of the enuing Experiment for a good while in the naked Fire, notwithtanding that
divers Metalline Minerals will carce be brought to fuion in Glaes, epecially without uch a Fire, whoe violence makes them break the Veels. For I thought, that by making a fit choice of the Metals to be employed, I could prevent that inconvenience: But wanting the Accommodations I deir'd, and yet preuming, that in a Sand-furnace I might by degrees adminiter heat enough to melt o fuible a Metal as fine Tin, and keep it in fuion; I reolved to make ome tryals, firt upon that, and then upon another Metal. For though I was not ure of being then able to proecute the Experiment far enough; yet I hoped, I might at leat ee ome Effects of my firt tryal, which would enable me to gues, what I was to expect from a complete one.

div.head: EXPER. XVII.
div.p:
[We took then a piece of fine Block-Tin, and in a pair of good Scales weighed out carefully half a
Pound of it; this we put into a choice Glas-retort, and kept it for two days or thereabouts in a Sandfurnace, which gave heat enough to keep the Metal in fuion without cracking the Glas. Then taking out the mixture, we carefully weigh'd it in the ame Scales, and found the uperficies a little alter'd (as if it were dipos'd to calcination) and the weight to be increaed about two Grains or omewhat better.]

div.head: EXPER. XVIII.
div.p:
[The other Experiment, I tryed in Glaes, was with Mercury, hoping, that, if I could make a Precipitate per e in a Hermetically eal'd Glas, I hould by comparing the weight of the Precipitate, and the Quick-ilver that afforded it, have a clear Experiment to my purpoe; and I hould have no bad one, if I could but make it ucceed with a Glas, though not eal'd, yet well top'd; intead of thoe Infernal-glaes (as
they call them) which are commonly us'd and wont to be left open (though ome lightly top them with a little Paper or Cotton:) But though, partly that I might a little diverifie the Experiment, and make it the more likely to ucceed in one or other of the Glaes, I divided the Mercury and ditributed it amongt everal of them, and but a little to each, the ucces did not anwer expectation, the Hermetically eal'd Glaes being unluckily broken; and the Precipitation in the others proceeding o lowly, that I was by a remove oblig'd to leave the tryal imperfect; only I was encouraged, (in cae of a future opportunity) to renew it another time, by finding that mot of the Glaes, though tall, and top'd with fit Corks, afforded ome very fair Precipitate, but not enough to anwer my Deign.]

div.head: Tryals of the Fourth ort.
div.p:
MOt of the Experiments hitherto recited, having been made as it were upon the by with others, whoe exigencies 'twas fit thee hould comply with; very few of the expos'd Bodies were kept in the Cupelling-fire above two hours or thereabouts. Upon which account I thought fit to try, how much ome Bodies, that had been already expos'd to the Fire, would gain in weight by being again expos'd to it; epecially conidering, that mot calcinable Bodies, (for I affirm it not of all) which yield rather calces than ahes by being without additament reduc'd in the Fire to fine powder, eem'd to be by that Operation open'd, or (as a Chymit would peak) unlock'd, and therefore probably capable of being further wrought upon and increas'd in weight by uch a Mentruum as I uppos'd Flame and igneous Exhalations
to be. And about this Conjecture I hall ubjoyn the enuing Tryals.

div.head: EXPER. XIX.
div.p: [One Ounce of Calx of Tin, that had been made per e for an Experiment in our own Laboratory, being put in a new Cupel and kept under the Muffler for about two hours, was taken out hot and put into the Scales, where the powder appear'd to have gain'd in weight one Drachm and thirty-five Grains by the operation of the Fire, which made it alo look much whiter than it did before, as appeared by comparing it with ome of the Calx that had not been expoed to the econd Fire: No part of the Puttie was, as we could perceive, melted by the vehemence of the Fire, much les reduc'd into Metal.]

div.head: EXPER. XX.
div.p: [Out of a parcel of filings of Steel, that had been before expos'd to the fire and had its weight thereby increas'd ome Grains, not Scruples; we took an Ounce, and having expos'd it at the ame time with the Calx of Tin, and, for the ame time, kept it in the Fire, we took it out at the two hours end; and found the weight to be increas'd two Drachms and two and twenty Grains. The filings were very hard bak'd together, and, the Lump being broken, looked almot like Iron.]

div.head: EXPER. XXI.
div.p:
The following Experiment, though it may eem in one regard but a Continuation of the XV th; yet it has in this omething peculiar from all the foregoing, that not only it affords an intance of the increae of Weight obtain'd by a Metal at the econd
time of its being expos'd to the fire, but hews alo, that uch an increment may be had, though this econd ignition be made in cloe Veels.]

[Some of the Copper mention'd in Experim. XV. being accidentally lot, one Ounce and four Drachms of what remain'd was included betwixt two Crucibles and expos'd to a trong fire for two hours, and uffer'd to continue there till the fire went out: When it was taken out, it appear'd to have gain'd ten Grains in weight, and to have upon the uperficial parts of the Plates (as we oberv'd) divers dark colour'd flakes, ome of which tuck to the Metal, but more, upon handling it, fell off.]

And here I hall conclude One of the Two Parts of our deigned Treatie: For, though I remember, that thee were not all the Tryals that were made and et down upon the Subject hitherto treated of; yet thee are the chief, that having ecaped the michances, which befel ome
others, I can meet with among my promicuous Memorials; whoe number, when I drew them together, I could carce increae, having by all thee and other Tryals of differing kinds wated my Cupels and commodious Glaes, where I could not well repair my los. Whether I hould have been able by Reduction, pecifick Gravity, or any other of the ways, which I had in my thoughts, to make any dicovery of the Nature of the Subtance that made the Increment of Weight in our Ignited Bodies; the want as well of leiure, as of accommodations requiite to go through with o difficult a task, keeps me from pretending to know. But thee three things, I hope, I may have gained by what has been deliver'd. The Firt, That we hall henceforth ee caue to proceed more warily in the Experiments we make with Metals in the Fire, epecially by Cupellation. The next, That it will jutifie and perhaps procure an eaier aent to ome paages in my
other Writings, that have Relation to the Subtance, what-ever it be, that we are peaking of. And the third, (which is the principal,) That it will probably excite you, and your inquiitive Friends, to exercie their agacious Curioity, in dicovering what kind of Subtance that is, which, though hitherto overeen by Philoophers themelves, and, being a Fluid, far more ubtile than viible Liquors, and able to pierce into the Compact and Solid Bodies of Metals, can yet add omething to them, that has no depicable Weight upon the Ballance, and is able for a coniderable time to continue fixt in the Fire.

div.head: Additional Experiments, ABOUT ARRESTING and WEIGHING OF Igneous Corpucles.
div.p:
EXperiments to dicover the Increae in Weight of Bodies, though inclos'd in Glaes, being thoe that I conidered as likeliet to anwer what I deign'd in the hitherto proecuted Attempt, and finding the eventeenth Experiment as well as the next (try'd upon Mercury) to be very low, and its performance not to be very great, I began to call to mind, what, many years ago, Experience had hewn me poible to be perform'd, as to the managing Glas-veels, even without coating them, in a naked Fire,
provided a wary peron were contantly employ'd to watch them. And uppoing hereupon, that, in no longer time than a Laborant might, without being tir'd, hold out to attend a Glas, a Metal expos'd in it to a naked fire might afford us a much more properous tryal than that lately referr'd to, I afterwards reolv'd, when I hould be able to procure ome Glaes conveniently hap'd, to proecute my Deign; in puruance of which though I had not any Furnaces fitted for my purpoe, I directed a Laborant to make the following Tryals.

div.head: EXPER. I.
div.p:
[We took eight Ounces (Troy weight) of Block-Tin, which being cut into bits was put into a good round Vial with a long neck, and then warily held over quick Coals without touching them till it was melted; after which it was kept almot continually haken, to promote the Calcination, near an hour, the
Metal being all the while in fuion, and the Glas kept at ome ditance from the throughly kindled Coals. The mot part of this time the orifice of the Vial was cover'd with a Cap of Paper (which ometimes fell off by moving the Glas) to keep the Air and Steams of the Coals from getting into the neck. And at the end of this time, he that held the Glas being tir'd, and having his Hand almot corch'd, the Vial being remov'd from the fire was broken, that we might take out the Metalline Lump, which had a little darkih Calx here and there upon the upper urface, but much more beneath, where it had been contiguous to the bottom of the Glas; then putting all this carefully freed from little fragments of broken Glas into the ame Ballance with the elf-ame counterpoie I had us'd before, I found, according to my Expectation, an increae of weight, which amounted to eighteen Grains, that the Tin had acquir'd by this Operation.]

div.head: EXPER. II.
div.p:
[This done we eparated the Calx for fear of loing it, and having melted the Metal in a Crucible, that by pouring it out it might be reduc'd to thin Plates capable of being cut in pieces, and put into uch another Vial as the lat; we weigh'd it again together with the •• tely reerv'd Calx, but found, that, notwithtanding all our oare, we had lot three Grains of the eighteen we had gain'd. This done we put the Metal into another Vial. But in regard the neck was horter than that of the former, and could not like it be long held in ones Hand; and becaue alo I was willing to ee what Interet the haking of melted Tin has in the quicknes of the Calcination, the Glas, which had a topple of Paper put to it to keep out Smoak and Air, was held at ome ditance from the Coals, only whilt the Tin was melting; and then was warily laid
upon them and kept there for two hours, at the end of which 'twas again taken off, and the Metal weigh'd with the ame Counterpoie and Ballance as formerly; and then it appear'd to amount to eight Ounces twenty-four Grains, and to have much more eparable Calx than at the firt time. Nor did I much wonder, that the weight hould be increas'd in this lat Operation but nine Grains in two hours, and in the former twice o many in half the time; ince, during the two hours, the Glas was kept in one poture, whereas in the firt Operation, it was almot perpetually haken all the while 'twas kept in fuion. And 'tis oberv'd, that the agitation of melted Minerals will much promote the Effect of the Fire upon them, and conduce to their Calcination.]

div.head: EXPER. III.
div.p:
Though thee Tryals might well atisfie a peron not very crupulous,
yet to convince even thoe that are o, I undertook, in pite of the difficulties of the Attempt, to make the Experiment in Glaes Hermetically eal'd, to prevent all upition of any acceion of Weight accruing to the Metal from any Smoak or Saline Particles getting in at the mouth of the Veel. And in proecution of this deign I thought upon a way of o Hermetically ealing a Retort, that it might be expos'd to a naked fire without being either crackt or burt; an Account of which Tryal was thus et down.

[Eight Ounces of good Tin carefully weigh'd out was Hermetically eal'd up in a new mall Retort with a long neck, by which 'twas held in ones Hand, and warily approach'd to a kindled Charcoal-fire, near which the Metal was kept in fuion, being alo ever now and then haken for almot half an hour, in which time it eem'd to have acquir'd on the urface uch a dark colour as argued a beginning of Calcination, and it
both emitted Fumes that play'd up and down, and alo afforded two or three drops of Liquor in the neck of the Retort. The Laborant being not able to hold the Glas any longer, 'twas laid on quick Coals, where the Metal continued above a quarter of an hour longer in fuion; but before the time was come that I intended to uffer it to cool in order to the removing it, it uddenly broke in a great multitude of pieces, and with a noie like the Report of a Gun; but (thanks be to God) it did no harm neither to me nor others that were very near it. In the neck we found ome drops of a yellowih Liquor, which a Virtuoo that tated it affirm'd to be of an odious but peculiar Sapor; and as for the Smell, I found it to be very tinking, and not unlike that of the ditill'd Oyl of Fih.]
But, though our firt Attempt of this kind had thus micarried, we were not thereby dicourag'd, but in proecution of the ame deign made the enuing Tryal.

div.head: EXPER. IV.
div.p:
[The Tin which had been before (in the firt or ome uch Experiment) partly calcin'd in a Glas, being melted again in a Crucible, that it might be reduc'd to pieces mall enough to be put into another Glas, was put again into the Scales, and the urpluage being laid aide, that there might remain jut eight Ounces; thee were put into a Bolt-head of white Glas with a neck of about twenty Inches long, which being Hermetically eal'd (after the Glas had been a while kept over the fire, let that hould break by the rarefaction of the Air,) the Metal was kept in fuion for an hour and a quarter, as (being hinder'd by a Company of trangers from being there my elf) the Laborant affirm'd. Being unwilling to venture the Glas any longer, it was taken from the fire, and when 'twas grown cold, the eal'd end was broken off; but before
I would have the bottom cut out, I oberv'd, that the upper urface of the Metal was very darkly colour'd, and not at all mooth, but much and very odly aperated; and the lower part had between the bottom and the lower part of the Lump a pretty deal of looe dark-colour'd Calx, though the neighbouring urface and ome places of the Lump it elf look'd by Candle-light (it being then Night) of a golden Colour. The Lump and Calx together were weigh'd in the ame Scales carefully, and we found the weight to have increas'd twenty-three Grains and better, though all the Calx, we could eaily eparate, being weigh'd by it elf amounted not to four Scruples or eighty Grains.]
For Confirmation of this Experiment I hall ubjoyn another, wherein but a quarter of o much Metal was employed with uch ucces as the annexed Memorial declares.

div.head: EXPER. V.
div.p:
[Two Ounces of filings of Tin were carefully weigh'd and put into a little Retort, whoe neck was afterwards drawn lenderly out into a very mall Apex; then the Glas was plac'd on kindled Coals, which drove out fumes at the mall orifice of the neck for a pretty while. Afterwards the Glas; being eal'd up at the Apex, was kept in the fire above two hours; and then being taken off was broken at the ame Apex; whereupon I heard the outward Fire ruh in, becaue when the Retort was eal'd the Air within it was highly rarified. Then the body of the Glas being broken, the Tin was taken out, coniting of a Lump, about which there appear'd ome gray Calx and ome very mall globuls, which eem'd to have been filings melted into that form. The whole weigh'd two Ounces twelve Grains, the later part of which weight appear'd to have been gain'd by the Operation of the Fire on the
Metal. In the neck of the Retort, where it was joyn'd to the body, there appear'd a yellowih and clammy ubtance thinly pread, which melt almot like the foetid Oyl of Tartar.]

div.head: EXPER. VI.
div.p: To vary the foregoing Experiments by making Tryals on a Mineral that is held to be of a very Metalline nature, but is not a true Metal, nor will be brought to fuion by o moderate a Heat as will uffice to melt Tin, and yet has parts les fixt than Tin, as being far more eaily ublimable, we thought fit to make the following Experiment.

[We took an Ounce of filings of Zinke carefully weigh'd, and having as carefully put them into a round Bolt-glas, we caus'd the neck to be drawn out very lender, and then order'd the Laborant to keep it upon quick Coals for the appointed time. Afterwards returning home, I call'd for the Glas, which he aid he had
kept four hours upon the Coals; anwering me alo, that there did for a great part of the time Smoak appear to acend from the Zink and get out at the untopt Apex. And in effect I oberv'd, that the upper part of the Glas was lin'd with Flores or Sublimate of a darkih gray. The Glas being dextrouly cut aunder, we took out not only the filings of Zinke, ome of which were melted into little globuls, but the Flores too, and yet weighing all thee in the ame Scales, we had us'd before, we found five Grains and omewhat better wanting of an Ounce. Which we the les wonder'd at, becaue of the continuance of the lately mention'd Exhalations emitted by the filed Mineral.]

div.head: EXPER. VII.
div.p:
For more ample confirmation of the truth dicover'd by what I have been reciting about Tin, I thought fit to try the like Experiment upon another Metal, which though of
omewhat more difficult fuion than Tin, I had reaon to think might, if employed in a moderate quantity, and warily managed, be kept melted in Glas without breaking it. And accordingly having carefully weigh'd out four Ounces of good Lead cut before-hand into pieces little enough for the orifice of the Glas, I caued them to be put into a mall Retort with a long neck, wherein was afterwards left but an orifice not much bigger than a pins head: Then leaving directions with the Laborant what to do, becaue I was my elf call'd abroad, at my return he brought me together with the Glas, this Account: That he had kept it over and upon the Coals two hours, or better, and then uppoing the danger of breaking the Glas was over, he had ealed it up at the little Orifice newly mention'd, and kept it on the Coals two hours longer. Before the Glas (which I found to be well eal'd) was broken, I perceived the pieces of Lead to have been melted into a Lump, whoe
urface was dark and rugged, and part of the Metal to have been turn'd into a dark-colour'd Powder or Calx: All this being taken out of the Retort, was weigh'd in the ame Ballance, whereon the Lead appear'd to have gain'd by the Operation omewhat above thirteen Grains.

div.head: EXPER. VIII.
div.p: To hew that Metals are not the only Bodies that are capable of receiving an increae of Weight from the Fire, I thought fit to make upon Coral a tryal, whereof my Memorial gives me this Account.

[Little bits of good red Coral being Hermetically eal'd up in a thin bubble of Glas, after two Drachms of them had been weigh'd out in a pair of nice Scales, were warily kept at everal times over and upon kindled Coals, and at length being taken out for good and all, were found of a very dark Colour, and to have gain'd in weight three Grains and about a half.]

div.head: EXPER. IX.
div.p:
One Experiment there is, which, though it might have come in more properly at another place, is not to be omitted in this becaue it may invite us to conider, whether in the foregoing Experiments, excepting thoe made on Lead and Tin in eal'd Veels, there may not be more of the Fire adherent to or incorporated with the Body expos'd to it, than one would conclude barely from the recited Increments of their Weight. For having taken very trong freh Quick-lime provided on purpoe for choice Experiments, and expos'd it, before the Air had time to lake it, upon the Cupel, to a trong fire where it was kept for two hours; I found that it had increas'd in weight even omewhat beyond my expectation: For being eaonably put into the Ballance, the Lumps that weigh'd, when expos'd, but two Drachms, amounted to two
Drachms and twenty-nine Grains; which makes this Experiment a pregnant one to our purpoe. For by this it appears, that notwithtanding a Body may for many hours, or even for ome days, be expos'd to a very violent Fire, yet it may be till capable of admitting and retaining freh Corpucles; o that, though well made Lime be uually oberv'd to be much lighter than the Stones whereof 'tis made; yet this lightnes does not necearily prove, that, becaue a burnt Lime-tone has lot much of its matter by the Fire, it has therefore acquir'd no matter from the Fire; but only inferrs, that it has lot far more than it has got. And this may give ground to upect, that in mot of the foregoing tryals the acceion of the fiery Particles was greater (though in ome more, in others les o,) than the Ballance dicover'd; ince, for ought we know, divers of the les fixt Particles of the expos'd Body might be driven away by the vehemence of the Heat; and
conequently the Igneous Corpucles that fatned themelves to the remaining matter might be numerous enough, not only to bring the acceion of Weight that was found by the Scales, but to make amends for all the fugitive Particles, that had been expell'd by the violence of the Fire. And ince o fixt a Body as Quick-lime is capable of being wrought upon by the Igneous Effluvia, o as that they come to be as 'twere incorporated with it, it may perchance be worth conidering, whether in other calcin'd or incinerated Bodies the remaining Calces or Ahes may not retain more than the bare Impreion (unles that be tretch'd to mean ome participation of a ubtance,) of the Fire. Whether thee Particles that adhere to or are mingled with the tony ones of the Lime may have any thing to do in the Heat and tumult that is produc'd upon the laking of Lime, this is not a fit place to examine. And though by this Experiment and thoe made
in eal'd Retorts, which hew that what is afforded by Fire may in a Corporeal way invade, adhere and add Weight to even fixt and ponderous Bodies, there is a large Field open'd for the Speculative to apply this Dicovery to divers Phaenomena of Nature and Chymitry; yet I hall leave this Subject unmedled with in this place.
A DISCOVERY Of the PERVIOUSNESS OF GLASS TO PONDERABLE PARTS OF FLAME.
With ome Reflexions on it by way of COROLLARY.
Subjoyned as an Appendix to his Experiments about Arreting and Weighing of IGNEOUS CORPUSCLES, BY. The Honorable ROBERT BOYLE.
LONDON: Printed by W. G. for M. Pitt at the ign of the White Hart, over-againt the little North Door of St Paul's Church. 1673.

div.head: A DISCOVERY OF The Perviounes of GLASS TO Ponderable Parts of FLAME.
div.p:
THAT I might obviate ome needles cruples that may be entertain'd by upitious Wits upon this Circumtance of our Additional Experiments, That the Glaes employ'd about them were not expoed to the Action of mere Flame, but were held upon Charcoals, (which to ome may eem to contain but a Groer kind of Fire:) And that alo I might, by diverifying the way of tryal, render uch Experiments both more fit to afford Corollaries, and more erviceable to my other purpoes, I attempted to make it ucceed with a Body o thin and diingaged
from gros matter as mere Flame is allowed to be, knowing, that by going cautiouly with it to work, one might handle a Retort without breaking it, in pite of a violent agitation of kindled matter.

div.head: EXPER. I.
div.p:
Suppoing then that good common Sulphur by reaon of its great Inflammability and the vehemency and penetrancy of its Flame, would be a very fit fuel for my purpoe, I provided a mall double Veel o contrived, that the one hould contain as many Coals as was neceary to keep the Sulphur melted, and that the other, which was much maller, and hap'd like a Pan, hould contain the Brimtone requiite for our Tryal; and (latly,) that thee two hould be with a convenient Lute o joyned to one another, that all being clos'd at the top, ave the orifice of the little Pan, (the fire and moak of the Coals having their vent another
way,) no fire hould come at the Retort to be employed, but the flame of the burning Brimtone. Then two ounces of filings of Tin being heedfully weigh'd out, and put into a Glas-Retort provided for uch Tryals, and made fit to be eaily eal'd up at the neck, when the time hould be convenient, the Sulphur (which ought to be of the purer ort) was kindled, and the Glas by degrees expoed to it; where it continued, as the Laborant inform'd me, (the mell of Brimtone, peculiarly offenive to me, forbidding me to be preent,) near two hours before the Metal melted; after which he kept the Retort near an hour and half more with the Metal melted in it. Then bringing it me to look upon, I perceived a pretty deal of darkih Calx at the bottom, and partly too upon the urface of the far greater part of the Metal, which now lay in one Lump. The part of the Retort that had been eal'd being broken off, we firt took out the Calx, and then
the Lump, and putting them into the Scales, they had been formerly weigh'd in, found them to have made a very manifet acquit of weight, which, if both the Laborant and I be not mitaken, (for the paper, which hould inform us, is now miing) amounted to four grains and a half, gained by the recited Operation. Afterwards, we being grown more expert in making uch Tryals, the experiment was repeated with the ame quantity of filings of the ame Metal: At the end of the Operation, (which in all lated omewhat above three hours) having broken off the eal'd neck of the Retort, we found, that a good proportion of darkcolour'd Calx had been produc'd. This being weighed with the uncalcin'd part of the Metal, the two ounces we firt put in appear'd to have acquir'd no les than eleven grains and a half (and omewhat better.)

Such Supertructures, both for number and weight, may poibly
in time be built on this and the like Experiments, that I hall venture to obviate even uch a cruple as is like to be judg'd too Sceptical. But I remember, that, conidering upon occaion of ome of the Experiments formerly recited, that though it were very improbable, yet it did not appear impoible, that the increment of Weight, acquir'd by Bodies expos'd in Glas-veels to the Fire, might proceed, not from the Corpucles of Fire, but from the Particles of the Glas it elf, looened by the power of o intene a Heat, and forcibly driven into the inclos'd Body; I was content to take a couple of Glaes, whereof one was hap'd into a little Retort, and having weigh'd them, and then having kept them for a coniderable time upon kindled Coals, and then weigh'd them again, I could gather little of certainty from the Experiment, (the Retort at one time eeming to have acquir'd above half a grain in the fire,) ave that there was no likelihood at all, that
o coniderable an increae of weight, as we divers times obtain'd in cloe veels, hould proceed from the Glas it elf, and not from the Fire.

div.head: EXPER. II.
div.p:
Becaue it eems evident enough, that, whatever Chymits tell us of their Hypotatical Sulphur, common Brimtone is a body Heterogeneous enough, having in it ome parts of an oyly or inflammable nature, and others acid; and very near of kin to the Spirits of Vitriol; I thought fit to vary our Experiment, by making it with a liquor that is generally reputed to be as Homogeneous as Chymits themelves are wont to render any, I mean with a Spirit of Wine, or ome uch liquor as will totally flame away without affording Soot, or leaving any drop of Phlegm behind it. In proecution of this deign, we carefully weighed out an ounce of filings of Block-Tin, and put them into a Glas-Retort, fit for
the purpoe, whoe neck was afterwards drawn out to a great lendernes; and we alo provided a conveniently hap'd metalline Lamp, uch as that the flame of this ardent Spirit might commodiouly burn in it, and yet not melt nor crack it; which Lamp, though furnihed with a Cotton wick, afforded no Soot, becaue as long as it was upplied with liquor enough, it remained unburnt. Thee things being in readines, the Retort was warily approach'd to the flame, and the Metal was thereby in a hort time melted. After which the Glas being kept expos'd to the ame flame for near two hours in all, the eal'd apex of the Retort was broken off, and there appear'd to have been produc'd a not inconiderable Quantity of Calx, that lay looe about the remaining part of the Tin, which, upon its growing cold, was harden'd into a Lump. This, and the Calx, being taken out of the Retort with care, that no little fragment of Glas
hould at all impoe upon us, was weigh'd in the ame Scales as formerly, and found to have gain'd four grains and a half, beides the Dut that tuck in the inide of the Retort, of which we reckon'd enough to make about half a grain more; o that of o fine and pure a flame as of this totally ardent Spirit, enough to amount to five grains was arreted, and in good meaure fixt by its operation on the Tin it had wrought upon.

div.head: EXPER. III.
div.p:
For confirmation of the former tryal, wherein we had imployed the Spiritus ardens of Sugar, we made the like experiment with highly Rectified Spirit of Wine, only ubtituting an ounce of Lead intead of one of Tin. The event, in hort, was this; that after the Metal had been for two hours or better kept in the flame, the eal'd neck of the Retort being broken off, the external
Air ruh'd in with a noie, (which hew'd the Veel to have been very tight,) and we found pretty tore of the Lead; for 'twas above even cruples, turn'd into a grayih Calx, which together with the ret of the Metal being weigh'd again, there was very near, if not full, ix grains of increae of weight acquir'd by the Operation.

1. N. B. The Lump of Lead, that remain'd after the newly recited Operation, being eparated from the Calx, was weighed and cut in pieces, that it might be put into a freh Retort, wherein it was again expos'd to the flame of Spirit of Wine, that I might atisfie my elf, whether probably the whole Body of the Lead might not, by repeated Operations, or (perhaps by one continued long enough) be reduc'd to Calx. And though, after the Retort (whoe neck had been drawn out) had been kept in the flame for about two hours, it was, by the negligence of a Footboy, unluckily broken, and ome of
the Calx lot; yet we made a hift to ave about five grains of it, (whoe colour was yellowih;) which was enough to make it likely, that, if we had had conveniency to purue the Operation to the utmot, the whole Metal might have been calcin'd by the action of the flaming Spirit.

2. N. B. And let you hould be induc'd by ome Chymical conceits to imagine, that the particles that once belong'd to flame, did make more than a Coalition with thoe of the Lead, and by a perfect Union were Really tranmuted into the Metal whoe weight they increas'd; I hall add, that (according to a Method elewhere deliver'd) I examin'd the even cruples of Calx, mention'd to have been made in the third Experiment, by weighing them in Air and Water, and thereby found, as I expected, that though the abolute Gravity of the Metal had been increas'd by the particles of Flame that tuck fat to it, yet this Aggregate
of Lead and extinguih'd Flame had lot much of its pecifick Gravity. For, whereas Lead is wont to be to Water of the ame bulk, as about eleven and a half to one, this ubtil Calx of Lead was to Water of the ame bulk little, if at all, more than as nine to one.

Thee are not the only Experiments I made of the Operation of meer Flame upon Bodies inclos'd in Glaes; but thee, I uppoe, are ufficient to allow me to comply with my preent hate, and yet make good the Title prefixt to this Paper. For, whence can this increae of abolute weight (for I peak not of pecifick Gravity,) oberv'd by us in the Metals expos'd to the mere flame, be deduc'd, but from ome ponderable parts of that Flame? And how could thoe parts invade thoe of the Metal inclos'd in a Glas, otherwie than by paing through the pores of that Glas? But, becaue I judge it unphiloophical, either to more careful that what one writes hould appear trange, than be true;
or to be forward to advance the repute of Strangenes, to the prejudice of the Interet of Truth, though it be perhaps but a remote one, or a collateral one; I hall deal o impartially, as to ubjoyn on this occaion two or three hort Intimations, that may prove both eaonable for Caution, in reference to the Porounes of Glas, and give a hint or two in relation to other Things.

I do not then by the foregoing Experiments pretend to make out the Poroity of Glas any farther, than is expret in the Title of this Paper; namely, in reference to ome of the Ponderable parts of Flame. For otherwie I am not at all of their mind, that think Glas is eaily penetrable, either, as many do, by Chymical Liquors; or, as ome, by Quickilver; or, as others, at leat by our Air: Thoe opinions not agreeing with the Experiments I made purpoely to examine them, as you may find in another Paper.

Again, if we compare the Increae
we oberve to be made in the Weight of the Bodies that we expoe to the naked Fire, and thoe of the ame or the like kinds that we included in Glaes, or o much as in Crucibles; it may be worth conidering, Whether this difference in acquir'd weight may not give caue to upect, that the Corpucles, whereof Fire and Flame conits, are not all of the ame ize, and equally agitated, but that the interpos'd Veel keeps out the groer Particles like a kind of Strainer, though it gives paage to the minutet and mot active?

I offer it alo to Conideration, Whether this perviounes of Glas, even to the minute particles that pervade it, and their adheion to the Metal they work on, does necearily imply Pores constantly great enough to tranmit uch Corpucles? or, Whether it may not be aid, that Glas is generally of a cloer Texture, than when in our Experiments the pores are open'd by the vehement Heat of the flame that beats upon it,
and in that tate may let pas Corpucles too big to permeate Glas in its ordinary tate; and that this penetration is much aited by the vehement agitation of the Igneous parts, which by the rapidnes of their motion both force themelves a paage through the narrow pores of the Glas, and pierce deep enough into thoe of the included Body to tick fat there; (as hail-hot thrown with ones hand againt a board, will pas off from it, but being hot out of a Gun will pierce it, and lodge themelves in it?) And I know a Mentruum that does not work upon a certain Metal whilt the liquor is cold, or but faintly heated, and yet by intending the Heat would be made to turn it into a powder or Calx, (for it does not properly diolve it.)

Perhaps it may not be amis to add on this occaion, that though Glas be generally acknowledged to have far maller pores, than any other matter wont to be implyed to make veels, that are to be expos'd
to the fire; yet till I be farther atisfy'd, I hall forbear both to determine, whether the rectitude, that ome Philoophers uppoe in the pores of Glas, as 'tis a tranparent body, or rather in their ranks or rows, may facilitate the Perviounes we above oberv'd in Glas, and to conclude from the foregoing Experiments, that ponderable parts of Flame will be able as well to pas through the pores of Metalline veels as thoe of Glas. For though, with a ilver veel, made merely of plate without Soder, I made two or three Tryals (of which you may command an account) in order to the reolving of thee doubts; yet by an accident, which, though it were not a urprizing one, was unlucky enough to defeat my endeavours, I was kept, for want of fit Accommodations, from bringing my intended tryals to an iue.

And now having endeavour'd by the foregoing Advertiements to prevent the having unafe Conequences
drawn from our Experiments; it remains that I briefly point at three our four Corollaries that may more warily be deduc'd from them. To which, if I get time, I may ubjoyn a hint or two about further Inquiries.

div.head: COROLLARY I.
Confirming this PARADOX, That Flame may act as a Mentruum, and make Coalitions with the Bodies it works on.
div.p:
THE Experiments, we have made and recited of the premeating of Flame (as to ome of its parts) through Glas-veels, and of its working on included Metals, may much confirm the Paradox I have elewhere propos'd, That Flame may be a Mentruum, and work on ome Bodies at the rate of being o; I mean not only by making a notable Comminution and Diipation of the parts,
but by a Coalition of its own particles with thoe of the fretted Body, and thereby permanently adding Subtance and Weight to them. Nor is it repugnant to Flames, being a Menstruum, that in our experiment the Lead and Tin, expos'd to it, were but reduc'd to powder, and not diolv'd in the form of a Liquor, and kept in that tate. For, beides that the interpos'd Glas hinder'd the Igneous particles from getting through in plenty enough; I conider, that 'tis not neceary, that all Mentruums hould be uch Solvents, as the objection uppoes. For whether it be (as I have ometimes upected,) that Mentruums, that we think imple, may be compounded of very differing parts, whereof one may precipitate what is diolved by the other; or for ome other Caue, I have not now time to dicus. Certain it is, that ome Mentruums corrode Metals and other Bodies without keeping diolved all, or perhaps any coniderable part; as may be een, if you put Tin
in a certain quantity of Aqua fortis, which will in a very hort time reduce it almot totally to a very white ubtance, which, when dry, is a kind of Calx. And o by a due proportion of Oyl of Vitriol, abtracted from Quickilver by a trong fire, we have divers times reduc'd the main body of the Mercury into a white powder, whereof but an inconiderable part would be dioluble in water. And uch a white Calx I have had by the action of another fretting Liquor on a Body not Metalline.

And having thus clear'd our Paradox of the oppos'd Difficulty, my hate would immediately carry me on to the next Corollary, were it not, that there is one Phaenomenon belonging to this place that deerves to be taken notice of. For, whether it be, as eems probable, from the vehement agitation of the permeating particles of Flame, that violently tear aunder the Metalline Corpucles, or from the nature of the Igneous Mentruum, (which being as 'twere percolated
through Glas it elf, mut be trangely minute,) 'tis worth oberving, how mall a proportion, in point of weight, of the additional adhering Body may erve to corrode a Metal, in comparion of the Quantity of vulgar Menstruums that is requiite for that purpoe. For, whereas we are oblig'd to imploy, to the making the olution of crude Lead, everal times its weight of Spirit of Vinegar, and (though not o many times) even of Aqua fortis, 'twas oberv'd in our Experiment, that, though the Lead was increas'd but ix grains in weight, yet above ix core of it were fretted into powder, o that the Corroive Body appear'd to be but about the twentieth part of the corroded.

div.head: COROLL. II.
Propoing a PARADOX about Calcination and Calces.
div.p:
Another Conequence, deducible from our dicovery of the perviounes
of Glas to Flame, may be this; That there is caue to quetion the Truth of what is generally taken for granted about Calcination, and particularly of the notion, that not only others, but Chymits themelves, have entertain'd about the Calces of Metals and Minerals. For, whereas 'tis commonly uppos'd, that in Calcination the greater part of the Body is driven away, and only the Earth, to which Chymits add the Fixt Salt, remains behind; and whereas even Mechanical Philoophers, (for two or three of Them have taken notice of Calcination,) are of opinion, that much is driven away by the violence of the fire; and the remaining parts by being depriv'd of their more radical and fixt moiture are turn'd into dry and brittle particles: Whereas thee Notions, I ay, are entertain'd about Calcination, it eems, that they are not well fram'd, and do not univerally hold; ince, at leat they are not applicable to the Metals, our Experiments were made on. For, it does not appear
by our Tryals, that any proportion, worth regarding, of moit and fugitive parts was expell'd in the Calcination; but it does appear very plainly, that by this Operation the Metals gain'd more weight than they lot; o that the main body of the Metal remain'd intire, and was far from being, either as a Peripatetick would think, Elementary Earth, or a compound of Earth and Fixt Salt, as Chymits commonly uppoe the Calx of Lead to be. From which very erroneous Hypotheis they are wont to inferr the weet Vitriol of Lead, which they call Saccharum Saturni, to be but the weet Salt of it extracted only by the Spirit of Vinegar, which does indeed plentifully enough concurr to compoe it. Whence I conclude, that the Calx of a Metal even made (as they peak) per e, that is, by fire without additament, may be, at leat in ome caes, not the Caput mortuum, or Terra damnata, but a Magitery of it. For, in the ene of the mot intelligible of the Chymical Writers, that is
properly a Magitery wherein the Principles are not eparated, but the bulk of the Body being preerved, it acquires a new and convenient form by the addition of the Mentruum or Solvent imployed about the preparation. And, not here to borrow any Argument from my Notes about particular Qualities, you may gues, how true it is, that the greatet part of the Body, or all the radical moiture is expell'd in Calcination, which therefore turns the Metal into an arid unfuible powder; by this, That I have everal times from Calx of Lead reduc'd corporal Lead. And I remember, that having taken what I gues'd to be but about a third or fourth part of the Calx of Lead, produc'd by the third Experiment; I found by a tryal purpoely devis'd, that without any Flux-powder or any additament, but meerly by the application of the Flame of highly Rectified Spirit of Wine, there could in a hort time be obtain'd a coniderable proportion of malleable Lead;
whereof the part I had the Curioity to examine, was true malleable Lead; o little was the arid powder, whence this was reduc'd, depriv'd by the foregoing Calcination of the uppo'sd radical moiture requiite to a Metal. The Conideration of what may be drawn from this Reduction in reference to the Doctrine of Qualities belongs not to this place.

div.head: COROLL. III.
div.p:
One ue, among the ret, we may make, by way of Corollary, of the foregoing Dicovery, which is in reference to a Controverie warmly agitated among the Corpucular Philoophers themelves. For, ome of them, that follow the Epicurean or Atomical Hypotheis, think, that when Bodies are expos'd in cloe veels to the fire, though the Igneous Corpucles do not tay with the Bodies they invade, yet they really get through the Pores of the interpos'd Veels, and permeate the included
Bodies in their paage upwards; whereas others, epecially favourers of the Carteian Doctrine, will not allow the Atomits Igneous Corpucles, which they take to be but vehemently agitated particles of Terretrial matter, to penetrate uch minute pores as thoe of Glas; but do uppoe the operation of the fire to be perform'd by the vehement agitation made of the mall parts of the Glas, and by them propagated to the included Bodies, whoe particles by this violent Commotion are notably alter'd, and receive new Textures, or other modifications.

But our Experiments inform us, that, though neither of the two Opinions eems fit to be depied, yet neither eems to have hit the very mark; though the Epicurean Hypotheis comprize omewhat more of the Truth than the other. For, though it be not improbable, that the brisk agitation communicated by the mall parts of the Glas to thoe of the Body contain'd in it, may contribute much
