to the effect of the fire; and though, by the mall increment of weight, we found in our expos'd Metal, 'tis very likely, that far the greater part of the Flame was excluded by the cloe Texture of the Glas; yet on the other ide 'tis plain, that Igneous particles were trajected through the Glas, which agrees with the Epicureans; and they, on the other ide, mitook, in thinking that they did but pas through, and divide and agitate the included Bodies; to which nevertheles our Experiments hew, that enough of them, to be manifetly ponderable, did permanently adhere.

Whether thee Igneous Corpucles do tick after the like manner to the parts of meat, dret by the help of the fire, and epecially roat-meat, which is more immediately expos'd to the action of the fire, may be a quetion, which I hall now leave undicus'd, becaue I think it difficult to be determin'd, though otherwie it eems worthy to be conider'd, in regard it may concern mens Health,
to know, whether the Coction of meat be made by the fire, only as 'tis a very hot body, or whether it permanently communicates any thing of its ubtance to the meat expos'd to it: In which (lat) cae it may be upected, that not only the degree and manner of application of a fire, but the nature of its fuel may be fit to be conider'd.

div.head: COROLL. IV.
div.p: The Experiments above recited give us this further Information, That Bodies very pirituous, fugitive, and minute, may, by being aociated with congruous particles, though of quite another nature, o change their former Qualities, as to be arreted, by a olid and ponderous Body, to that degree, as not to be driven away from it by a fire intene enough to melt and calcine Metals.

For, the foregoing Tryals (taking in what IExp. III. N. B. 2. lately deliver'd of the leen'd pecifick Gravity of calcin'd Lead)
eems plainly enough to dicover, that even the agitated parts of flame, minute enough to pas through the pores of Glas it elf, were as 'twere entangled among the metalline particles of Tin and Lead, and thereby brought to be fixt enough to endure the Heat that kept thoe Metals in fuion, and little by little reduc'd them into calces: Which is a Phaenomenon that one would not eaily look for, epecially conidering how imple a Texture that of Lead or Tin may be uppos'd to be in comparion of the more elaborate tructures of very many other Bodies. And this Phaenomenon, which hews us, what light and fugitive particles of matter may permanently concurr to the Compoition of Bodies ponderous and fixt enough, may perchance afford ueful hints to the Speculative; epecially if this trict Combination of pirituous and fugitive ubtance with uch, as being gros or unwieldy, are les fit than organiz'd matter to entangle or detain them, be applied, (as it
may be with advantage) to thoe aggregates of pirituous Corpucles, and organical Parts, that make up the Bodies of Plants and Animals. And this hint may ugget a main Inference to be drawn from the Operations of the Sun-beams on appropriated ubjects, uppoing it to prove like that of flame on Tin and Lead.

And now having dipatch'd our COROLLARIES, we might here inquire, Whether all the particles of Fire and Flame, that are ubtile and agitated enough to penetrate Glas, and faten themelves to included Bodies, be reduc'd by Ignition to the ame nature, or ele retain omewhat of their proper Qualities? Which Inquiry I have ome caue not to think o undeterminable, as at firt bluh it may appear. For, one of the ways, that may be propos'd for this Examen, is already intimated at the cloe of the third Experiment, which hews, that we may compare the pecifick Gravity of the Calces of the
ame Metal, made in Glaes by the operation of Flames; whoe fuels are of very differing Natures. And I aid, one of the ways, becaue 'tis not the only way I could name, and have partly tryed. But though I might ay more concerning Expedients of this kind, and could perhaps propound other Inquiries that may reaonably enough be grounded upon the hitherto recited Phaenomena (and thoe of ome other like tryals,) yet I mut not uneaonably forget, that the puruit of uch Diquiitions would lead me much farther than I have now the leiure to follow it.

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.
div.p:
IT hath been thought, it might be the Interet of the Reader, epecially Foreiners, to be advertied, That thee Eays are already Tranlating into Latin, and beginning alo to be printed in that Language; which that it may duly be done, both as to this and the Author's other Writings, to be publiht for the future, the greater care will be taken here, becaue it hath been everal times found both at home and elewhere, that the Verions made of them abroad, and not in the place, where in cae of any difficulty the Author may be conulted with by the Latin Interpreters, are often very defective, and not eldom injurious to the ene he hath deliver'd them in. Which being conider'd by thoe that deire to know the genuine ene of the Author, 'tis preumed, they will rather chooe thoe Verions, which are made by perons that have that advantage of comulting him in any cae of doubt, than
uch as hall mis-inform them; notwithstanding the pretence of a cheaper rate of the Book.

Which being thus advertied, the Printer taketh this opportunity of farther acquainting the Reader from the Latin Interpreter, that thee Eays, to his knowledge, were ready and in the Pres everal Months before Dr. Thomas Bartholin's Acta Philoophica & Medica appear'd in England, in which there are two or three paages that may eem of affinity with ome to be met with in the latter part of the Papers about Experiments of Arreting the parts of Flame, and of making them Ponderable.
